name: Child of the ’50s
lastTime: Holidays. Memories of what was can make it a very lonely time.
lonelinessMeans: It’s missing something or feeling disconnected from what the world says should be a busy exciting fun time. I’ve felt lonely in a room of happy partying people. I am not good at watching frivolous stupidity. Guess I’m a loner who is never lonely. I visit archives and never want to leave because I discover things that excite me. I can have great conversations with strangers in odd places and feel connected. Loneliness is so different for everyone. I don’t need people around me. I do need a few I can connect with for specific interests and projects. That sustains me.
mostLonely: I’m too old to put a specific on that but think my first Christmas away from family would be near the top. I could hardly make the call home and not cry. But I see it now as just a stepping stone to growing up. Life will send more difficult times than a Christmas away from family. You will find you are not alone at facing sad lonely times. That’s when it’s time to reach out. Find the lonely. Create your own special time. Make a new memory. You don’t have to conform to society’s normal expectation and tradition. Change the expectation and tradition. Don’t focus on yourself and the loneliness will lessen. Look outward and you’ll find what or who was meant to brighten your day. Find your purpose and you won’t have time for loneliness. Be kind to yourself. Buy yourself your favourite birthday cake, light the candles, sing the song and eat the whole thing! Because you can. Because you’re alive.
firstTime: At a party. It wasn’t my scene. The conversation was mind-numbing. Would have preferred to be at home with a good book.

name: Anonymous
lastTime: Last night at 3:00 am. As usual I could not get to sleep easily. My sister, who I am currently living with, fell asleep before me and I suddenly felt entirely alone in the darkness of the night. I looked out the window to see other apartment buildings with a few scattered lights turned on and wondered who else might be awake with me. Even though they were visible and across the street, they were so far away.
lonelinessMeans: Feeling disconnected and isolated in that disconnection. More than anything loneliness for me is about feeling alone in a crowd; a certain kind of sadness with not finding my tribe; an inability to relate to the popular values presented in mainstream media in North America; not being able to find a place of comfort and safety outside of my own home; a disappointment and disconnect with the mainstream ways of the world.
mostLonely: Later in life I wound up in a leadership role with more than forty employees and several direct reports at the company where I worked. It was a high profile position that involved public speaking, television appearances, attending galas, and meeting upon meeting. I was inundated with people coming and going from my office. I had a narcissistic boss who was emotionally abusive. I realized that I was the buffer for all these wonderfully talented people but I couldn’t really talk about how difficult the experience was for me with anyone at the office. When things became really challenging, I would take long walks, stay in the washroom for longer periods of time, or I would get sick and stay home from work. Even though I had this highly public job, I was utterly lonely.
firstTime: At a birthday party when I was 6 or 7 year old. All of the other kids were playing games, yelling, and making noise — generally having a fun time I suppose. But I just wasn’t up to joining in. I knew that, generally speaking, I was more at ease in quiet, one-on-one situations where a real connection can be shared between friends. Unable to join in the fun, I retreated to a quiet room to play alone until my mom came to pick me up.

name: Maisa
lastTime:
The last time I felt lonely was a few days ago. It was dusk and I decided to go for a walk around the new neighbourhood I just moved into. It’s a residential area, with calm streets, beautiful houses and little parks. I like to look at each house and see what kind of lives are being lived in it. I could smell food being made inside homes, and I could hear kids playing in the backyard. I realized how badly I crave family life, and miss my family who lives all the way in Brazil.

I felt lonely because there is always a dissonance to what I am experiencing. I never lived in big Canadian houses growing up. They look like the movies.

I never walked my golden retriever in a park. I never ran unsupervised with my friends, freely, around the neighbourhood.

Instead of bemoaning how badly I miss Brazil - the music, the warmth, the colours and trees, and most importantly, my language - I am here now. I am trying to let go of my old life (kicking and screaming) and build a Canadian life. It feels like the loneliest thing in the world to do. I don’t know anybody else who is doing it. I have one foot here, and one foot there all the time. And I wonder if when I am walking around my neighbourhood, standing outside somebody’s house trying to negotiate all of this...whether anyone inside can understand what it feels like.
lonelinessMeans: Not being able to relate to others, physically being away from familiar people, sounds, language, food.
mostLonely:
My loneliness comes in waves. I feel very lonely when I think about my niece back home, and how I’ve only met her once, and haven’t seen her in person in two years. I feel lonely that she gets to hang up on me whenever she likes on FaceTime because I’m not truly physically a person to her. And that can also be a little bit funny.

I feel lonely the most around the holidays because I have to spend it with other people’s families. I am so grateful that I have somewhere to go, but at the same time, I get exhausted having to adopt other people’s lives, customs, etc. My mind is always somewhere else around the holidays. I have definitely cried in bathrooms after Christmas dinner.

I feel lonely when I hear people talking about immigrants in a particular way, because I am an immigrant, even though I don’t look like what people perceive an immigrant to be. I feel lonely that my partner doesn’t like my country’s cuisine. I feel lonely when I want to greet people with a warm hug and kisses on their cheeks, but Canadians don’t really like being touched. I feel lonely when nobody asks me about Brazil, or asks how my family is doing.
firstTime: When people kept forgetting that I was foreign. My English is flawless, and so it’s hard to discern that I am from a different country. I feel lonely each time I have to remind my close friends and my partner of 7 years that I had a different experience than they did. They forget. They just forget, and will start to tell stories and say "you know?" and truly, I don’t know a lot of the time. I don’t know the TV shows they are referring to, the old movies, the places, the regular Canadian experiences they had.

name: Lily
lastTime: When was the last time I didn’t?
lonelinessMeans: Feeling left behind.
mostLonely: I’m not sure if there was one specific time, but to me the feeling of loneliness has encompassed my 20s. It’s the feeling that everyone else around me knows exactly what they want out of their lives - the type of partner they want, the career they’re pursuing. I’ve never felt clear about who I am and as a result it has been difficult to define what I want out of my time on this planet. It can be very isolating and, well, lonely to feel that everyone around you is moving forward while you remain cemented to where you are. Loneliness to me is not knowing which direction to step, and watching those around me walk miles ahead without looking back. While I’m happy for them, I just wish I could keep up.
firstTime: Middle school.

name: Chloe
lastTime: Every time I’m by myself with my thoughts.
lonelinessMeans: Being the person people see you as instead of the person you know you are.
mostLonely: Some nights when my depression gets bad, I badly need someone to talk to, and the first time I had a full on wave of depression was the first time I realized I had no one to talk to about it. No one I knew was I comfortable to share it with, and my parents were definitely out of the picture. I was forced to internalize it, and the next day when I went to school I expected people to notice that I was not alright, and that I needed someone to talk to and didn’t know who to reach out to. No one noticed. I realized then that it didn’t matter how I felt on the inside and how well I knew myself if everyone I know sees me as a bright and happy girl. If I’m the only person that actually knows who I am, how does anyone really know me at all? Are we really the people we know ourselves to be if everyone else has a different image of us? Do I exist outside of their main image of me?
firstTime: When I was really upset and really needed to talk to someone, but realized that I didn’t have anyone to confide in.

name: K
lastTime: I threw a holiday party, and only a fraction of the people I invited showed up.
lonelinessMeans: Your life doesn't have a witness. Others are indifferent to you, and aren't interested in knowing you on a deeper level.
mostLonely: Whenever I am tired after work, or sick, and want nothing more than to get into pajamas and be comfortable - but then I realize that there is no food in the house or no cold medicine, and there is no one there I can ask "hey, can you do me a favor and go get Sudafed", and I have to get back out of my pajamas and trudge out to the market to get it myself. Whenever that happens, I always feel that there is no one who has my back at the little moments when I need it; I do have friends I know would help when I have a genuine crisis, but it‘s someone having your back in the mundane moments that REALLY matters.

name: Leigh
lastTime: Monday - Friday, 8AM - 5PM
lonelinessMeans: I work from home running a tech related businesses. Some weeks 2-3 days will go by without seeing another human, well, except my husband. My husband is military and during the year he'll be gone for training exercises. He also has quite a long daily commute to his 9-5 job. My husband is an introvert so I try not to dump my loneliness on him too much. Since I moved to this rural town (no 'neighborhood') 18 years ago I really have not been able to make friends, mostly due to religious and political differences, and my specific hobby interests I'm sure. All of my life I've only ever had one or two good friends at any given time. This makes going through life transitions a bit difficult, especially when a transition removes a friend from your daily life.
mostLonely:
Last summer was kind of hard. Both my kids are now married and their military lives have taken them far away. My husband was in and out of town all spring / summer doing military training. My best friend got a new boyfriend and stopped doing our usual routines (going to our favorite sandwich shop, doing carpentry projects, hiking, and just getting into mischief).

My husband and I found land closer to his work that is actually within a series of small neighborhoods, with people who have similar interests/hobbies. We‘re in the process of buying it and starting a new chapter where we can actually KNOW people we live around. Everyone there seems very nice and relatable. But it‘s also been hard to think about moving from the home I raised my children, and moving away from my best friend.

I‘ve been having a really hard time with nostalgia. Music from my youth, thinking about being a child again... and wondering if there will be fun times to be had and memories to be made when I look back on this time in 20 years from now.
firstTime: I guess I've always craved to have and be around friends, people you share common interests, and create memories and a support web with. But loneliness really hit me when my kids grew up and moved out/away. Empty nest syndrome is no joke. Around that time is when my boss retired and I took over the business and started working from home. It's been about 4 years now and the loneliness of my youth has returned with a vengeance. It's starting to affect my work/business.

name: Megan
lastTime: Today
lonelinessMeans: Feeling like no one is thinking of you or wants to be around you
mostLonely:
I was in Boston for a summer internship. I knew two people there from back home who were going to school. One of them was one of my best friends. We had known each other since Kindergarten. I was so depressed and lonely being in a new city by myself with my boyfriend back in California and my family in Colorado. I would go to work and basically come right back home to an empty house. I explored the city a lot on my own but it only did so much. I wanted to see my friend so badly, but she didn‘t have time for me. She had school and her own life there, and I felt like she didn‘t even care that I was in the same city as her, even though we hadn‘t seen each other in a year.

One day she finally told me she didn‘t want to see me. She said she couldn‘t be friends with someone who made her feel guilty for not spending time with them. That was not my intention at all, I just really needed a friend at that time. I suffer from depression normally and being isolated in a new city was making it worse. I haven't seen or really talked to her since.

To make matters worse, right before the holidays another one of my best friends from elementary school back home told me she couldn't be friends with someone who didn't support our president (Trump!) and blocked my phone number and me on all outlets of social media. She was one of the only friends I had left that still lived in my hometown. Now being home for the holidays is just a lonely reminder that I will never have those friendships that I cherished so much again.
firstTime: When my friends in college started hanging out with each other without me there, after I had introduced them.

name: Ella
lonelinessMeans: Feeling undeniably empty and unwanted – by others, and by yourself.
mostLonely:
As I sit alone, in the upstairs spare room of my parents house, I come to terms of just how lost I feel. It has been two years since my family and I have moved almost 3,000 miles away from my old "home", and even though moving is second nature to me, tonight, the feelings I have encountered are nothing short than devastating. Mixed with seasonal depression, homesickness, and the stress a future I have yet to figure out and stabilize – I attempt to complete the endless amounts of worksheets and forms to pass my high school classes, as well as college classes I dual enrolled in. I am already behind.

Tonight is also Halloween. The fact alone, that I have done nothing at all to celebrate my favorite holiday, nor acknowledge its existence this year, due to my work load and unrelenting stress leaves me upset. In such a state that it‘s painful to continue on working. I can barely recall any months past August of this year; it ends up in becoming a blur of me counting down hours until the next deadline, and consuming unhealthy amounts of caffeine and sugar to keep my body awake.

Maybe the worst part about it is my entire family is out celebrating with their friends. They are out trick or treating, partying, and conversing with people they know and love while I‘m left crying all over the couch because I don‘t have a single friend in the entire state. But maybe that‘s just selfish.

My best friends, who live now very far away from me, are partying too. They have a group chat open and keep sending me photos of how much fun they are having, making me sick to my stomach. Eventually it got so painful I had to silence the messages and put my phone on the other side of the room. Deep somewhere, I wonder if they even care about me anymore, or if they keep up appearances because I try to remain friends with them.

But somehow – writing all of this down makes me feel better. And for that, I have you to thank.

name: Anonymous
lastTime: Every single day
mostLonely: Ever since I got married and came to live in another country. It has not been easy. I feel really alone. The people in this country are very friendly but they are not looking for friends. It’s very hard to find a group of friends here. That, and the language barrier. I haven’t felt this lonely in my life. I often think it was not worth to get married, he’s a good person and tries his best but it’s not enough.

name: Emily
lastTime: I've felt lonely off and on since I was 19, but the older I get, the more intense these feelings become.
lonelinessMeans: Isolation. Even when I'm in a room full of people I know, the isolation I feel can be overwhelming. You know when you're with two other people and the three of you can't all fit on the sidewalk together, so someone has to be the one to walk alone in the back? That's been me. My whole life. That feeling of intentional isolation swallows me up and it's a hole that I can stay in for weeks at a time.
mostLonely: After college, I moved to a different state for work, where I had literally no family or friends prior to moving. I had such high hopes of making a fresh start for myself and finally meeting my "squad", that "Friends"-esque type family that you build for yourself and aren‘t born into. Well, finding that is easier said than done, but I felt that I had found that with my coworkers. We‘re all around the same age and enjoy spending time with one another. However, as time goes on, I‘ve found that we‘re drifting apart and don‘t really connect the same way we used to. We used to all go to lunch together, and would round everyone up so we could all eat together in the break room. Recently though, I looked up from my computer and realized that I was all alone in the office. It was 11:30, and everyone had gone to lunch without me, and never told me that they were leaving. I felt so abandoned and isolated, that it triggered my loneliness again and I‘ve been struggling to cope since. I've found that being left out of group conversations, jokes, etc. is a big trigger for me, and so even though this incident was small, it felt so deliberate, that I've been wondering why my "squad" has decided that I'm not important enough to them to include on a regular basis anymore. What did I do wrong? Why don't I warrant their interaction, companionship and camaraderie? Thankfully, I have a wonderful best friend that lives in the same city as I do now, and my family (my parents in particular) are the people I'm closest to in the world, so I know that I can pick up the phone, day or night, and talk to the people who love me more than anything else in the world. I'm so incredibly grateful for this, but I long to have the "squad goals" that everyone else my age seems to have. Then that leads to feeling guilty for not being appreciative enough of the people that I do have in my life, causing a vicious cycle of loneliness, guilt and despair.
firstTime: When I was in college, I sat on my bed, and just bawled my eyes out for hours begging a deity I don't even think I believe in, to give me just one friend. I wrote in a notebook over and over and over, "Please, just one. Please, just one. Please, just one," for pages and pages as I sobbed, because I had nothing else to do. I don't have any friendships that have lasted years and years, because inevitably, the people I considered my closest friends have treated me in ways that had severe negative impacts on my mental health and fractured our relationships beyond repair, so I've had to sever ties with them. I only made one friend the entire time I was in college, because I transferred to so many different schools, that by the time I was somewhere for longer than a semester, everyone had already established friend groups that I just couldn't penetrate and belong to. So I begged the universe for "just one friend". I found them, thankfully, but honestly, the connection I have with them isn't very deep, but I have so few people in my life, I feel compelled to maintain my relationship with them, even though we live on different sides of the country and can go months without speaking.

name: Tessa
mostLonely:
I went to a party that my two friends were hosting. I got a haircut the day before, and even though my hair was short, I really liked it. I walked in the door, and everyone went, "Your hair!" Some people said nice things, but most people just commented on how short it was. I went to go surprise my best friend, and she turned around and couldn’t stop laughing. She told me it was the worst haircut I’ve EVER had, and that I looked like a guy. I felt my gut shrivel up a bit, but I brushed it off, pretending not to care.

Later on at the party, there was music playing. Half the people were dancing, and the other half were sitting on the side and judging (including my best friend). I got sick sitting on the side, so I got up to dance. A couple of my new friends dancing hyped me up, and then I saw my best friend laughing at me.
I was actually making an attempt to dance, so I kept doing it, but no one was paying attention to me, and I felt just really alone. I called my parents to pick me up.

I’m still "friends" with my best friend, but I don’t know what to do. She’s nice to me most of the time, but she just has these mean things she does. I can’t ditch her because she’s one of my only friends, and the oldest, and my parents love her.

I wish I could just be me.

name: Annie
lastTime: Today.
lonelinessMeans: Feeling adrift and untethered, as if you could just blow away in a strong wind and no one would notice that you were gone.
mostLonely: I feel lonely now that I realize the person I loved the most in the world was not who they said they were. I put a lot of myself into a relationship that was hampered by addiction. It is hard to realize that someone cares more about chemicals or substances than another person. Grief is really a lonely place. Once an addict is "outed‘ all the focus is on trying to help them, but that doesn‘t solve the loneliness inside when you realize that all of your dreams for the future aren‘t ever going to work out. Addiction is also really socially isolating. It is hard to admit what you are going through to others and people can be so judgemental and tell you you should have seen the signs. By the time it falls apart you can be so alone that it feels like there is no-one left to turn to for help. Self-help meetings are okay, but everyone is so caught up in their own sadness that it can be too upsetting to go and make you feel worse.
firstTime: When I was young and I realized my cat couldn't come to school with me.

name: Wendy
lastTime: At a 60th birthday party
lonelinessMeans: Feeling like you have no connection to anyone in the room
mostLonely: I created a network on the sunshine coast for women who felt lonely.  As a result of that I was at a 60th Birthday Party and everyone who was at that party the host had met through the group.  It was a great night, lots of laughing and dancing.  I was the only one who‘s partner didn‘t come along, and I sat at the back of the room watching, feeling very proud but also so lonely.
firstTime: I made a meal for the family, we ate together, then everyone got up and I was left sitting at the table alone, and to clear up.

name: Lauren
lastTime: Today
lonelinessMeans: Experiencing a numb feeling in your mind and limbs but a suffocating feeling in your throat and chest
mostLonely: My best friend who was practically my sister started ignoring me. I still don’t know why. I’ve tried reaching out and letting her know how hurt I am and how much she means to me. She hasn’t acknowledged how I feel or explained herself. I know she might be going through her own stuff, but the lack of the most basic acknowledgment still has me feeling anxious, angry, helpless, taken advantage of, and worthless. She was the closest friend I had. If she could do this to me, my other friends could too. This made me feel so alone and paranoid.
firstTime: Crying on a bench by myself at recess when I fell on the pavement. I was all scratched up and bleeding. None of the other kids asked if I was okay. They didn’t even realize I was there. I spent that recess alone and in pain.

name: Evan
lastTime: 2 weeks ago. My date got cancelled.
lonelinessMeans: Sending out all the love you've got, but receiving none back.
mostLonely:
I‘ve never been in a relationship with anyone. Hell, I‘ve never even kissed anyone. There have been a couple of girls who I‘ve liked, but none of them were ever interested in me. Whenever I hear other guys my age talk about girls, they‘re always talking about sex. How they would like to try a threesome, or anal or god-knows-what. I would just want to have somebody to hug me. Someone to hold hands with when we walk, someone to talk to endlessly, someone to go to concerts and festivals with me. I want someone to sleep with, literally. Stare at the stars and falling asleep in each others arms.

It all seemed so hopeful 2 weeks ago. I matched with this girl via Tinder. She was everything I ever hoped for. Kind, super pretty, lived relatively nearby and (at least via text) super nice to talk to. We chatted for about 2 months before she finally agreed to go on a date with me. Everything was set, location, date, time, you name it. I had made countless preparations, bought her flowers, practiced how to fold crane birds in case she went to the bathroom during our date, thought about jokes to tell her, printed out a staple of funny question cards we could ask each other in case there would fall an awkward silence. I had even washed my shoes, or at least made an effort to. But the day that it all would happen she texted me. She wanted to cancel the date since she felt like she wasn't ready yet to start a (new) relationship. I felt so sad, broken and alone. I had been looking forward to this for god-knows-how-long. I replied as kind and understanding as I could, which she really appreciated, but she had already made up her mind. We have kept contact since then, and I've tried to arrange a second date. This time just as friends though. It might happen sometime next week. I remain hopeful, I can't wait to see her and talk to her in real life sometime. Even if we would become "only friends" I'd still be super happy.
firstTime: In the 3rd year of high-school. I had a crush on a girl in my class, but realized there was no way she'd ever love me.

name: Lilah
lastTime: The short answer? now, but really, I feel lonely often. There is the 4pm lonely and there is the 2am lonely. They're different, but they hurt the same.
lonelinessMeans: I imagine my loneliness to be an all consuming blanket of selfishness, insecurity, pain and isolation. It surrounds me and traps me, always lingering long enough to become uncomfortable. For me though, it isn’t a single emotion, I never suddenly realise I'm feeling lonely, it's not like that. After a major earthquake, the smaller tremors that follow are often just as dangerous - the shaking of already vulnerable and fragile land can only cause more damage. Similarly the emotions that follow loneliness are as overwhelming as the isolation, but I think in a sense they have a greater impact because they help contribute to loneliness, they help its significance in my life grow. It's as if rather than competing with each other, they join together to create something seemingly impossible to overcome.
mostLonely:
I’m in a city which allows for so much adventure and experience. So many people to meet and things to do. I’m surrounded by opportunities. And yet I’m lonely. I feel so alone. I‘m young and I know I have a future ahead of me but right now I‘m living in hell. I‘m being told that I‘m living 'the best years of my life' but if this is what I'll feel for the next 70 years, then I don't want to experience the rest. It’s scary to feel this isolated, so removed from your own life. I can't name when I felt the most lonely because it's not predictable or constant. I never know when my mind is going to sabotage me and am never prepared so the feeling is always the same; miserable and agonising. I think I’m only starting to starting to realise it’s not solely a feeling, it’s a living. It’s a part of my life and myself and it's a part of human nature. I know I'm not alone in my feelings but still, I feel lonely.

P.S. I'm only sad so when I say I don't want to experience the rest of my life I don't meant that in a literal sense. I am in fact looking forward to growing up and hopefully growing away from this loneliness.

P.P.S. Thank you for what you are doing, sharing my thoughts makes me feel less lonely and the possibility of someone reading them and understanding what I'm saying makes everything a lot better.

name: Jacob
lastTime: Last week
lonelinessMeans: It is being unable to share a moment of emotion with another person. This moment can be anything from meeting someone for the first time, experiencing something together, or sharing something meaningful with another person.
mostLonely: My wife and I used to watch a lot of TV and movies together. It‘s been a struggle to get her to watch anything anymore with me. Finally I did get her to sit down and watch something we had been wanting to watch for a long time. A cringe worthy moment came that made me laugh and I turned to my wife and said "Can you believe they did that?" She‘s on her phone and after a long pause she just says "Uh huh." She doesn‘t stop or even look up. At that moment I wished I had someone to share that moment with. I realized I had no one else and the thought of finding someone terrified me.
firstTime:
I've been lonely for years, but I never realized it until college when I lost my small group of close friends and couldn't make more. By that point I was even too afraid to talk to the friends I already had because of my anxiety. Eventually those relationships died too leaving me completely alone.

Eventually I met my wife, we had kids, and I got through school and got a good job. I always thought that would fix my loneliness but it never did. While I'm surrounded by people, I'm isolated. My wife spends all her time on social media, hardly ever giving me her undivided attention. Work is just endless, meaningless, small talk. The kids are too young to have any meaningful adult connection with, when I'm not spending every waking second taking care of them. My wife isn't much help because she is glued to her phone all day. I thought i wasn't lonely for a long time, but recently I realized I'm lonelier than ever.

name: Stephanie
lastTime: Any time I think about it the loneliness is there. I’m pretty good at distracting myself from it but loneliness is a constant presence in my life.
lonelinessMeans: A sometimes empowering but mostly very sad security blanket.
mostLonely: For me loneliness isn’t an emotion that fluctuates so much as something that feels like a permanent part of my being. I learned at a young age that I could only count on myself for emotional support and that reaching out for help or appearing vulnerable is a bad thing (rationally I know this isn’t true and I’m in the process of unlearning some very bad habits and coping mechanisms but it’s not easy). I spent most of my life framing my loneliness as something empowering - I was completely self sufficient and didn’t need anyone’s help for anything, desperate to ignore the innate yearning for intimate human connection. I’m quite social and I have good friends but I’ve never been in a truly intimate relationship. The loneliness has become so much a part of me that, even though I recognize it’s sad and harmful, the idea of not being lonely is scary and confounding.
firstTime: Probably around puberty when I needed more complex emotional support than my parents were able to provide.

name: D
lastTime:
Right now, actually. Which is probably why I’m submitting this. I’m currently in the middle of a bed bug scare (have marks on my body that may be bites, but could also be hives). I’ve checked my mattress, took apart my bed frame, and searched my couch and found nothing. I’m getting a professional inspection done in 5 days. In the meantime, I’m staying at my partner’s and have washed all of my clothing I brought with me to make sure I haven’t brought anything unwanted with me.

Despite all this, two of my co-workers (who I also think of as friends) messaged me last night requesting I don’t come in to work today in case I pass the problem along. I am in grad school, so just deciding to not go in is a doable thing for me. I understand that bed bugs are terrifying and see where they are coming from, but on the other hand, if there was a risk of me spreading them, the damage would have been done as I was in for the past three days.

I am already terrified of what I might find out during the inspection, and now I feel like a pariah on top of that. I know it’s not about me, it’s about my situation, but to be told that I’m basically diseased and that me not being around would be less stressful is so incredibly isolating. I don’t know what to even say to them when I see them next week. I am incredibly upset and angry, and I can’t even tell if my reaction is valid or not. But I also know I feel incredibly lonely in this moment.
lonelinessMeans:
Feeling lonely when surrounded by others. Typically, when I’m lonely, I want to be with others when I’m by myself, but then wish I was by myself when I am with people. It’s the feeling of being lonely in a crowd, with my loneliness almost emphasized by the lack of loneliness I see around me.

Physiologically, loneliness feels like a pit in my stomach. It feels like nausea and hunger at the same time.

Funny story: One time, I thought I was having what I call a "lonely day" (when I wake up and feel lonely with no real reason for it) because I felt that pit in my stomach. Turns out I actually just had a stomach flu.
firstTime: When I was around 6 years old. My mom died when I was very young (I don’t remember her), and I started to understand what that meant around the age of 6. I felt like I was the only kid in the whole world whose mom had died, and for years I carried that loneliness with me.

name: Juliet
lastTime:
A week ago, coming home from school at around 4PM.

When I walked into my front yard, I could see that all of the blinds were shut, which is usually a pretty solid indication that my mother has been day drinking. Sometimes, I check the bins in front of our house for empty bottles of white wine, and that day, I saw a myriad of them which only confirmed my suspicions.

Anyway, I let myself in without hearing so much as a "Welcome home," went to my room, took off my bag and collapsed in my bed. It was when I was browsing my phone for any notifications that I may have overlooked, it hit me that I hadn’t said a word out loud, all day. There had been nobody to talk to after all considering I had a falling out with the ringleader of my friendship group a few weeks back. Next, came the realisation that nobody had said a word to me.

I felt like a ghost.
lonelinessMeans: Having a phone full of contacts, while feeling that there’s not a single person you can talk to.
mostLonely: I was in the hospital for a surgery. My boyfriend at the time didn’t visit because he couldn’t be bothered, and my friends all said they were too busy to show up. That night, I saw them on someone’s Snapchat story at a party. What stung the most however, was me knowing that had they been in my position, I would’ve crossed mountains to come running with "get well" cards, flowers and whatever else they would’ve wanted. I’ve done such things countless times before after all. Yet, I couldn’t even get so much as a visit. The only person who showed up was my mother, who raised me on her own. It made me want to never do a kind thing for anyone ever again.
firstTime: Father’s day when I was around 5. I was making a card for him, and just when I was about to draw a picture of him, my mother and I holding hands, I remembered that I didn’t even know what he looked like. They’re divorced with him living interstate, and I’d only ever talked to him on the phone. That day, I waited until 7PM for my mother to pick me up from work, after watching all of my classmates run into their father’s arms.

name: Anonymous
mostLonely: I felt most lonely the night the man I loved got married to someone else. He was my best friend for four years and the only man I ever really connected with. When we broke up, it was due to mounting pressure from third parties, not because either of us wanted out. I was young and stupid, and realized too late that I could have fought harder for our relationship. 2.5 years later and I still miss him every damn day. The worst part is, he started dating someone else within a few months and never looked back. My best friend went to his wedding.

name: Anon
lastTime: Tonight. I go to a school that is 150 miles away from my home. My home is where all of my family and my boyfriend resides. My closest friends have all either moved away or dropped out. I don’t even have a roommate. I have a semester and a half left until I graduate. It’s a lonely time, but I’ll get through it.
lonelinessMeans: Not getting the support that you need/want when you need/want it most.
mostLonely: I had a serious bout of anxiety come over me after I found out that my cancer came back. I remember sitting on my futon in my dorm room, alone, just crying for hours, just telling myself that I was going to be okay. No friends were there, and my family was on the other side of the state. All I needed was a very long hug from someone, literally anyone, but I didn’t want to seem weak. I eventually reached out to a therapist. It was the best decision I had ever made. I’m a lot better now.
firstTime: My first year as an RA. I became an RA my second year of college. During my freshman year, I had tons of friends and we all lived in the same building. Then, when I realized that this job would pay for my living, I jumped on it right away. Those friends that I had the year prior all moved in together and nobody wanted to be friends with the RA. That was also the year that I was going through my second cancer diagnosis… not really easy to balance a social life when it comes to stuff like that.

name: Victoria
lastTime: Today
lonelinessMeans: The abyss
mostLonely: I feel the most lonely when I‘m writing JavaScript. It feels like my soul is in an infinite loop, spiralling into the void with no help in sight.

name: Spencer
lastTime: Last night. My housemates and partner were all watching a show together, and when I came down to visit, I found that everyone had gone to bed. My partner hadn't even said good night.
lonelinessMeans: Reaching into a mystery box and only finding cardboard.
mostLonely: I was recently diagnosed with a mood disorder that has made my emotions unrecognizable to myself. I‘m angry or sad or anxious without cause. My partner is afraid of me because I can‘t check my reactions. I‘m in treatment, but I don‘t think it's working, and I can't return to intense psychiatric care until the end of the year or I'll lose my job. I feel like I'm going crazy and everyone in my life is just watching it happen.
firstTime: Middle school. I had no friends, my grades were failing, my father was verbally abusive, and in the middle of it all, the dog we'd had since I was a baby was put down. I felt like I had nothing and no one to turn to.

name: Al
lastTime: Constantly for the past 14 years
lonelinessMeans: Being married to someone and realizing that you don't love the person they have become but you feel obligated to stay.
mostLonely: I think everyone thinks they can save someone. That is the trap I fell into. My wife came from an abusive family and she wanted nothing more than to escape and I became her knight in shining armour who would whisk her away. Even during the early years of our marriage her libido was low, at least that is what I thought. I have come to realize that the truth is she despises being touched and avoids any physical contact when possible. I think the true depth of my loneliness became obvious after our son was born 15 years ago. A few months after he was born I was trying to get romantic with my wife who had been totally unresponsive since the pregnancy and I remember clearly what she said "now that I have my son, I never have to have sex with you." I grew up in a cold German family and all I ever wanted was someone who would touch me and hold me, and now 27 years after saying "I do", I am even lonelier than I was growing up.
firstTime: When my wife got pregnant and did not tell me for four months

name: Annelore
mostLonely:
Today I sorted through yet another box of my husband Roy’s life. The cardboard box contained an assortment of documents, a few photographs, the receipt of the purchase of his first new car, a collection of cards from birthdays past, university and high school diplomas, expired drivers licenses, receipts of car insurance payments, and a few other markers of his life before me.

I had always believed I knew everything about Roy’s life while growing up. Now I find empty spaces and surprises to fill them. Roy had once taken me to his University campus in Alberta, Canada, I had attended several of his High school reunions, listened to many stories from his adolescent years, met old friends and buddies from his Military years and yet here are new facts and new faces to complete the picture.

I found two High school diplomas: one issued in Roy’s hometown, from Fergus County High School in the year 1954 and another one dated in1955 from Canada. Perhaps the diploma issued in Canada was a requirement for admission to the University of Alberta? I also learned that Roy served in the National Guard in Montana and yet he was drafted into the Army. I find it interesting that the VW beetle he purchased from the factory in Germany cost him 5,500 DM, which at that time was equal to 1,375 U$...and while I turn these documentations around in my hands, I felt a growing need to share my emotions with Roy. I wanted to dive into memories with him and also relive the ones we did share, sit in that seafoam green Volkswagen and explore Europe and the US together one more time, the beginning of our relationship becoming fresh and new again.

As many memories flooded my mind and the realization that we never again would share these memories became reality, I was surprised that my sadness focused on him, on Roy. In those early years, it was him who created them. While I rejoice with happy memories he no longer can. It is up to me to nurture and keep them alive.

There he is, sitting across the table from me. The expression on his face tells me that he has noticed the tears rolling across my cheeks. He looks puzzled and uncomfortable. In these long years of the advancement of dementia, his life disappeared with the slow loss of memory – he lost his wife, his children, and finally himself. How can anyone cope with such tragedy? The process of experiencing fear, denial, anger and shame must finally give in to total darkness. He and I shared these stages differently, but together. In the end I am the keeper of these memories.

name: Kim
lastTime: 1am this morning
lonelinessMeans: Being alienated by people you thought you could trust.
mostLonely: A few years ago, I got laid off and my car was totaled in the same weekend. I couldn‘t find work anywhere and I had no savings, so I started walking and taking the bus anywhere I needed to go. As money got tighter I started selling my clothes, books, and furniture...but it wasn‘t enough. I lost 30 pounds because I couldn‘t afford groceries. I got fired from a contract job after two weeks when my boss saw me walking to work. Finally, I started missing rent payments. I had to do the thing I dreaded: Get the courage to ask my mom if I could borrow money. She blew up at me. She wrote me an email telling me that the only thing I cared about was money, I was always an ungrateful brat, and I didn‘t deserve anything from her. No one has ever understood what it was like to grow up with a mother like that, and I still feel incredibly lonely that I can‘t talk to anyone about it.
firstTime: When I was 6 or 7 my best friend told me she didn't want to play with me, so she ran off to play with all of our other friends and I was left by myself on the playground.

name: Violet
lastTime: Right now.
lonelinessMeans: There’s a lot to be derived from the word itself. I’ve often thought of loneliness as both social rejection and failure to integrate into the mainstream with my peers. After years of agoraphobia and handpicked loneliness, I can admit that there is also healing to be found in it as well. I’ve been lucky to flesh out the personality and core of who I am, but I’d be lying if I said it didn’t often hurt. Humans aren’t meant to go this long without another person nearby. My youth is gone and I know nobody. I have no memories, no pictures. No sweetness of another to remember.
mostLonely: Here. Now. As I write this, and the day before. The day after I submit this. I’ve lost my way in the forest and if I could do it by myself, I’d be out by now. There is no significant story attached. I stayed inside and kept myself away from everybody out of a shame that was self-given but never deserved. There is so much in my life to be picked up and put back together. There is so much I’ve given up under the false pretense that I deserved nothing. I am slowly working my way into allowing myself the sweetness of vulnerability, but until I reach that... I’ll always be a strange alien girl whose only company is a fluffy little cat (and even he prefers to hide under the bed alone).
firstTime: I was 16 and freshly departed from my previous friends and school. Shrouded with anxiety and a panic disorder, 16 became 18. 21. Every passing birthday was a sign of the loneliness, and then every morning was deeply reminiscent of how truly alone (more than ever!) I was. There doesn’t seem to be any way to escape it some days. I carry it with me always.

name: Barbara
lastTime: Today I guess
lonelinessMeans: Feeling like no one can actually be there for you even though you're surrounded by a lot of people
mostLonely: This is kind of recent. My grandma passed away in January of this year and she used to be one of the closest people to me, so, ever since she died I just can‘t shake off this feeling of being alone. She used to be my neighbour so we saw each other almost everyday because she needed help with a lot of things in her house and at night we even watched soap operas together, so we always kept each other company. I‘m not saying I loved every single minute I‘ve spent there, because sometimes she was very easily annoyed and I am a crazy mess, but it was nice and now it just seems like a part of me was ripped and I‘m all alone again.
firstTime: My family has this thing where we always compete to be the first person to wish happy birthday to each other, but there was this time when I was a kid that my parents and sister went out so no one was at home to wish me a happy birthday and everyone else just kind of forgot to call

name: Jessica
lonelinessMeans: Being the outsider and not knowing where you truly belong or are truly wanted.
mostLonely: I feel lonely every time a go to work. I have been in this position for five years and have a large amount of knowledge in this area of medicine. There is a clique within the group that for lack of better terms are the “mean girls” - they do whatever possible to damage the person that is a “threat”. I am a threat because I am well liked by other staff and the management - because I do my job well, and I do extra where and when it is needed. This makes the clique look bad, because they do the bare minimum. Being the target of the “mean girls” means you are left out of dinners, parties, breakfast plans, lunch, camping trips, etc. I get to hear them talk all about if after the fact (telling me “you were working”) or hear them try to quietly make plans. I have been left to complete a large wound dressing change in the operating room, only to be asked the next day “Where did you go? We assumed you left early” (knowing full well I had the late case). While this shouldn’t bother me, it does horribly. It has made me realize how alone I am and how I have focused on medicine and being good at what I do – which should be a good thing, but they have made sure to let me know it isn’t in their eyes and that I am not wanted. This feeds the anxiety and fear that since I don’t belong with professional peers, that maybe I am truly not good enough outside of work for anyone else. It is crippling to be worn down to this – and to realize I am truly alone.
firstTime: When a group of co-workers all got together for a holiday party and didn’t bother to let me know about it.

name: Allison
lonelinessMeans: Spending days on end without having contact with anyone. Feeling that everyone's life goes on without even a thought of you.
mostLonely: After 32 years my husband left our marriage. We were living out of state and I decided to move back to the area where I grew up and raised our two children. I was looking forward to reconnecting with old friends and family but I had been away for awhile. I realized you really can‘t go home. No one seems to have the time or desire to reconnect with me even though friends and family all say the love me and are so happy to have me back in the area. My children live out of state and both have very successful careers and significant others. In the past two weeks I haven‘t had any contact with anyone except for my daughter texting me here and there. I mean I go shopping, to the gym and run errands but that‘s about it. I am having trouble finding a job. I was a stay at home mom devoting all my time and energy in making a good home for my family. I never thought that this would be my life at 60.

name: H
lonelinessMeans: Isolation. Not belonging. Not experiencing intimacy. Forgetting how to connect.
firstTime:
Very recently.

I've always been single. For years I've told myself and those around me that it's because I value my freedom, my independence, my self-reliance. Gradually over the years I've created distance in my friendships too, for the same reasons.

A few weeks ago, I had a one night stand. It was the first time I'd let someone touch me in a very long time. And that one unplanned and casual act has awakened a craving for intimacy in me that I realise I've been suppressing since my teens. I don't want to be on my own, but I'm terrified of being unwanted, rejected, of not being good enough, of being hurt - by lovers or friends.

The realisation that I'm lonely - and have been for years without ever admitting it to myself - was sudden, and crushing. It is a loneliness so acute that I can physically feel it; fluttering in my stomach, restlessness, panic. But it's of my own doing, and it's been my reality for so long now that I don't know how to undo it.

name: Elana
lonelinessMeans: Not belonging anywhere really and knowing full well that nobody cares that this is your reality.
mostLonely: Moving out on my own in my first apartment a couple of months ago. Drinking and smoking are the only things that make me feel better about myself. Nobody will ever know how lonely I am. Being a young professional, with a degree and a career, a new fancy car, a closet full of fancy clothes, knowing full well that I am good-looking and smart, yet all these outwards signs of success don‘t mean a thing when you have no one to share them with. Feeling that emptiness inside on a daily basis and knowing full well that we are at an age when people have their circle already and wondering if I will ever feel the opposite of loneliness.
firstTime: In elementary school, getting that pang in my stomach when it was time for recess and I would not have anybody to play with, yet looking around and seeing how everyone had someone to spend their free time with.

name: Soraya
lastTime: Today. I got a 64% on a math test a few weeks ago and I've been holding off on telling my parents for weeks now because I know they'll just be disappointed in me. I told my mom a few days ago but I lied and told her that I got a 74%. She told my father and as he was leaving for work today, he asked why I got a 74%. I lied again and told him that it was because I made several small errors. My father then proceeded to point out all my flaws before leaving for work. He compared me to my older brother who's in his final year at a prestigious university four hours away. He told me how much my brother did in high school and how he still barely made it into the university. He told me I'd never get into any university, much less get a masters degree in architecture. My father has never told me that he's proud of me; not when I got a 100% on a trigonometry quiz a week ago, or when I skipped Math 9 and went directly to Pre-Calculus 10 last year. He doesn't see how much I'm struggling in Calculus 11 now.
lonelinessMeans: Not being able to tell people who you regard as "close" to you anything that's bothering you because you know they'll scoff. Having those people not regard you as someone close to them in reciprocation. Crying in the bathroom because you're too afraid to be vulnerable and cry in front of others.
mostLonely: I feel so silly even writing these words out. One of the times I felt the most lonely was last year, one of my best friends had just been broken up with, and I was writing positive things about her in a list to make her feel better. I wanted her to read it so she‘d know how amazing she is. She was hanging out with another one of her friends, so I was tagging along, a foot or two behind them. They were talking and laughing and I felt like my list was so unnecessary and I felt dumb. She finally read the list and she hugged me and told me how much she appreciated me and how good of a friend I was before going back to her conversation. That night I texted her and told her how I felt left out and how sometimes I felt like I was a liability without directly telling mentioning it was because of her other friends. After sending it, I immediately started regretting it because I sounded so clingy, like I was saying that my best friend wasn‘t allowed to have other friends. I realized that I always end up clinging when I find someone that even remotely likes me and I end up driving them away. It‘s a defense mechanism for me growing up, no one gave me the validation I crave now.
firstTime: I can't recall it because I have too many memories similar to this. I think I was maybe 8 when it happened the first time. My parents were comparing me to my older brother and I realized that there was no one in my life I could talk to, and there was no one in my life to support me and validate me. I felt so awful that I needed validation from other people because I felt like I was just seeking for attention.

name: Antigone
mostLonely: As a caregiver for many years to my ageing mother, who has multiple mental and physical health problems, I am confronted with both her loneliness and my own. Her inability to function on her own and her loss of her essence and personality have resulted in her not having any friends who truly know her and appreciate her for the fun-loving and sweet person she is. Everyone just perceives her as "crazy" or "needy". As for me, I miss my mom and get angry at her for her helplessness. I have no siblings or partner to share the work and emotional strain with. Friends are casually supportive, but mostly I am isolated and exhausted by the effort of just keeping her afloat. Institutional care and social programs are sorely lacking, especially if you are not wealthy. I am now losing touch with joy and my personality too.

name: April
lonelinessMeans: It is part of the human experience, yet it can be so challenging to not have friends or family to rely on. Some of this is by choice, yet I am single, I have no siblings, and no children of my own, not even a pet, and most of my family lives in another country, therefore I will always face loneliness more often than the average.
mostLonely: So many examples, yet one that stands out is wanting a divorce from my marriage. I had only been married for a few years and my family and friends turned away from me. I felt defeated and I had nobody close in my life to talk to about my feelings and what I was going through; I felt so lonely. Luckily, I learned that by trusting my instincts it helped me discover more about my needs and wants in my life. Regardless, loneliness is something that doesn‘t seem to go away.

name: Hannah
lastTime:
I spent money on a plane ticket to California for my “Best Friend’s” wedding. I travelled all day— a 4 hour bus ride, a 3 hour wait, a 2 hour flight— only to be picked up at the airport by her teenage sister and spend the rest of the day with my friend’s family. Apparently my friend and her other bridesmaids went to Tijuana, Mexico for the day for her bachelorette party. I only found out because I saw her post it on her Snapchat story. I wasn’t invited. They all stayed at an AirBnB together the entire weekend. I stayed with her family because I wasn’t invited. I didn’t even see my friend until the night before the wedding even though I was there 2 days early.

It was my best friend’s wedding and I wasn’t included in any of the fun stuff. I spent $450 just to smile for some pictures.
lonelinessMeans: Being excluded and forgotten. Always being the person someone thinks of last minute or not at all. Feeling unwanted. Realizing that no one would feel differently than they do now if you weren’t there.
mostLonely:
My junior year of high school. I was going through an eating disorder and an abusive relationship, but I couldn’t tell anyone close to me for fear of getting in trouble.

I remember sitting in my Algebra 2/Trigonometry class (I was failing), right after my teacher looked me in the eyes and asked me if I needed help, if I was okay. I sat in my seat and felt the world come crashing down. I didn’t think there was another human being on the planet who would be able to help me or understand. I felt like I was going to feel like that forever.

I remember feeling like everyone around me knew exactly what they were doing. No one else had a hard time understanding the lessons or falling asleep at night. I couldn’t even cry I just felt so empty and alone.
firstTime:
The first time I remember being lonely is the first night I ever spent alone in a house. It was the first time I ever had a panic attack.

I’ve shared a bedroom with at least one person since I was born. I have 2 sisters i always shared a room with. There were points in our childhood when we even shared a bed together. When I left home for college, I had roommates and bunk beds. From there, I got married and now share a bed with my husband.

Having spent my entire life sleeping next to someone, I never realized how much I depended on the comfort of another person being near as I slept. It wasn’t until I was alone in the dark that I realized how lonely I was.

name: Darren
lastTime: My company staff party. All around there were people I sort of knew, but very few I was all that close to. I had some meaningful conversations with a few co-workers, but then the DJ turned up the music to try to encourage people to dance, and making conversation of any kind took just too much effort. I slipped out without saying goodbye to anyone, expecting nobody would notice.
lonelinessMeans: That something is missing from your life. But I think there will always be something missing, as the "goalposts" keep shifting. One can be just as lonely (if not lonelier) in a relationship, or even in a large family, than when single.
mostLonely: Hands down Pride weekend. Pride is billed as the time when you can get together with your "chosen family" and celebrate however you identify as a member of the LGBTQ+ community. However, from my first Pride as a recently out-to-myself-and-close family 22-year-old, I‘ve just felt very isolated. Everyone seemed to be in a group of friends, or holding hands with their special someone. I felt invisible and unwanted. Since then, I‘ve become more involved with some parts of the gay community, so at least I have things to do and people to talk to during the celebrations. However, it still feels like I‘m totally alone as I walk through the streets of the festival.

name: Sensitive Idiot
lastTime: Now. Five minutes ago. Last week. Three months ago. Eight years ago.
lonelinessMeans: Becoming a secondary character in your own life, putting others first but not even being a priority for them, feeling like you’re watching the lives of those you care about through a glass window.
firstTime: When I wanted a book to swallow me whole and let me live inside it.

name: DawnAndDusk
lastTime: Right now. Last night. Yesterday. I used to have a partner, and two wonderful dogs, and local friends. Now I live alone, pet free, and an hour from my social networks. My place teeters between feeling like a home and merely a house.
lonelinessMeans:
Being afraid that I'm not a priority for people, that I'm not thought of when I'm not around. That maybe, if the darkest corners of my own fear are true and real, that people don't truly "see" me.

Maybe loneliness is the fear that the pain of being alone just might be permanent and forever.
mostLonely: I was sitting with my friends and looked around. All of them paired up in couples, with pets at their feet, children...I never felt quite so alone, so othered, so different and isolated, as I did in that moment while surrounded by loved ones.

name: Anonymous
lastTime: Everyday is pretty much the same. No phone calls, no visits, no conversations, unless you consider the few moments each day that my family is on their phone or laptop and they will occasionally look up to see where the voice is coming from.
lonelinessMeans: Being forgotten, treated as an outcast, being laughed at by those who have claim to be your friend. Instead of showing love or compassion, you receive judgement and criticism. No validation of your feelings, however; you are expected to show compassion whenever they are going through a difficult time.
mostLonely: When I was 36, I was singing in front of a crowd of about 100 people. I suffered a stroke. Cue the laughter and the jokes! When my wife got me to the hospital, the doctors thought I had a mental breakdown. Several months later, I was given the news: A rare progressive neurological condition that would shorten my life considerably. To make matters worse, the same condition that my abusive Father died of. The first five years of marriage, my wife and I took care of my parents. Knowing the outcome of my diagnosis has been terrifying! I discovered very quickly that I am in this alone. No one wants to be bothered with someone who is no longer healthy. Social media was my one shot to reconnect with people who I thought might want to rekindle a friendship. I was sadly mistaken. Most just want to know if you became successful, or if you turned out to be a loser. I’m an incredibly strong man. I’ve had to be. I went from being an extremely happy, overly energetic person, to a shell of my former self. What hurts is that no one has even noticed. When tragedy strikes, throngs of people hit the airwaves to offer kindness to total strangers. I could use some that myself! I can deal with being alone. I’ve had no choice. It’s the loneliness that eats at you; knowing that no one cares any longer.
firstTime: When I was a very small child, I knew that no one wanted me. As I grew, I was taught how to take care of a household and became responsible for taking care of the adults, while being used as a punching bag. My Mother showed me what love looked like, so fortunately, I grew up to be a kind and loving man, only to become comic relief for those claiming to care about me.

name: Robin
lastTime: Today. Most days lately.
lonelinessMeans: Loneliness is different from solitude. There is a solace in solitude, a balm for life's excess, a peace. Solitude is a thing with an end, a rest. Loneliness, on the other hand, feels like a vast, bleak emptiness without an end. It is a sense that no one really sees me, that I don't really matter, that I am unconnected, not understood, unknown.
mostLonely: The past two years since my marriage ended have been hell and heartbreak. I really want to be happy and try to stay hopeful but its hard.
firstTime: I've been lonely since I was very little. Maybe because I was sexually abused, other kids shied away from me. Maybe they sensed the blackness on my soul. I was intellectually gifted and precocious in a broken, dysfunctional family, so they often made me feel like an outsider. My father has no interest in me or my life, and my mom, who is autistic, doesn't really know how to connect with me, or people in general. They favour my brother, so that makes me feel even worse. Maybe this makes me keep myself apart from others.

name: Shannon
lastTime: Today
lonelinessMeans: An emptiness, a void. When you’re surrounded by others, but feel like you’re alone in a room.
mostLonely: My mom died a month ago, and I feel as if the whole world has continued moving but I’m still stuck in that hospital room with her. It’s a devastating loneliness to watch life happen around you and you’re not able to take part.
firstTime: When I was younger, and being bullied. I didn’t know what was happening or how to talk about it. I felt like I had only myself to turn to.

name: Lindsey
lonelinessMeans: Not having any meaningful connections with anybody close to you.
mostLonely: It’s my first year of college. Everybody says that it’s supposed to be the best time of your life. I don’t see how. I had amazing friends at home, and a boyfriend, and I am super close with my mom. I was excited to make new friends here, though. But the people I hang out with I don’t consider my friends. I don’t have any connections with any of them, and I can’t seem to feel that connection with anybody. I feel like there’s something wrong with me. Everybody else here seems to be doing just fine, my hometown friends are excelling in their social lives, the people I’ve been hanging out with all seem to feel that connection with each other. I’m the odd one out. I spend my time studying and alone, as I’d rather spend my time alone than with people I can’t seem to click with. Not a day goes by that I don’t feel lonely.

name: Christen
mostLonely: The loneliest time in my life was the summer of 1981. It was the summer Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer got married; I was 13 years old. My parents had moved my older brother and me from Toronto to the Cobourg area (about an hour east of Toronto) a couple years before because they decided to pursue their dream of being small business owners and an opportunity in Cobourg presented itself that they couldn’t resist. When we first moved to Cobourg my parents rented houses and in the summer of 1981 we were house sitting for the summer in a rural area just north of Cobourg called Baltimore. My parents were often gone to work before I woke up and didn’t return home before I was already in bed for the night. My brother was old enough to help out with the family business so he was often gone with my parents but there was no place for me at the family business so I was by myself in this strange house for the entire summer. Too young to drive, too far out to walk or ride my bike to visit any friends so I was just stuck there. In the middle of nowhere with nothing to do, no computers or internet or social media back then, we didn’t have any family pets and the lone black and white TV only got three channels. The radio was my only company during those lonely months and I would spend my days singing along and dancing around the house to the songs on the radio. Although I loved the songs at the time (“The Friends of Mr. Cairo” by Jon Anderson of YES and “Gemini Dreams” by The Moody Blues, for example) when I hear those songs now they bring me right back to that lonely summer as a kid and make me incredibly sad. I often change the radio station or just turn it off.

name: Quinn
lastTime: Today
lonelinessMeans: Not knowing who you have until they’re gone
mostLonely: My mom was recently diagnosed with a very aggressive form of cancer. She’s had surgery and is hopefully now cancer free. But mine and my family’s lives have been consumed by it. I barely saw my parents for a month while my mom was in the hospital. We didn’t want to risk me bringing in a cold or something because it could’ve killed her with her demolished immune system. That being said, I’ve been looking forward to Halloween all year. My dad and I always go all out with the decorations. And even set up a haunted house for little kids. But this year my dad is too busy helping my mom. Normally my friends would come and help in this situation, but they are all much too busy with their lives at the moment. Right now is the longest I’ve gone without seeing them since we met in high school. So I’ve been trying to decorate on my own. Today I cried while holding a skeleton, I feel like I’ve had to grow up in the past two months. I didn’t realize I wasn’t ready to do so...
firstTime: When my parents chose to stay at my brothers hockey game instead of coming home to take me to the doctor due to an emergency.

name: Z
lastTime: Not having a person with whom to share things.
lonelinessMeans: A few weeks ago, most recently.
mostLonely:
As I sit here writing this, I realize that although I have a girlfriend and a really cool mom, I don’t have anyone I can talk to really. Over the past several months, I have been getting sexually harassed at work by a guy who will turn on a dime and start threatening my job if he ever got the sense that I wasn’t interested in him. As a gay woman, he is far from my type, but I felt like in order to maintain the peace I had to just accept it. I finally went to my manager and told her that was going on and while she was very apologetic, stood by while HR did nothing. He was told not to do it again. I was told to keep it together.

Around the same time, I started back to school to work on my doctorate. Going back to school for another degree is difficult enough without dealing with some creep asking to see me naked or trying to find out where I live. I tried to talk to my girlfriend and she told me that I basically needed to not stress about it. Over the course of the past several weeks, things have gotten progressively worse, with an increase in migraines and a vandalized car being the least of my problems. I had to make the decision to drop out of school because of failing grades and all I wanted to do was talk to my girlfriend about it. But I can’t. Because she tells me that I’m too negative and I’m afraid that she’ll leave me if I keep talking to her about the things that are on my mind. I’m surrounded by people but have no one that will give me a second to cry or grieve or whatever I need to do to get through this.

name: Ebs
lastTime: Today.
lonelinessMeans: Having no family, no one to share my day with, my life with.
mostLonely: I left the home, I left her, rented a room. Spent my weekends driving around or listening to the radio in a parking lot in my car, without a home, without a family. Looking back I‘m amazed I survived it. Although my life if much better now, I look forward to meeting someone again and maybe have a family.
firstTime: I was married to a women with a narcissistic personality disorder, while married I felt lonely. I could never tell her my fears, my joys, my ups and downs. When all honest conversations is used against you as a weapon you stop communicating to the one you love.

name: Charlotte
lastTime: This week. I've been struggling with depression for a while and my rocky relationship with my mum is making it worse. This week, I wanted support from a friend to either distract me from my thoughts, or help me through them but I don't have anyone in my life to do that. Realising that I have no support network has made me feel incredibly lonely.
lonelinessMeans: Feeling lost. When I feel lonely, I don't feel like I have someone, or something, to turn to. There is no compass or centre I can refer to.
mostLonely: Right now. Right now is when I have felt most lonely. I have come home to see my mum for Mother‘s Day, thinking it would be nice given that we have a rocky relationship at the moment. She is showing signs of depression and I have begged and pleaded with her to see someone. Knowing first hand what depression does to someone, I‘ve tried to be there to support her. But I‘ve had so much resistance and no support. When it gets real hard for me, I don‘t have anyone to turn to. I've pushed my friends away, I am an only child, and our extended family aren't close. I feel like I am lost with compass or support to guide me. I feel so lonely and isolated, and it's breaking me apart.
firstTime: At school when I was asked to choose a partner for a project and I couldn't pick because I didn't have any friends. Up until that point, I hadn't really felt lonely. But having it highlighted that way, and in front of a classroom full of kids, has always stuck with me.

name: Forever Alone
lastTime: This minute, yesterday, last year, a decade ago...a lifetime.
lonelinessMeans: Not having anyone in my life who has my back, not having anyone for me to be able to lean on and not feel like a burden, not having anyone to talk with, being abandoned.
mostLonely: When I realized that the man I was married to was really an alcoholic and he didn‘t want to put his family/children‘s needs above his compulsive drinking, when he told me that he didn't want another child when I was seven months pregnant with my second child, when I realized he was taking money to support his drinking and I was the parent that had to keep telling our kids that we just can't afford whatever it was that they wanted at that time in their lives. I feel the most alone when I realize I was never truly and completely loved and I will never be loved and cherished.
firstTime: When I told my dad I was feeling scared, depressed and wanting to harm myself. He wasn't equipped to deal with my struggles (I don't think he ever wanted to be a father) and told me not to 'be stupid' and to 'get back to work'.

name: Holly
lastTime: Last week.
lonelinessMeans: A sadness you can't shift and a hole in your life.
mostLonely: Loneliness is something I live with most of the time; I only have my partner and dogs for company, so when he goes away on business, which is often, I spend days without speaking or seeing anyone. I long for friendship but I struggle with social anxiety. We moved to a new area a year ago and we don‘t know anyone. At first I tried to join new things so I could meet people, but I started to have panic attacks beforehand and eventually gave up. I find it too stressful to meet people, even people I know, who aren‘t close family or my partner - I worry about being judged and I over analyse every social interaction - its maddening and in some ways being lonely is preferable to the stress. I know I need professional help to overcome this, but that in itself would trigger my social anxiety - so it‘s a hard cycle to escape from.
firstTime: When I developed social anxiety as I entered Secondary School. I used to skip school and spend time alone, unable to socialise but also wanting to.

name: Naomie
lonelinessMeans: That I am at the point where a lack of fear or sadness is what I consider happy. It's feeling like a sand castle built too close to the shore, or the feeling that you're an intruder on your own life. Loneliness is this feeling of screaming but no sound is coming out. Nobody can hear you. Or maybe nobody cares enough to listen.
mostLonely: Freshman year of high school (a common trope, I know). For weeks at the beginning of the year I would spend my lunches crying in the back bathroom stall, and panic attacks became my only companion. I would try to gag myself so I could go home "sick" and cry myself to sleep. It doesn‘t help that I‘m gay and I have nobody to confide in. I‘m bursting at the seams. I feel like such a freak, and on top of that, being friendless doesn‘t help either. I'm scared to come out because I don't want to be known as the lesbian in an all girls school I guess. You start to feel like there must be something wrong with you. It can't truly be possible to be this lonely if I was a person worth being around. I don't think I've ever felt so alone.

name: Jeff
lastTime: Currently lonely
lonelinessMeans: Feeling out of place in the world, kind of lost in time and space, like life is moving on and you can never catch up.
mostLonely: My significant other has a big family. A few years ago I was with her at a family event, in a room with probably 30 other people, and I realized I hadn’t spoken a word to anyone in over an hour. I started having a panic attack so I went for a walk to calm down. I just intended to go around the block but wound up walking for close to an hour. I finally came back and no one realized I was gone. I was a background player and no one saw that I left. Pretty sure I could have kept going and never come back, and it would have been no big deal.
firstTime: I had an abusive addict father. My mom and I moved around a lot as a kid trying to avoid him. We got kicked out of homes, spent time in shelters. It was hard to make friends. I always felt like an outsider. Even with my mom I felt like a burden, like things would be easier if I wasn’t around. I remember being in a women’s and children’s shelter with my mom and knowing this wasn’t how life was supposed to be lived. When we finally settled on our own I never made friends in the neighborhood. It was like they knew.

name: Melanie
lastTime: Not having a significant other.
mostLonely: I separated from my partner a couple of years ago. In my determination to get out into the world in those first few months of singledom I decided to go to a theatre production that I really wanted to see but had no one to go with. I told myself that didn‘t matter, proceeded to buy my ticket and travelled to the theatre. Settled into my seat which turned out to be sandwiched between two couples. The production began and although the performances were excellent, I couldn‘t help but feel self conscious when laughing alone at a funny part, with no one to share the reaction with. I ended up leaving at the intermission, rationalizing that I would beat the crowds on the train home. I haven‘t been to the theatre since.
firstTime: When, in my twenties I told my friends and co-workers that I had a long distance fiancé just to avoid having to explain why I was alone all the time at parties and movies...I regret that now but at the time it helped me feel less alone.

name: Layla
lastTime: Sitting on my doorstep with a hot tea, hearing the noises of the party up the street that I wasn't invited to.
lonelinessMeans: Having no one who would smile when you walk into a room.
mostLonely: I feel lonely all the time. Floating in the universe with no one who really gets what I‘m about. I don‘t even get what I‘m about. I know I have time to figure it out, but time either goes too slow or too fast.

name: Karimov
lastTime: Every single day
lonelinessMeans: No hope, no fun, no friends, no interests
mostLonely: I live in Busan and my life is going to be bored and not natural. People are different culture is unknown. I study here but can not learn anything. I want to make new friends but they can not speak in English, Russian, Uzbek or Turkish. I know I will adopt to Korea and I hope it will not take much time.
