firstTime: When I came to Korea

name: Lisa
lastTime: Constantly, since retirement.
lonelinessMeans: Not having anyone in your life who would put you first, even when life is really difficult for you.
mostLonely: I went from being a well-paid teacher to someone who is trying to exist on the breadline. A year after breaking my leg, my pay reduced to 50% and eventually stopped, so I made the decision to take early retirement which meant living on a very small private pension. At least this gave me an income. The State pension wouldn‘t be available for another 6 years. I thought I could manage with savings. What I hadn‘t considered was how isolated I would become. Everyone important to me were a lot wealthier than I am, enjoying social lives I could no longer afford. I spiralled into a deep depression and didn‘t know how to ask for help. I had spent my life putting others first. Even in depression, I put on an act so not to place my burden onto others. I started to withdraw from social contact, it was easier to stay at home where I could be ‘safe'. Also, a lot of the people around me were of the 'get a grip ' response to mental illness. I felt inadequate enough, I didn't need friends telling me to get a grip. Gradually, I've built up a life with volunteering, looking after my grandchildren, joining groups which cost very little, but, I still feel lonely for that one person who would provide companionship in old age. I feel very vulnerable for the first time in my life!
firstTime: When I broke my leg. To begin with, friends and family visited regularly. I live on my own, so people brought food and it was lovely to be fussed over. However, I suffered a non-union and my leg took over 2 years to mend. So much of that time was spent alone at home, it gave me a glimpse of what it would be like to be housebound in old age. I have a daughter who did what she could, but she's a nurse and did very long hours at the hospital.

name: F
lastTime: This afternoon.
lonelinessMeans:
Loneliness means being the only individual in the photo smiling, but literally falling apart on the inside. I'm a gay man in a generally homophobic country where statements like "gays are worse than dogs and pigs" are thrown around, and people clap wildly at such statements. The dating scene in such a scenario is obviously toxic, leading me to question why I bother.

I graduated a year ago, and had to leave the supportive network of other gay men and women that I'd built over a five year period to return to my small town where Grindr is not only ineffective, but generally a bad idea. So, the adjustment has been rocky, to say the least.
mostLonely: My first week from college. I didn‘t know anyone around, and hence couldn‘t leave the house to have fun somewhere else. I‘m a bit of an introvert, so making friends has always been difficult. Added to the fact that I‘m generally terrified of being outed to a homophobic neighbourhood, it felt especially harder to make new friends. But, we survive. I'm talking to a few people now, and am generally trying to live each day as it comes.
firstTime: When I was in seventh grade and realised I was gay – no one else was attracted to people of the same sex, and the first person I talked to about this, my class teacher, looked at me with this repulsion I have not gotten over.

name: Withheld
lastTime: It's been a while, but going to a party always makes me feel isolated and alone, like there's some grand social meaning that I just can't quite get. There's a world out there, and I can see it, but I can never really be a part of it.
lonelinessMeans:
I'm going to be weird here. Loneliness means peace to me. Being alone, isolated, means that I have to rely on myself, I can look inward and view a situation through my own set of filters, rather than trying to see through someone else's point of view. It's peaceful and can be kind of calming just to float in my own consciousness, listen to my own thoughts without the intrusion of other ideas.

I have a great connection with my partner, and that relationship keeps me from feeling lonely most of the time, but I eagerly look forward to times when my partner is gone for a few days, and I can be totally alone, just turn off social media, turn off the outside world, and be totally, 100% me.
mostLonely: New Year‘s Eve from age 16-25.
firstTime: Going to karate class when I was a young child. It felt like everyone else knew how to navigate through the community centre but me, knew things like where to put their shoes, or where to get changed, little things like that; like they all knew what they were doing, and I didn't, and never would.

name: Julia
lastTime: Right now.
lonelinessMeans: Being surrounded by people who love and cherish you and yet feeling nothing but emptiness.
mostLonely: During hospital stays for my anorexia nervosa. Surrounded by so many lovely people who are just as stuck and alone in their own minds as I am.

name: Ryan
lastTime: Two weeks ago when I won a major competition in my profession I was so exhausted I couldn't feel joy anymore. I worked like crazy and didn't respect my boundaries. The price I pay for disrespecting myself is usually loneliness and depression. When I become exhausted I don't have the energy to have an inner conversation with me and I lose contact to the inner and outer world and I feel like astronaut on another planet.
lonelinessMeans: Being disconnected with my inner self. In my experience loneliness has nothing to do with being with friends or the amount of people around you. Rather it has to do with the acceptance of my inner shortcomings. I've made peace with myself and my decisions and I rarely feel loneliness anymore (except when I push myself too far like stated above).
mostLonely: The most lonely moment of my life was when I was standing naked in the shower with my girlfriend and she yelled at me that she would like to punch my fucking face. My girlfriend was raped as a teenager and she couldn‘t cope with men. She loved me but she detested me at the same time. I was standing there naked in the shower, warm water ran over me while being yelled at with threats and all I wanted was to give her a hug and comfort her.
firstTime: When I was a child. My brother and I shared a room. He was always easily asleep. The TV was creating some noise in the other room. Some chatter from my mother on the other side of the wall. A car driving by outside… all seemed so very far away yet it was just a few meters. I prayed to god every night the he sped up time so the morning would come sooner and everything would become alive again. But he never heard me.

name: Charlie
lastTime: In my second year of university, last year.
lonelinessMeans: I was never without friends, but they had other friendship groups to hang out with, whereas, I only had the one group of friends. We also all had clashing schedules, which really didn't help.
mostLonely: I lived with people who were only interested in staying indoors. My uni friends just never invited me to do anything with them. I ended up going on a trip to another town and going ice skating alone. I‘m glad I did because that‘s the most fun I had at that time. I‘m still friends with my uni friends, but I‘m now living with new people. The people I live with now actually have an interest in joining me on my adventures. It's much better now.
firstTime: It took a year before I realised I was lonely after I had been out of the situation I was in for a few months.

name: Susan
lastTime: The day my father didn’t want me to visit him.
lonelinessMeans: To quote another contributor, “Loneliness isn’t being alone; it’s being around people with whom you cannot be yourself.“
mostLonely: We moved from the UK to New Zealand when I was a kid in the 60s, there was a lot of anti-English sentiment back then, I was called “pommy Sue”. My parents were very busy establishing a new life and I wasn’t accepted by the kids at school, I had to get myself ready for school alone and I would come home to an empty house. I wasn’t allowed a pet so I trapped a bird in the garden and kept it in a shed, ostensibly to look after it, after a couple of days it died of fright and I felt incredibly guilty.
firstTime: At age 7, getting ready for school my parents had already left for work and I couldn’t figure out what to wear.

name: Enn
lastTime: 2 weeks ago
lonelinessMeans: The desire to have a social aspect to my life.
mostLonely: The whole of 2016 I spent alone; I was single after a heavy breakup, I saw my friends maybe only once every two months and I loved it! I had the most productive year towards my music and art, learned and understood new aspects of myself and indulged in pleasures I had been wanting to fer years. It was truly a valuable time in that I learnt that loneliness wasn‘t completely a bad thing, and now I truly treasure the times I have to myself. It‘s made a stronger, more understanding person with greater relationships than I could have ever fathomed. I truly relish those times.
firstTime: Back when I was 10 years old, and realised that my perception ostracized me from others.

name: Barbara-Anne
lastTime: A few minutes before I came across this site. I had been watching neighborhood children playing hockey in the street. At first I felt a sense of joy to see children actually outside playing together. Then the nostalgia; I remember as a child doing such things, being part of something. I was not sure exactly what it was, but it was something and it felt good. A kind of "tidings of joy" state. And then I had this suffocating sense of loneliness as I walked into my house, alone, realizing that none of them probably cared whether I saw them or not, let alone what I was thinking. They probably get together for dinner, I thought.
lonelinessMeans: Not mattering.
mostLonely: My mother and grandmother lived together for over 3 decades. I would help them out - all the time - meals, errands, visits. I loved it. My mother died in 2013 - medical error. My grandmother died 6 months later at 96. They gave me a sense of purpose - I loved them so much. I mattered to them. The loss was unimaginable and I never really talked about it with anyone, because it was so big...deep...a piece of me went with them. How do you explain that to someone else? How is such pain conveyed? I dreaded the thought of sharing it with someone only to have them respond with something like...Well one time I had this terrible loss and it was so sad and xyz - at which point I would stop listening and feel worse and wonder how it could be that we humans had come to be such poor communicators. To be heard; to matter - how do we get that back as a species?
firstTime: About two decades ago when a relationship ended. 1995. I was never able go get back on track. Loneliness has been my orbit ever since, though occasionally I do feel the love of the planet and that sense of belonging; and it is awesome.

name: Ruth
lastTime: Christmas – well, all holidays, really. When they come along, I feel so vulnerable. No family, old friends gone now, son follows his wife's lead and she does not like me. I will not be a victim, but still...
lonelinessMeans: Abandonment. As though I am not worthy.
mostLonely: When I was nine, my tonsils were removed, though I wasn‘t told it would happen. In 1957, anesthetic for children was imprecise, and I awakened flat on my back on the operating room table. Held down. When home, I couldn‘t manage to speak, was severely claustrophobic and nothing seemed real.
firstTime: At about two years old when my brother came along. He was literally the fair-haired boy. What's a girl? Not anything, you see.

name: Anahita
lastTime: A few days ago.
lonelinessMeans: Being forsaken, needing someone and being unsurprised when nobody is there.
mostLonely:
My very first party was freshman year, the day before my 15th birthday. It was a really nice party, actually, with fairy lights and nice people from other schools and a lot of dark beer. And vodka — which I had a preference for. One of my friends felt depressed and I didn‘t want to leave her alone, but I also wanted to keep drinking, so I grabbed a bottle of rose vodka. I guess I felt like that night was supposed to be a rite of passage or something. We walked to this peach tree orchard at the center of our town, only a few blocks away, but by then I was drunk out of my mind. I couldn‘t even walk, I kept stumbling into fire hydrants. The last thing I remember from that night was shrieking, “I love you!” to her half-sickened-half-concerned face.

I woke up the next morning at like 3 am and it was horrible, the worst I‘ve ever felt in my whole life. All my friends and a few strangers were sleeping in the next room over and I was in some guy‘s shirt because my friend didn‘t have any clothes that fit me. And it was my birthday. I stumbled over to her couch and sat on it and the world was just so quiet. Suddenly, I was 15 years old and hungover and everything hurt because I was scraped-up. There were thorns in my feet because I‘d walked barefoot places. I‘ve never felt so alone in my life. I wanted to be held so badly. For someone to tell me that it was okay, to stop crying, even wish me a happy birthday. I felt so small and afraid. I put my hands between my thighs and just kept looking at my toes and how chipped up my coral nail polish was even though I‘d got them done with my mom the day before. I remember all of this viscerally. The morning stars, the silent TV, and me.

Nobody comforted me when they woke up finally, obviously, besides a few comments about how scared people got when my pulse began to stutter. I don‘t think they knew it was my birthday either, so I got no birthday wishes. But that didn't hurt so much. What hurt was when my mom picked me up. My mom‘s very principled about these things. I think she could tell what happened the moment I got into the car because I reeked of vodka. She didn‘t speak to me at all for the entire day. She‘s usually the one who buys cake and stuff, who gets really happy about birthdays. She canceled the big dinner we were supposed to have that night with all our family friends without telling me. That was the first time we didn‘t really celebrate. My dad didn't say anything to me either. It was like I was blanked out for that whole day. No one could even look at me. That was the loneliest I've ever felt — when I everyone I loved made me feel like I didn‘t exist, made me feel like I was repulsive and not worth anything. It was my fault and I probably deserved it, but it still made me feel so awful and alone. That no one would forgive me or at least held me with such unconditional positive regard that they could look past this mistake for one day, that day, my birthday — it hurt so much. Anyways, I still can‘t eat anything that tastes of rosewater.
firstTime: When I was 5 years old. My parents are immigrants who moved to America from India. My dad's a software engineer and my mom used to be one, until she moved into something related to business, which she‘s way better at. When I was younger, they were still getting themselves figured out. They got married pretty young — it was a love marriage, not arranged — and moved here shortly after, so they were wrapped up in their own lives even though I existed. They couldn't pick me up after school, so I got shoved into a day-care every day. Pick up time was always at 6 o’clock. They were always late. It was okay, usually. They’d give me extra snickerdoodles. One day, we went up to wait in the front office. The person I was with was getting antsy, because it was nearing seven. I think he had a date. Anyways, he gave me a slice of cake, because it had been their boss’s birthday, and let me play one of those old card games with red kings and queens and jokers on the spare computer. I don't really know how to explain it. I wasn't lonely because anything big had happened. Honestly, it felt like any other weekday. I think it's because I finally realized that I was unwanted. I felt unloved, even though rationally, I knew I wasn't. Still, that’s stayed with me and all those nights of being alone has made me carry some resentment towards my parents, even though it’s really not their fault.

name: Annelore
lastTime: Yesterday
lonelinessMeans: Temporary need to share time with a loved one.
mostLonely: The first time his symptoms were bad enough to keep us housebound for several days.
firstTime: When my husband showed the first signs of dementia.

name: Kevin
lastTime: This morning.
lonelinessMeans:
Loneliness is an aching in my heart, I call it the lump. The lump is there when I wake up and there when I lay in bed trying to sleep.

It is a sense of hopelessness and feeling disconnected. Of knowing I am a good man, that I have so much love and affection to offer someone, but not having anyone to share that with.

Loneliness is fear, it is fear of the future and of never meeting that special person. It is being a gay man that doesn't fit into the gay world or the straight world. It is not being able to meet anyone I can feel that deep and loving connection with.

It is being stood in a club with all my friends and looking around trying to see if there is anyone else there who might be gay, who might be looking at me and realising I have no idea and no way of knowing, and in that moment feeling so alone and so hopeless.
mostLonely:
I feel lonely most nights when I am in bed. When all I want is to cuddle someone and feel loved and to feel seen and held. It is hard to explain. But I am not into the gay scene and I don‘t identify with that scene at all. But this means I rarely ever meet other likeminded gay men. I am not obviously gay to other people, who always assume I am straight. It means I am left to use apps like Grindr. Grindr is a place where loneliness is abundant. Where people seek a quick fix to there current feeling of isolation and loneliness.

It makes me so fearful for my future. How will I ever meet someone, how will I ever find love, that deep meaningful connection, where that one special person sees you in your entirety, the good and the bad and accepts it wholeheartedly and loves me for who I am. That person who is there to dream my dreams with me and hold me when they don‘t work out. That person who will be there as my health fails, that person who will walk the dark paths with me as well as the light ones.

I have so much to offer and sometimes I feel like a balloon filling up to the point I will burst.

To me, living in a world that places people on boxes, straight, gay or whatever, makes me feel like I don‘t belong and I will not ever meet the man who could walk alongside me in life. To me loneliness is a poverty of opportunity to meet that someone. It is looking around at all my friends and seeing them dating and falling in love and feeling left behind.
firstTime:
When I was 14 and I realised I was gay and that no one else knew this or could know this about me.

Laying there in my bed, crying and desperately wishing I was "normal" like my friends. Begging to just like girls like everyone else. Being frightened and feeling deeply unseen.

name: Ellie
lastTime: Now
lonelinessMeans: Feeling isolated from the people around you, and the people you love, no matter what situation you are in.
mostLonely: I felt the most lonely a few months ago, when I found out my partner had been seeing other people. Suddenly I couldn‘t trust him any more, and I realised that by focusing on our relationship I had isolated myself from the few friends i‘d had. He on the other hand, had an ever growing network of friends, that I of course was not welcome to be a part of. I‘d been so content on being the perfect girl for him, that he would always want to be with, that I didn't even realise he was taking advantage of my kindheartedness, as well as gas-lighting and subtly controlling me. I'm still in that relationship, because I have nowhere else to go, and don't have the mental or financial capability to be on my own.
firstTime: I was about 8 years old. i'm an only child, and my parents fought for the majority of my childhood, up until their divorce when i was 14. I remember sitting in my room, listening to the screaming, and realising I had nobody to talk to about how it made me feel. I often wished that I didn't exist, so they didn't feel forced to stay together.

name: Tess
lastTime: Today, when I registered for my freshman year of high school. I stood in line nervously, the sun beating down on me and my dad watching me from a nearby bench with a concerned expression on his face. I was surrounded by my peers – kids I’ve known since I was 9 – and I was silent in the midst of their excited chatter, my eyes darting from one smiling girl in a trendy outfit to another. The loneliness was suffocating. I hoped so terribly that someone would say a simple hello to me; not one person approached me, save for someone I have not considered a friend since fourth grade, who looked at me with condescending pity in her eyes as she made polite conversation with my dad (he had asked her how her summer went, obviously trying to get me to follow his cues and “get out there”). If I had not needed my textbooks and ID photo, I would have begged to be driven home after five minutes of feeling like an outsider.
lonelinessMeans: Feeling like everyone who cares about you is so, so far away. Feeling like there’s a part of you that’s broken, that what’s supposed to connect with other people is defective. Feeling like it’s hopeless to remember your friends when they’re never close enough because they’re all across the world. Feeling like everything that makes you yourself is what makes you an outsider. True loneliness is when you can’t bring yourself to be optimistic anymore because nobody really cares about you enough to just be there.
mostLonely: When I went through 3rd grade being bullied, picked on, and excluded. Then I moved. 4th grade would be so much better, I thought – but by the end of it, I only had one friend. By the end of 5th grade, she had betrayed me and left me lonely yet again. In 6th grade, I finally found a friend group. In 7th grade, all but two of my friends left me because I was annoying and also a lesbian – and in the second half of the year, those two decided to ditch me for a month just to see what happened. In 8th grade, my remaining two friends ditched me for good. Now I’m starting 9th grade and I have no one. I’m done being optimistic. I’m done telling myself this year will be better than the last. I’ve given up. I think this is the loneliest I’ve ever felt.
firstTime: One week ago, when I got back home from camp. I spent three weeks at arts camp pursuing my love for classical singing. For three weeks, for the first time in years, I did not feel lonely. People there wanted to be my friends. People there understood what it’s like to have a passion and to be ostracized because of it. People there didn’t already know me as the weird kid who talks too loud. Now I’m home, and that’s all gone. Only now do I realize how lonely my life really is.

name: Penelope
lastTime: Every day for many weeks.
lonelinessMeans: My local friends have all moved away or died. Except for taking my dog to the woods or the beach I'm always home alone. I used to be very sociable, hosting regular dinner parties and visiting with friends. Now I have no one in my life and feel completely isolated and very lonely. I find company in books.
mostLonely: My sister-in-law, who had lived with me for years, and knows me well moved out recently and now I have no one to talk to. But the worst was when my adult sons grew up and left home because I loved cooking for my family. Now it‘s a struggle to feed myself. One son lives hours away and the other is busy with two jobs and two kids.
firstTime: When I had no no one to talk and laugh with.

name: Luke
mostLonely: I was on a vacation with friends in Europe and planned to spend my last week solo, mulling around and just enjoying the last of my vacation before starting a new job. In reality I spent 2 days walking around a city pretending to be just another tourist while internally I was more lost than ever before. On the third day I purchased a one-way ticket home (a week ahead of my original flight home) and spent 24 hours travelling embarrassed and anxious because I didn‘t know how I was going to explain my change in plans. To this day I have never told another person the real reason I came home early, that I couldn‘t handle the crushing reality of how alone I felt. Instead I lied and told everyone I was always the plan to finish my vacation at home.
firstTime: I was 6, my family had just moved into a new neighbourhood. I was standing in my driveway watching a few kids play road hockey and asked if I could join. I can vividly recall how the rejection felt when they said no. I continued to stand in the driveway, while tears were streaming down my face, as I watched them return to their game.

name: K
mostLonely:
One evening I was stood up by my boyfriend and he didn‘t reply to my phone calls or my messages and my kids were with their father and I came home to an empty house and sat on the steps and realized the depth of the void inside me. I think I sat with my mouth gaping, incredulous at the profundity of my loneliness. It shattered the image I have of myself as independent emotionally and self-sufficient generally. It made me realize that I attempt to fill the hole with lovers but that I need to learn to fill it with self-love.

Which sounds so cheesy, I know, and ultimately if we‘re social creatures we can‘t simply rely on ourselves for overcoming feelings of loneliness, no?

I thought I would have figured this all out by 50!

name: Anonymous
lastTime: Christmas
mostLonely: I’ve been in a loving lesbian relationship for over a year but haven’t come out to my parents. So i’m having to spend Christmas this year away from her and her children, who are my world, to spend it with my family. It is so lonely to have this whole other amazing world that I can’t even talk about because of my parents close mindedness. I feel like I have to hide away all the best parts of my life and pretend to be an entirely different person. On a holiday that is supposed to be spent with loved ones and showing how much you care about them, i’m spending it with people who don’t even really know me. I’m a stranger in a room full of people i’ve known my entire life.

name: Anonymous
lonelinessMeans: It feels like invisible walls surround you and prevent you from reaching out. Nobody can come in, and you can’t get out.
mostLonely: I was at church. There are plenty of people who are my age, and after over a year of attending, I have not felt welcomed by them. No one spoke to me. I held back tears during service.

name: Caroline
lastTime: Today. I’m always lonely. I feel disconnected from most people.
lonelinessMeans: Being surrounded by human beings who are so clearly full of life but feeling dead to all of them.
mostLonely: I had been with my former husband 7 years and 5 months, married for 9 of those months, when he told me, over Google chat, that he didn’t love me anymore. We got into a fight before he went back to Afghanistan to finish his 4th tour of duty. The worst part is he had to leave. We had no time to really feel resolved, but never in my wildest dreams did I think he would just quit. No one saw it coming. And there was just no arguing with "I don’t love you anymore." I later learned he remarried, to a soldier he was deployed with that year. I may never know for sure if I was cheated on, but it took me over a year to even consider dating again.
firstTime: When I was 16. We found out my father had cancer. He is my anchor, my rock, my hero. The very idea of him dying killed a part of me that I haven’t been able to revive, even though my father recovered. I should be grateful, but instead I still feel a nagging emptiness nearly 20 years later.

name: Sarah
lonelinessMeans: Feeling ashamed of my aloneness. Feeling like I've done something wrong, and am being punished, and set apart from the rest of humanity.
mostLonely:
I‘m single. Have no children even though I always wanted to be a mother. But I didn‘t feel I could do it alone. And I never found the right partner. Getting up in the morning and facing the day, and facing people – all married or divorced with children, or planning for a life like that. Knowing that I don't fit in. It takes courage every day to go to my job and out into the world, as myself – a single, childless woman. I'm lucky enough to have finally found a job that I love, and my coworkers are very kind. I don't think they judge me. But on weekends and vacations I feel lost, weighed down by the stretches of unaccounted for time. When I go back to work after a weekend, I almost feel like I'm recovering from an illness – slow and disorganized. Then the cycle starts all over again the following weekend.

I hate holidays. I hate being a tag-along to someone else's celebration, hate being invited places out of pity, and also suffer when I spend a holiday by myself. Even when I'm with my family, I'm the odd one out. Watching way too much Netflix and Hulu over here in this particular apartment.
firstTime: I remember hiding behind a screen in my preschool class, looking at the other children and teachers, feeling like an alien species, with no way to connect to them.

name: Julia
lastTime: 2pm today. Nothing I did could stop my little one from wailing. My husband has a job that demands most of his time and a lot of his emotional energy. He comes home and he checks out. I feel trapped. I wish I could take the baby and go live with someone who would try to get to know him and help when I'm depleted. Or, I wish I was single. At least then I would feel free to ask for help. I don't want people knowing how empty my marriage has become since the baby arrived.
lonelinessMeans: Being unknown and unheard.
mostLonely: When I found out I was pregnant I was so happy, but as my pregnancy progressed I realized, no one else is going to defend and fight for my child, no one else is going to take an interest in all his little milestones, no one else will be there through the monotony of the day. I never understood that motherhood could be so lonely until my second trimester.

name: Noelle
lastTime: Today
lonelinessMeans: When you feel absolutely singular with no possible escape. There is you and only you.
mostLonely: This year in general. I’ve felt a lot better than I have in passed years but sometimes I still feel a recurring feeling of isolation. I have friends but in an age of rising technology there seems to be a big disconnect from reality sometimes. I feel like my relationships have gotten significantly worse as technology continues to progress. There’s never any time to have conversations anymore. Everyone always has something to do or somewhere to be and I am here watching it through a tiny screen. Loneliness is a persistent feeling that resonates throughout the whole body and sometimes it feels like there is no way to stop it from consuming you.
firstTime: I was in elementary school. I just wanted to talk to someone about my day. Then, I realized that I had no one or it seemingly felt that way. I was severely bullied in elementary school and I stopped talking to everyone including my mother for a while. I felt like frankly no one cared. I felt as though no one understood the depth of my feelings and it’s also when I figured out that sadness could be endless.

name: Dale
lastTime:
My husband of 36 years died 18 months ago. We had no children and I have a very small family – 2 brothers who live in different cities and only 1 nephew who is single and has his own personal issues.My husband was a single child.

I have no close friends who are single and couples just don't think about inviting me along when they go out.

I am retired and live on my savings. I would like to travel on group vacations but don't have unlimited funds to do so. I involve myself in volunteer work and belong to a couple of clubs but I spend much of my life by myself. I miss having a close relationship with someone to share thoughts and feelings and events. I get so lonely and bored. The idea that this is my world going forward is very frightening.

name: Marina
lastTime: Every night.
lonelinessMeans: Watching everyone moving forward and enjoying life while I’m stuck.
mostLonely: Hearing love songs. I physically can’t have sex so I can’t even do something as small as relating to a song. If I can’t have sex then I can’t have a boyfriend let alone a family. I wish I could see into my future and know if things will get better.
firstTime: When I realized this isn’t a phase and I think this is how the rest of my life is going to be, I don’t know if it will get better for me and I worry about how my life is going to turn out.

name: Kyla
lastTime: Two days ago
lonelinessMeans: An empty house, excluding the dogs.
mostLonely: I was recently separated from my child’s father. I had an empty house for the first time in over a year. It was the first time I was truly alone since the birth of my daughter.
firstTime: When I felt secluded in high school

name: Tammie
lastTime: Last night. I got in an argument with my close friend and he was right - I do get dramatic when I start feeling left behind.
lonelinessMeans: Lacking opportunity to connect with anyone even in the most casual of contexts. Feeling like an other; not fitting.
mostLonely: When I was in my third year of medical school. I had lived in that country for 4 yrs, I was 25 yrs old, I had never had a boyfriend, I wasn’t seeing anyone at that time. I had very rough days and I looked forward with desperation to Fridays. I would enjoy being on the crowded buses because of the human touch I would experience as others brushed by me. But when I got off the bus and climbed the steps to my room on hall, I realized I had nothing to do, no one to call and nothing I could have truly been looking forward to. I would cry myself to sleep each time and then repeat the whole thing again the following week.
firstTime: In elementary school, another girl I considered my close friend slammed my head into a wall in front of all my classmates. No one cared to even gasp or laugh. No one stopped her. They all looked and looked away, continuing what they were doing as though nothing had happened. She insisted that she was playing around.

name: Richard
lastTime: Arriving home from work yesterday to an empty condominium as I have every day for the past five-and-a-half years when my former spouse and I separated. I crave enjoying the presence of someone at home so strongly that I announced my arrival as if an imaginary person was actually there. That simple act was marginally fulfilling but ultimately short lived.
lonelinessMeans: I have learned that loneliness is not being alone but actually desiring more social interaction than what one is experiencing.
mostLonely: I once felt particularly lonely when I was home alone and thought about all the other people around the world that for a multitude of reasons felt similarly at that moment. I believe people around the world are fundamentally the same in that we just want to love and be loved. The recognition of the absence of love in my life that evening gave me a profound sense of loneliness.
firstTime: When my former spouse and I separated and I discovered that while my friends and family members would occasionally make time for me, they all have their own lives and priorities.

name: Michelle
lastTime: Today, when I realised my friends were hanging out without me again, and how completely separate I felt for them.
lonelinessMeans: It means being stuck in a storm of your own thoughts, and attempting to look through the cloud, only to see that everyone else can't see the storm, and pretending that it's all okay.
firstTime: I realised that there is no one I trust completely. I've struggled with mental health problems since as far as I can remember, and I'm going to a therapist and taking medication. Only my parents know. Even though they've been completely supportive and understanding, they don't actually know what it's like, and that frustrates me. Also, at school, one of my friends has this power over everyone else, and she puts me down a lot. I feel like I'm the only one that sees that she isn't all sunshine and rainbows.

name: Michelle
lastTime: Last night. After a nice day with my family and embracing their love and support, I went about my day home. It wasn't until I was getting ready for bed and a song I love that talks about painful love came on my playlist. I was reminded of my relationship that recently ended. It wasn't so much of his lack of absence was it more of the wasted potential of a relationship.
lonelinessMeans: The feeling of abandonment or unacknowledgement.
mostLonely: Most certainly after a serious break up. Sometimes there aren‘t perfect words to say or hear from the support of your family and friends. The best mechanism to this when I experience a romantic heartbreak is that I‘ve learned to depend on myself the most. Tons of self reflection and introspection helps me process my wounds and heal internally; which inevitably uplifts my external world as well.
firstTime: I think I would say I was a child and at a time my needs were unmet. I remember being reprimanded for my reaction and spending time in my room to think of my actions. Parents aren't perfect and unfortunately are not given a manual when we're born. I believe that isolation wasn't the perfect solution for me. And it in fact hindered my self competence and instead pushed me to seek validation and approval from others. This is something I would later heal and develop as I got older.

name: Amanda
lastTime: Today. I'm struggling with the fact my mum, who raised me as a single parent and has always been a huge part of my life, is slowly dying from ALS. She is the only person who has been a constant in my life up until now.  I'm a single mum and don't want to burden my teen daughters with my grief, because they need my support in what they are losing, because of their nana's illness. I've been without a significant other for 3 years and despite my efforts to find a suitable partner, I've failed to find an honest, caring man. Having no significant other to just hug, on days when I feel so sad, is crushing. Having to do it all by yourself, is sometimes so overwhelming.
lonelinessMeans: Having no one who knows you fully and completely.
mostLonely: The night I walked out of the hospital alone, after hearing mum‘s diagnosis. I barely made it to my car, before I completely broke down. I sat there alone in the freezing cold and cried, until I had no tears left.
firstTime: About 10 years ago, when I looked across the dinner table and my then partner, who could have cared less that I was even in the room. At that point, he wouldn't even ask about my day and when I asked about his, he'd barely share anything and say he didn't want to talk about work.

name: Stu
lastTime: When I see photos of me with members of a community band I play in and I realize I'm the oldest person there. They see a cheerful, energetic sax player, always at the center of things. In the photos I see a sad, old man pretending these young people are his friends because he doesn't have anybody else in his life.
lonelinessMeans: Loneliness is the price of solitude. I want my money back.
mostLonely: Last night I played with a new band with mostly young people. They were making plans to go to the pub. I went home, drank wine and wrote emails. Most of these emails are friendly and thoughtful, but I never send them. Last night I wrote to my daughter who rarely calls unless she needs money. She‘s dealing with some serious mental health problems and I‘m pretty sure she got them from me.
firstTime: In junior high, walking on a playing field at lunch hour and realizing everybody else was walking in pairs. I was the only one alone.

name: John
lastTime: September 6th, 2017. My birthday.
lonelinessMeans: Feeling like you don't belong. Feeling isolated.
mostLonely: When my father and I got into an argument and he told me I wasn‘t worth 10 bucks.
firstTime: One day, just out of the blue, my two best friends just stopped talking to me and started to avoid me, for no discernible reason. Whenever I tried to talk to me, they would just turn and walk away. I still don't understand why.

name: Michelle
lastTime: Right now
lonelinessMeans: Realizing that you no longer want to be alone, but being unable to change that.
mostLonely: My freshman year of college is the loneliest I have ever been. I was a poor hispanic girl from a small suburb at a school for wealthy white kids from big cities, and I felt incredibly isolated. The school was notorious for being painfully cold and unwelcoming, but I didn‘t care. I wanted to be a writer and at the time, it seemed like the only way. I didn‘t make many friends, I was too depressed to function, and the friendships that I had spent my whole life building back home were crumbling before my eyes. The least lonely I ever felt at that college was at group therapy. It was a rough year.
firstTime: In first grade. Our teacher had as all sit in a circle and talk about what we did during recess, and who we played with. I was the only one who played alone. I didn't mind much, but my teacher did, so she tried to force one of my classmates to play with me during recess. I was looking forward to have someone else to play with, but the next day, she was nowhere to be found. It turns out she had been hiding from me, because she absolutely refused to play with me. That's the first time that being alone really felt lonely.

name: Anonymous
lastTime: Being at the other side of the world with the man I loved, who was no longer in love with me
lonelinessMeans: Detachment from joy, connections being lost-mentally and physically.
mostLonely: The day before I left and flew thousands of miles back home. When everything had failed. I took a picture of you sleeping on that lazy boy chair you loved. You looked so peaceful. I knew that would be the last photo I’d ever take of you and all the years of memories came rushing back. It was that moment I knew that I was alone. I’d lost you and you’d lost me.
firstTime: Staring into my ex partners eyes, knowing I’d already lost him a long time ago.

name: Sarah
lastTime: Last night, shamefully after I had masturbated.
mostLonely:
I met him via an online game called Trivia Crack. It’s similar to Trivial Pursuit. He said “hello” and I said “good game, shall we play again?” We continued to challenge each other for a while before I asked him where he was from, “Washington, D.C.” he said. He asked me, “Australia” I replied. He became intrigued as he hadn’t spoken to an Australian before. We spoke every day thereafter, exchanging numbers and Instagram handles. Before I knew it, I was head-over-heels for a man who lived over 11,000 miles away.

I arrived in Washington, D.C. on the 31st of October 2016, 15 months after the first hello. I had just spent a month touring America, having met amazing people along the way and feeling accepted. The tour continued to New York however I departed and checked myself in at an AirBnB in Potomac, Maryland, recommended by the man of whom I had fallen for. No set plans had been made however he advised me that his mother was in hospital, he was stressed, it wasn’t good timing. I’d send a text message asking if he wanted to do this, wanted to do that though he never replied. I spent a lot of time in bed. I watched YouTube, which created an illusion of company. I dragged myself to Macy’s in the afternoon and browsed the department store alone, occasionally asking customer representatives where to locate an item, just to prove I wasn’t invisible, to feel alive for a moment. I took myself to the cinema and ate popcorn alone. I dined out alone. I drunk at a hotel bar alone.

Occasionally we’d speak on the phone and I begged him to meet me, excuses were given. Sometimes I was given false hope, so I’d make an appointment at a beauty counter and have my make-up professionally applied, only to fall asleep at an ungodly hour having wasted my evening waiting to hear from him. I felt so utterly alone. I realised how alone I was when I continued to make appointments to have my make-up professionally applied, the beauty technician was polite and we’d share a conversation, general chit chat. Sometimes this was the only interaction I experienced all day. I felt worthless. I felt as if I was not worth his time nor effort.

It was now the 18th of November 2016 and I spent the majority of my last day in a park watching squirrels and their behaviour. After a few final purchases and sights that had to be seen, the time had come to take myself to the airport. It was two hours before boarding and he had promised he would call so we could chat before I departed. One hour passed and I patiently waited, my anxiety level rose. I checked the time, thirty minutes until boarding and still nothing. I hid myself in a corner, called him and left a teary voice message. It was time to board and with wet eyes I showed my passport and ticket. As I was sitting down in my seat on the aeroplane, he rung. I sobbed, an air hostess asked if I was okay and I mouthed to her “saying goodbye”. She nodded and gave me a hot towel for my face, her kind gesture only caused me to sob more. The phone connection disintegrated and I was asked to switch off my mobile.

Sometimes I question my decisions, the actions directed by a heart worn on the sleeve.The choices made by an individual can brutally effect others, I don’t think I’ve ever felt more alone in my life. In October, it will be two years since I was stood up and to this day I still cry over how I was treated, the lack of respect, the lack of answers, the silence.

name: Anonymous
lastTime: Today, when I realized that the television series I'm watching on Netflix has become the only family love I really know, and that I never really learned to hug people like my television family – The Fosters – does. They hug and cry together and pat each other on the shoulder. They touch each other. No one touches me.
lonelinessMeans: A perpetual feeling of sitting next to a large hole in the couch. You know there should be something there, the something is necessary and obvious and unable to be ignored, but it's oddly an empty space.
mostLonely: When I crossed the finish line of my first marathon for my 26th birthday out of state, I realized that no one would be around to be proud of me. Other marathoners had family, spouses, or significant partners waiting and when I crossed it was silent. Many people had gone home because it was a small race and I‘m not a fast runner. I grabbed my medal and went to my hotel room, alone, as though my biggest athletic feat that I‘d trained for months and months to achieve...had never happened. I posted it on Facebook, but the "likes" will never be the real thing.

name: Lisa
lastTime: Today
lonelinessMeans: Not feeling part of the community even if you are within it. I am deaf and I work with all hearing people. No matter how much my boss knows about deafness, she still doesn't realize that I miss a lot and I feel invisible at work, that I'm not worth more than just saying hi to.
mostLonely: Always around the holidays. It always sucks as I don‘t have anyone to be with. I haven‘t had a romantic relationship in forever.
firstTime: Growing up in school with no social life.

name: Bookworm
lastTime: Every second of every day
lonelinessMeans: A variety of things, but my personal brand means I can be surrounded by people and still be isolated
mostLonely: My most lonely is currently. I‘ve always been a slightly sickly person, but the summer of 2016 it got ramped up to 11. I lost my job, I was vomiting blood, and a bunch of other gross stuff. I was weak, exhausted. I‘ve gotten my main diagnosis, but there is no cure, just gradual decline and decay. At Christmas this year, my favorite uncle (who only sees me once a year) uncomfortably said hello & then spent 5 hrs avoiding me with my other uncle. This man and I used to talk for hours because he genuinely enjoyed my views and opinions, and how he won‘t be in the same room as me. It made me step back and realize that all my friends have basically acted like Homer Simpson in the gif where he slowly steps back letting the shrubs engulf him. Even my ‘best friend' who used to be my patient advocate at times and check on me daily... I hadn't seen her in 4 months and the only time she talks to me is if she needs to vent because she knows I'm around. I'm lonely because an illness I didn't ask for, that is killing me, has left me homebound and uncomfortable to look at because it took too long for the doctors to catch it. Aside from when my boyfriend gets home from work, I spend my day entirely alone. And most of his time after work is running errands and cooking and picking up the slack so... still alone. Alone and a burden.
firstTime: The same time I realized I could only rely on myself. I was 8 or 9.

name: Anonymous
lastTime: Right now
lonelinessMeans: Feeling like a single balloon released into the sky, moving further and further away from love and connection and floating uncontrollably into a terrifyingly dark and unknown abyss.
mostLonely: Whenever I make a mistake. I feel unforgivable, as if any chance I stood of being loved fades to black.
firstTime: September 11th. All of New York was coming together and I couldn't find security in another human.

name: Ms. Lonely
lastTime: Today
lonelinessMeans: Being trapped in your own thoughts and feeling there is no way anyone could understand how empty you feel.
mostLonely: I felt the most lonely when I had my first panic attack due to my anxiety, but felt I had no one to tell about it. It was an absolutely terrifying experience. I didn’t know what was wrong with me. I was too scared to ask for help, and instead of reaching out to others I started to separate myself from every “friend” I had and my anxiety began to consume me.
firstTime: In college at UCSB when there was a school shooting. While I was not in the immediate proximity of the tragedy, it really hit me hard. I felt lonely in that I had no one to confide in or felt judged when I expressed how much the shooting affected me. For some it became a platform for people to push their political views (ie gun control). This bothered me because I wasn’t quite healed or ready to discuss the incident in that manner. I felt unsafe in a community I once felt like home. This immediately triggered the anxiety, loneliness, and PTSD I still battle today.

name: Khalil
lastTime: خلال هذا الشهر / During this month
mostLonely: بدأت بشرب الكحول لأول مرة في حياتي كسرت حواجز ديني ومجتمعي كان هذا مجنونا / I started drinking alcohol for the first time in my life. I broke religious and community barriers, that was crazy.
firstTime: امشي ليلا ولا استطيع النوم / I walk at night and I cannot sleep.

name: Jonathan
lonelinessMeans: Feeling unwanted
mostLonely: There comes a time when you’ve retired and your kids find excuses not to hang out with you. When I was their age there was an energy and vibrancy to everything. You wanted to fill every moment with friends and activities. I’d spend time with my parents regularly as a kind of obligation but not so much quality one on one time. Wouldn’t invest the kind of spontaneity I gave to my friends and peers. I suppose that’s the way of things. I never gave a second thought as to whether my busy schedule pained my parents the way it pains me now. I might have made more of an effort.

name: Robin
lastTime: Earlier today
lonelinessMeans: A feeling of not being seen or heard, that I am not loved or valued, that what I need isn't important. That I am unimportant. That I am a freak. The greatest antidote to my loneliness is when someone remembers something I said, or just calls or texts just to check in. Being alone and being lonely are not the same thing. I enjoy solitude - and I can be very lonesome in the company of others.
mostLonely: When my marriage ended and I was up at the cottage we rented every summer, and my daughter was away at camp. I was heartbroken and utterly alone. I journalled my days to survive it. Here is an actual excerpt: 7:10 trying to get out of bed. 7:20 am out of bed making coffee. 745 back in bed. 810 crying on floor in bathroom. 8:30 made myself go for a walk. Saw falcon. 10:00 how many hours until bedtime and this day is over?" Being alone at Christmas that year was a close second.
firstTime: When I was a little girl playing alone in the field at recess. I couldn't understand the other girls and I know they couldn't understand me. I had been marked by abuse so I knew I didn't belong. It's the earliest memory I have of self isolating. That is the behaviour I am trying hard now to unlearn.

name: K
lastTime: Today
lonelinessMeans: No one truly knowing the real you. A feeling where you feel like the only way you'll be accepted is to put on a persona
mostLonely: One of my first sleepovers in fourth grade. At that age a lot of kids are finding their sexual orientation and talking about crushes and such. As per usual truth or dare came about and the most asked truth- who do you have a crush on. If you answered no one you were pushed til you let out an answer, but for me the answer was genuinely no one. Honestly, I felt a deep sadness inside me, I had a feeling that I would forever be alone and never find myself. Instead of showing my true self, I decided to pick a random kid in our class and go on with life and girls thinking I liked this boy. I felt out of place, not accepted for myself. In around 7th grade, I found the terms asexual and aromantic. While it was reliving to find myself, I still have to put on a persona everytime that dreaded question comes up or whenever my aunts and uncles come over and ask when I‘ll have a boyfriend.

name: Kim
lastTime: Mostly I feel lonely when I’m out and I see couples together. I ponder as to how 2 human beings can be brought together to be able to spend so much time together and to fall in love - I spend a lot of time wondering whether I’ll be able to find someone who can love me for longer than a week.
lonelinessMeans: To feel abandoned and forgotten.
mostLonely: It was a Saturday night and I was in bed. I’d had a bad week, having it been really busy plus I’d Also messaged a guy I was interested in earlier in the week but there had been no response. Saturday nights, late in bed are the hardest. I was sad because he hadn’t replied and then I started to think of the fact that he was gone and that there was no one else and from there my thoughts spiralled out of control until I was crying and I felt like I couldn’t breathe. I sat up in bed, trying to catch my breath, tears streaming down my face until I finally relaxed. Since that night, I vowed to never get too disheartened about my singleness. To never get too attached to a person so that I didn’t have to feel this way again. This year has been a good year and most the time I’m okay, but when the loneliness sneaks in, it’s hard to shake. I’m still on a path to accept that maybe me being single is how it’s supposed to be right now and I think about it everyday, but I’m learning to sit with the loneliness and accept that it’s okay to be lonely, but really, you’re never alone.
firstTime: Most the time I’m happy spending time alone. I love my independence and I love my life. But then I think about the fact that I’m single and I have been for a long time. That I’ve gone on dates that have never become anything. That I’ve seen guys for a period of time but they’ve never fallen for me. Most times I love my life, until that thought creeps in that maybe I’ll Never find anyone. Maybe this is it for me. I’m fine until this thought pops up and it can completely cripple me.

name: Sarah
lastTime: Today, everyday
lonelinessMeans: Chaotic silence. Not feeling like you have someone to share with. Feeling like a disease that nobody wants to catch. A desire for human contact that isn’t there, because you might as well be on mars. Feeling like you don’t fit in, even with your own pack. I am a contractor for the OR (so while OR employees are my “coworkers”, they are really just people I work in the same building with) and I see this family dynamic all around me and I am still an outsider. I don’t feel like my OR staff are my friends, even though I spend 40+ hours a week with them. And it’s hard to discuss surgery with people who don’t work in that environment, so I can’t even tell my husband about my day because he just doesn’t get it.
mostLonely: Moving to Las Vegas with my husband (then boyfriend). He was offered a job and I had just graduated so I didn’t hesitate to come with him. I’d had surgery before the move so I would be unable to do anything for some time after. I decided to leave my cats and resolved to get them at a later time, and brought my ferret. We moved on a Saturday, and by Monday she was not doing well. She passed away later that night, after only 3 days, and I don’t think I ever felt so lonely in my life (it really was just a coincidence as she was older, but the timing couldn’t have been worse). My husband would be off at work all day, and I was stuck in a 1 bedroom apartment by myself all day until he came home. I sat alone all day with no one to talk to, nowhere to go, and I couldn’t even unpack any boxes because I’d just had surgery. Everyone I knew but my husband were all still back at home, across a state line in California. They were living their lives, going to work and socializing and hanging out with friends while I sat in my quiet apartment, lonely and feeling sorry for myself. The silence was deafening, and was the most honest and truthful thing I’ve ever heard. It has become easier to be alone, and in fact I sometimes prefer it. But sometimes the loneliness comes with it and it comes crashing down hard and even the radio or my favorite music does nothing. Even in a room full of people I know or are at least familiar with, I still feel lonely much of the time. I suppose it’s just part of my makeup now, imbued in my DNA
firstTime: When I was a child, still very young and in grade school. I have always been a little stranger than most my whole life, and definitely the black sheep of my family. I had a very small group of about 3 friends that I clung tightly to for most of my early years. There was a birthday party for a classmate - a Halloween party, and Halloween has always been my favorite holiday - and I was one of only a few kids in class not invited. My little group of friends was invited but I wasn’t (this was before the time when kids HAD to invite everyone in class to parties and give everyone a valentine, etc), and I spent that Saturday like any other. Doing my chores, weekend homework, that sort of stuff - all while remembering that the Halloween party was starting in 2 hours, starting in 1 hour, starting in 30 minutes - and wondering what kind of costumes kids would be wearing and what kinds of games everyone but me would be playing. I remember walking and playing with my dog for hours, just the two of us. And even though I had her company, I felt so lonely. Now I’m not even sure why, I guess as a child you want to be part of the group and you want to be included, and I wasn’t - on purpose - for whatever reason. Now ever since then, I feel most lonely without a dog because my best and healthiest relationships have always been with a canine. And I know my dog would invite me to a party.

name: Sarah
lonelinessMeans: Not connecting on a deeper, fundamental level with someone. Having to hold back who you truly are. To me that is when I’m at my most lonely. I am trapped alone in my head with my thoughts unable to share with anyone else.
mostLonely: The time I felt the most lonely was sitting in my living room with my husband and feeling completely and utterly alone. I felt like I did not have anyone who truly cared even though another body was sharing this space with me.

name: Anonymous
lastTime: Today
lonelinessMeans: Wanting to reach out but not having anyone to reach out to.
mostLonely: As a stay at home mom it comes with the territory. I know I chose this but I also didn’t really have the option to go back out into the world after. Every day being alone takes a toll on you mentally, you have your online mom groups but it’s just not the same.
firstTime: I’ve always felt lonely – but since becoming a mother at a younger age, losing the circle of friends I DID have because of it I’ve noticed it more. Especially in summer.

name: Susan
lastTime: Yesterday.
lonelinessMeans: Not having anyone to share successes and failures. Always feeling on the outside, never part of the group.
mostLonely:
I truly do not remember. Too many years without emotional support except for the professional kind.

Right now I am dealing with the recent death of my mom. I am really taking a closer look at grief and how it feels to me. I am trying to write it down. Grief is very lonely.
firstTime: When I felt if I died it would only be noticed when my body started to smell.

name: Richard
lonelinessMeans:
That there is something missing from my life that can only be filled by the presence of others and/or the belief that there are others who know me, care about me, and accept me exactly as I am.

It is a feeling that I will not be understood or accepted. That there is no one who will ever know me in such a way that I feel as if I belong somewhere.

I’m somewhat rather depressed at the time of writing this, which is definitely influencing my response.
mostLonely:
One of my oldest friends was sleeping with the person I was in love with behind my back and then didn’t have the guts to tell me, so I found out from my lover. The week my terminal project for grad school was due. Suffice it to say, it took me another year to graduate. It took months to recover from the feeling that I really couldn’t trust anyone; even my closest friends, and that people didn’t care about me enough to think about how their behavior might hurt me. I’m mostly better now. It’s been 11 years and my mind still brings it up as a reason not to trust that people will really be there for me when I need them. That I am alone in the world and always will be.

All that said, I am with a wonderful person who loves me dearly and we’re happily planning to spend the rest of our lives together. But the feeling of loneliness never goes away, and there is always a nagging thought in my mind that I will die alone and forgotten in the streets. (I know, rationally, that there are people in my life who would never let that happen, but that knowledge doesn’t make the feeling go away.)
firstTime: Preschool. I’ve always been different enough that making friends was very difficult growing up. Lots of empathy without understanding. The desire to connect on a level that most people feel uncomfortable with when first meeting someone, especially kids. Some of my earliest memories are of me being alone, and almost all of my memories include some feelings of loneliness.

name: Tara
lastTime: Two days ago. A friend came by, and as usual, I was supportive, inquisitive, interested and connected. As usual, it was all about the friend and the friend’s life and problems. I got cut off twice, and when I mentioned something painful from my own past from several years ago which I still grieve over, said friend stared at me blankly and had no clue about what I spoke, then changed the subject again.
lonelinessMeans: Being amongst people, but feeling like you don’t fit in...not knowing where to put yourself...wanting someone to really know you and live you anyway, but knowing that it’s not possible.
mostLonely: When my one true friend who knew my life inside out passed away. She was my safe place.
firstTime: A family fishing trip. I was about eight.

name: Petra
lastTime: I’m not sure.. always but also never.
lonelinessMeans: Missing people who I love.
mostLonely: Standing on the driveway the day one of my brothers moved to the US for university. My family is insanely close and still are, despite my parents being divorced. That said, when the person who I could relate to most in the world moved away I was terrified. I was so happy for him and his new chapter but felt insanely lonely. I was 23. My parents split at 22. We decided (my two brothers and I) that no matter what we’d always be there for each other. I am the oldest and was left in Toronto with the youngest. I didn’t know how to relate to him or open up to him because we (as a family) always protected him from the ugliness of reality. I think ultimately my loneliness came from guiltiness (I didn’t know how to relate to my youngest brother) and selfishness (I didn’t want to face my parents divorce alone).

name: Anonymous

lonelinessMeans: Not being able to call your mother.
mostLonely: Every single Mother’s Day since 2005.

Because I’m so young I don’t know many people who’s mom has passed away. I definitely don’t know anyone who has lost their mom that I’m close enough to call and talk about it with. name: Vanessa
mostLonely: I broke my ankle and didn’t see anyone besides my husband for weeks at a time. I could stave off the loneliness at my job but literally trapped in bed 24 hours a day was soul-crushing.

lonelinessMeans: Having people around who you feel you can’t relate to
mostLonely: I was sleeping alone in the guest bedroom of a friend’s house. I could hear her and her boyfriend laughing. I knew I was going to bed alone while they had each other. It made me feel so lonely.

name: Katrina
lastTime: Last week
lonelinessMeans: Feeling like you have nobody out there
mostLonely: By far, when I was sexually assaulted by a stranger in broad daylight in 2014. That was the first trauma i personally experienced and it was just after my first year of college. I was not sure of who I was at the time and was in a period where i was losing touch with high school friends and struggling to make friends in college in a program I did not enjoy very much. The people I was close to did not know how to help me through that experience, which made me feel lonelier than ever.

name: Anonymous
lastTime: Yesterday (I was at an airport).
lonelinessMeans: Feeling disconnected from people who make you feel loved and accepted.
mostLonely:
I developed an eating disorder at the age of 15. When I was 20, my parents found out about my problem and over the next year, I attended a drop-in group therapy program in order to appease them. I wasn’t ready to give up my coping mechanism or dig into my trauma at that time, so I basically just got better at hiding my eating disorder, which continued to control and haunt my daily life for many years to come.

At age 27, I was finally fed up of having my life controlled by food and exercise, and I started attending an intensive holistic therapy program at a well-respected center in Toronto. I saw a team of specialists 2-3 times a week over a period of 4 months, and eventually tapered my treatment to single weekly therapy sessions. I worked hard as hell to dig into the key causes of my eating disorder, including sexual trauma and an emotionally abusive upbringing, both which resulted in anxiety, substance abuse, and compulsive behaviour problems.

I am privileged and fortunate to have had access to the program that eventually allowed me to heal from my eating disorder, but it came with a huge price. That summer, as a student, I used a student line of credit and OSAP to pay for the $14,000 of treatment I received. None of it was covered by the government or my limited student healthcare benefits.

Despite an ongoing rocky and tumultuous relationship with my parents, I reached out to them for help paying for my treatment, but they said no. Since eating disorders are still so stigmatized, and because I’ve always prided myself on being independent, I was ashamed to reach out to anyone else for help. I still struggle to this day to make ends meet, but I’ve managed to get by, and now that I only have one more year of school left, there is light at the end of the tunnel. I know deep down that I’ll be okay and somehow find a way to make it through. I am resourceful as hell, and I’ll figure it out. But it really hurts that the people who should’ve been there for me more than anyone else in the world simply weren’t.

Thankfully, due to my therapy work, I now know that my parents’ lack of support isn’t a reflection of my worth, and is instead a result of their own personal trauma and hurt. I’ve built myself up in the ways that my parents never did, and put loving people around me who make me feel supported and seen and valued. Working through my eating issues gave me the foundation to be able to finally face my sexual trauma, which has allowed me to be able to reconnect fully with my body and learn to love and care for it.

I still get sad when I think about my relationship with my parents. I have effectively cut them off for the past 2 years, but for now I know it’s better than the alternative. I don’t think I could have done the healing over the last 2 years that I did if I was still in contact with them. By disconnecting from something destructive, I was finally able to start connecting with myself and my life.
firstTime: When my family moved from England back to Canada and I was in my first day of 4th grade and desperate to make friends. My best friend in England was a girl named Emily and I remember that on my first day of 4th grade there was a girl named Emily in my class so I immediately approached her and asked her to be my friend. She seemed a bit surprised, but agreed :).

name: Azoz
lastTime: Few days ago
lonelinessMeans: Being alone, friendless and not surrounded by anyone to love
mostLonely: I felt lonely when my father and brother has to leave the country and i stayed in Jordan with my mom, it was a week full of grief but I got over it with some friends.

name: Erin
lastTime: Today.
lonelinessMeans:
In my life’s experience, loneliness has always been most closely associated with standards and dreams. The more successful I am at pursuing goals related to career and life purpose, the more lonely I am. More lonely because I am more intimidating to potential friends and partners, more alien to family and friends back home, more tired and desirous of alone time, and more enmired in an environment where everyone is transient and intimacy is less common to begin with.

Loneliness is an inescapable and cyclical part of being human. We’re all interconnected and also unchangeably separate. Trying to run from feeling lonely only causes you more pain, I think, and I remind myself of this very often.
mostLonely: Moving abroad five years ago began the most lonely period of my life. I knew I had to pursue something that I couldn’t find at home, so I left behind friends and family to do it. I looked forward to meeting scads of new incredible people but that hasn’t panned out. It’s me, my work, and a seemingly endless chain of frustrated attempts to cultivate intimacy. Have I made the wrong decision? Should I go back home and have close friends, but no career or sense of purpose? I find that I can’t.
firstTime: I can remember feeling different, unknowable, and separate as a child but I always had close family members and at least one best friend. The first time I felt really adrift was in Peace Corps, surrounded by people who couldn’t understand my past history or cultural upbringing, but who understood my reality much more completely than anyone back home could possibly do. I realized that for the first time, there was no one anywhere on the planet who could possibly understand every facet of my life. That had never been true before.

name: Michaela
lastTime: A couple days ago
lonelinessMeans: Feeling as if no one is thinking of you, or that no one will support you when you need it.
mostLonely: The loneliest I’ve ever felt was when I realized that the love of my life didn’t want to spend time with me. To put that much power on another person, any person really, is a choice though. It’s as if I had this expectation that if another human being actively sought me out, I would feel validated as a person myself. I’ve since come to realize (or possible delude myself into thinking) that loneliness is simply a feeling of low self esteem. When I am with others that care to have conversations with me, I feel worthy. I’m currently working on my perspective of self worth.

name: Kay
lastTime: I don’t remember
lonelinessMeans: Feeling unhappy at being alone
mostLonely: The loneliest I’ve ever felt was when my marriage hit a very dark patch and I thought my husband and I were going to divorce.
firstTime: I’ve rarely felt lonely in my life. I like solitude, almost always.

name: Gabrielle
lastTime: I’m abroad, living away from my family. It was thanksgiving back home recently, and my uncle texted me and asked if I was coming over for our Sunday dinner (that I usually avoided each year, actually). I was sitting on my bed, staring at the message and realising that no one in this country cared what holiday it was back in my hometown.
lonelinessMeans: I think humans aren’t equipped for loneliness, so any time any of us realises the sheer amount of people in the world and how little they actually might matter in the grand scheme of things – well I think that’s why we do a lot of what we do. So to me, loneliness is the root of all of our creation and art.
mostLonely: I threw a going away party – a huge, crazy fun one, and only 6 or 7 people showed up of the 40+ I had invited. And that’s when I realised I had spent so much time chasing quantity in friends after all of those years alone that I had somehow ended up lonelier than before.
firstTime: My mom was a single mom, and we moved around a lot. I always read, but I think I didn’t have a single ’realisation’ of loneliness – that was just my constant state of being. It’s hard to keep friends when you’re at each school for a few months.

name: Ree
lastTime: A few hours ago
lonelinessMeans: Being surrounded by so many people, yet not having anyone to talk to
mostLonely: I’m sitting with some of my friends and that day everyone is talking about the latest gossip of a girl getting together with a boy. I tried to ask a question about them, as I really didn’t know what was going on. Everyone laughs and is like “oh it’s nothing.” They go back to talking and a couple minutes later, a girl says "Why are you so smart Ree. You can’t hang with us if you are. To bad you have no idea what’s going on. Clearly you aren’t as smart as everyone says”. That was like a punch in the stomach. I’ve always been the ‘smart kid‘, but I didn’t realize it had put me so far apart. Now, no matter who I try to talk to, I know that there’ll always be that loneliness in me, because I had yet to find another soul who understood me.
firstTime: When everyone around me was engaged in some sort of conversation. Every time I tried to join in, the conversation would immediately shut down and the response would be that it was nothing.

name: Mya
lastTime: Today
lonelinessMeans: Not being with the person who was/is your soulmate.
mostLonely: It was when my ex married someone after only six months of knowing her. Before that I was with him for 10 years, even had a child together. It makes me feel so alone, and often makes me wonder if he truly did love me. It’s been 3 years since our separation, and even though things got bad at the end of our relationship, I know I still love him. What tore me up was they just recently got a cat that resembles the one he inherited from his deceased uncle, and became my cat so to speak. He was my therapy cat, and is no longer alive. My ex for some reason today told me the cat that him and his wife got is the ghost of our other one. Sounds stupid, but it tore me up inside. He knew how much I loved that cat, and just picturing them picking out a family pet together makes me feel so alone that I no longer am a part of his life. Also, not even sure wtf his intention was telling me that.
firstTime: When my ex got married.

name: Vanessa
lastTime: This afternoon when I sat in detention for being late two days in a row, and despite being surrounded by students, I couldn’t help but think, "I don’t belong here." They were all delinquents. They talked back, cheated on tests, copied homework. I was just tardy. I was alone, but the room was full.
lonelinessMeans: Being seen, but not perceived.
mostLonely: Sorry, this is long. To me, loneliness is when you are surrounded by people and they see you and you see them, but no one really ponders each other’s presence. People see you as just some colored blur in the background that they’ll never have a want or need to interact with. To them, you’re just another prop. This also tends to be vice-versa. This realization hit me kinda hard, that every stranger you see is just another person you pass by in the daily stream of people, and chances are you’ll never see them again. You’ll never learn what their name is, what their favorite color is, what foods they enjoy etc. And that’s exactly what you are to them as well. Every person you walk past or glance at has a life that is just as, if not more, complex than your own. I was 9 when I noticed this and it freaks me out to this day. I remember sitting in those little chairs and staring at the teachers and suddenly wanting to know more about his wife and his son. I wanted to know the hobbies and interests of the kids in the class across the hall. I stared at everyone with eyes the size of dinner plates. Third grade was crazy, man.
firstTime: When I was nine years old, and the thought just struck me like a ton of bricks.

name: Chris
lastTime: A couple of months ago. It was the perfect weekend to go out with friends, but none were available.
lonelinessMeans: Being surrounded by people, but not knowing if you can trust them with your life
mostLonely: I’ve felt lonely many times, mostly because I never felt like I belong here. Having Asperger’s doesn’t help either, and I only knew I had it a couple of years ago. Until college I was never invited to parties or any other social meetings. Once I tried to get together with old high-school "friends" only to realize that I had virtually none, as only one of them showed up with her (now ex-) husband. Later I learnt that the other people I invited were actually at another meeting. A much more popular person had a birthday party which of course I was never invited to.
firstTime: When I finished middle school and realized that in all those years I was only invited to a single birthday party, and mostly to be laughed at.

name: Hyun Min
lastTime: Maybe last month
lonelinessMeans: A space that I can normally breathe, live and think about my existence. This is the time that I charge my mind and find God in this crowded world. On the other side I also feel the loneliness like a helpless condition if I need someone to talk to but can’t find it.
mostLonely: This is another circumstance, this is my hometown when I get back, meet people and they never ask about me, but for my sister to me.
firstTime: In my boarding home in Jakarta, I don’t fit with this big city, I always dream about living in a calm small city in Indonesia. But because of my work I can’t make it better for now.

name: Brynn
lonelinessMeans: Privacy and self-containment
mostLonely: Every day I go down to the cafeteria at work and find it difficult to locate an empty table to eat at by myself.
