At times I would just cry and there was nobody i could really talk to because my parents never would spend most of the times home, they always had to work and i had to take care of my brother who was born with cerebral palsy and he was 6 at that time. I guess i had to grow up faster than my actual age because I had to take care of another child.
lonelinessMeans: It means being so sad that you feel really empty, and not having somebody who wants to know why you are alone and quiet.
mostLonely: At the beginning of high school I had friends and by the end I had none. The people I thought were my friends did not turn out to be my friends and I spent most of my days being verbally abused by some of them. I felt really powerless and I pretended to not care but it really got the best of me. At home there were things going on with my family and since the ones I thought I could open up to betrayed me I became more and more enclosed. I still find it really hard to share anything with anyone, I am really afraid.
firstTime: When I was 18, I was going through a bad relationship and the pain was so unbearable, I felt lost and useless. I honestly wanted to die. One night i was alone in my room and I felt like i should end my own life and I went to my  mom and i cried on her lap and I told her how I was feeling. She went on and on and on about how it would look if people were to find out that I had killed myself. In Africa I guess what matters the most is the whole not bringing shame to your family thing and what she was worried about was that and not me and why I wanted to kill myself.

name: Cassie
lonelinessMeans: To me, loneliness means a lot of things. It means hiding in the school bathroom, crying, but covering your mouth so that no one will hear you. It means being surrounded by the most wonderful people, but realising that they don’t understand you, and never will. It means smiling when you feel like crying, as if waking up from the sweetest dream, because even when you do have the courage to open up, no one truly understands what your going through. Being lonely doesn’t mean being alone. Being lonely is feeling like you are the only person in the room even in the midst of a huge gathering, feeling like it’s your fault you don’t belong. In reality, it’s their fault not deserving a person like you.
mostLonely: One of the times I felt most lonely was a month or so after my thirteenth birthday.  I was under the pretense that loneliness is a good thing, that when you are alone the world slows down and gives you time to reflect. That was one of the first times I realised how wrong I was. It is solitude I enjoy, not loneliness. When that thought hit me, it was like the loneliness grew and ate away at my insides, screaming to me that I could pretend it was something it wasn’t, but it would still be there in the end. It was the idea that there was nothing I could do to rid myself of it’s poison. I just collapsed, too exhausted to cry, on my bed, letting everything batter me, feeling lost and blind and hopeless. A terrible weighing in my chest like the thoughts my heart held was too heavy, that slowly they would drag me down. And that no one would even notice me go.
firstTime: My childhood is just a blur, littered with a few of the most shining memories. It’s difficult to pinpoint one of the first times I realised I was lonely, but there’s one I particularly remember. At my birthday party quite a few years ago, my eighth, or ninth. I was so excited to open presents. It was the only thing I thought about throughout the whole party. But when the time did come, and I tore open the glittery packages to find toys labelled 3+, I realised just how little my friends knew of me. It was one of the worst experiences, putting on a smile and hugging every one of them, and then breaking down in my room when the last of the cars pulled out of our driveway.

name: James
lastTime: Today when I woke up and wished I did not have to see her, knowing she probably felt the same.
lonelinessMeans: Knowing with your mind, body and heart that you have no connection with those closest to you. You are transactional.
mostLonely: I was sitting at the dinner table eating by myself after making Sunday dinner. No one came when I called. I ate by myself.
firstTime: It was our 5th wedding anniversary and I was excited to share it with her. She forgot, dismissing it so easily. She said she was too busy. I went for a walk.

name: Daniella
lastTime: Today
lonelinessMeans: Loneliness isn’t being alone; it’s being around people with whom you cannot be yourself.
mostLonely:
Six months ago a colleague of mine became my manager. In essence, he refused to provide feedback or oversight for any of my projects and began a campaign of undermining my reputation at work. As our office had thin walls, I could hear much of his conversations with colleagues that would basically consist of him convincing people who I thought were friends and confidants that I was incompetent and responsible for what were ostensibly his shortcomings.

It hurt so badly to watch these relationships crumble... but more than anything it was the most lonely moment in my life because in that time I realized that one well-situated person can sully the waters of thousands of hours of authenticity. In the end, I left that job. It has been hard trying keep in touch with people who refuse to keep plans or see you. I still wonder what exactly I did or said.. As an adult, I cannot reconcile how painful it is to watch people you love, trust, and respect be so fickle and so disingenuous. I still struggle daily with the loss of so many friends in such a short time.
firstTime: When I was six years old I realized that other people had expectations for who I was supposed to be, how I was supposed to act. One day on the school bus my best friend told me I was weird. I never thought of who I was in any other sense than the person I am... but that moment changed me. From that moment on I’ve been stuck in a cycle of trying to fit in, be accepted, and be a version of myself that people like instead of just being myself.

name: Evan
lastTime: When I was house sitting for my parents in an empty house last year.
lonelinessMeans: Loneliness is when the peace and quiet of chosen solitude turn into the anxiety and stress of the world operating sufficiently without anybody noticing you’re not there.
mostLonely: The loneliest I felt was when my roommate moved out of our apartment in the middle of the semester. At first I loved the solitude of it all, relishing the newfound freedoms I had been granted (goodbye pants!) Eventually, I started to miss the feeling of being noticed and acknowledged by others every day. Eventually, it started to feel like the world was beginning to forget I was there.
firstTime: When I stayed home alone for the first time – at first the solitude was soothing but it eventually turned to unsettling.

name: Marguerite
mostLonely: When I was in primary school, nobody wanted to be friends with me, because I am autistic and struggled with holding conversation. Everyone thought I was weird and made fun of me. Kids overestimate their ability to whisper.

name: T
lastTime: Today. My boyfriend left me because he thinks I’m an alcoholic, and then drunk texted me about it.
mostLonely: Once I had a rough day at work. I was supposed to hang out with friends after and was really looking forward to it. When I got there, they told me that I was too upset to be around them and kicked me out of their apartment. All I wanted was some support.
firstTime: When, at 3 years old, my mother left me at her date’s house while I was having an anaphylactic reaction. My eyes were swollen shut and I could barely breathe. I was there for 6 hours by myself.

name: Mary
mostLonely:
At the age of 36, I finally realized that I was depressed and probably been for a very long time. I fell apart emotionally, sought out treatment, and after several years I was feeling better about myself (this gave me the courage to get out of an abusive marriage along with my three children). When I was in hospital for my depression my mother visited and asked me “how could you do this to me?”

None of my siblings visited, I had no close friends so no friends visited either. I was ashamed and felt lesser than... I’m sounding melodramatic, the truth is I always feel lonely. ALWAYS. My life has a great deal of wonderful moments. I remarried a lovely, kind man, I have grandchildren. I have a comfortable lifestyle. Yet, I feel utterly alone.
firstTime: When I was 8 years old we moved to a new city, new school, etc. My father worked all the time and my mother stayed home to raise the five of us. She was an angry person and told me that I was just another mouth to feed. Two years later my father died of a heart attack, at his funeral I was standing beside my mom in front of his coffin. She looked down at me and said in a low growl with gritted teeth “don’t you dare cry.” I didn’t, and have stuffed my feelings ever since.

name: Anonymous
lonelinessMeans: Feeling on the outside of life, as if I am standing and watching others go by and I just can’t seem to get to where they are. It also means carrying the load of being human all by myself.
mostLonely: We have had some awful things happen in my family and as a result I go to counselling. Sitting in this waiting room, which is full of other people who share similar trauma, feels so alienating. Each of us has a terrible secret but no-one acknowledges anyone else in the room. We are almost completely invisible in a small, hot, crowded room. Each week different people come and go, some alone, some not, but it is quiet. It is hard to even imagine speaking to another person as no words seem quite right to say.
firstTime: In elementary school, when no one wanted to play with me and I was left standing on a large field by myself.

name: Joseph
lastTime: 2 months ago
lonelinessMeans: Not feeling welcomed in any space. Your own home, your workplace, the coffee shop you love. You feel like you are intruding on everyone and that you are better in the background where no one notices you.
mostLonely:
When I won my first Judo Tournament at 28, I told my friends about my 1st place victory that evening at a restaurant we all met up that evening. Everyone stared at me like I didn’t belong at that table. I was surrounded by people and I just felt so alone and defeated. I didn’t feel welcomed the whole time and just picked at the food we ordered.

I began to not wanting to do Judo, a sport I loved dearly, after that event because I felt alone for liking things that none of my coworkers, friends, and family had in common. Being a individual and yourself was casting a aura around me which people wanted to avoid. I felt that this loneliness was of my own making and I needed to like things that others liked so I can be included and not so lonely. I wanted to be normal. Being normal and trying to fit in with my friends only made me feel more lonely.

Allowing myself to accept my differences is what allows me to be at peace with this feeling. Fitting in with the popular crowd is just not something I wanted to do but the conventions of modern society wants me to do. It’s not normal for someone to not go on a coffee date with friends because you want to train for 2 hours on Judo moves they been thinking about for a week with people who understand. It’s not normal to avoid parties because you have a date with a couch and a book you want to finish up.

When my loneliness hits me, it is just a reminder that I am just doing what I can in a society that doesn’t agree with everything that I do. It’s made everything I do worthwhile and reminds me that while not everyone will agree with my life, I always have someone who gets my choices and I do the same for them.
firstTime: When I was a kid, my friends never invited me to anything that they did. I never was part of their plans and always had to be included by force when they were planning something. I never shared all the same interests so they slowly just isolated me from the group. I was alone in school, lying to my parents I had friends when I would go to the school library and just feel sorry for myself because I couldn’t be like the others.

name: Alone
lastTime: I was at a family party and no one wanted to be near me. Ever since I moved away from my abusive mother, my family barely speaks to me anymore. No birthday wishes, no hugs, no jokes, no support... nothing.
lonelinessMeans: Feeling isolated even with a group of people around you. It doesn’t matter if there’s a thousand people around you. If they don’t care about you, then you are alone.
mostLonely: I was the only person in my 9th grade health class who believed in abstinence. Everyone thought I was a freak. I was completely isolated from everyone and no one wanted to talk to me. I never had a partner in gym class and I’d always do my work alone. It hurt like hell. I was made to feel worthless only because I wanted to save myself.
firstTime: A year after my parents’ divorce, I was sitting in daycare when I saw a little girl getting picked up by her parents. She said "Hi Mommy and Daddy!" and they both embraced her at the same time. That’s when it hit me that I’d never been able to do that with my own parents ever again.

name: Anonymous
lastTime: Every day since 2015.
mostLonely: There’s never been one time where I’ve felt the most lonely. It’s rather a constant thing that I feel everyday. I have friends and family I can count on for support but no one with whom I can connect or share anything. I’ve been a journalist for about 3 years now and have covered mostly crime and war. I’ve seen enough death, bloodshed and devastation to last a lifetime, and I don’t really know anyone with whom I can relate to anymore. Veterans have a lot of support groups, mental health access and so on. But journalists make little money and have no support. The images of bloodied corpses, of people screaming and terrified for their life, of children staring at dead bodies, of soldiers with shrapnel in their chest bleeding profusely, of trying to sleep when bombs are dropping around me, are constantly with me no matter how hard I try to forget. The only time I can connect with people are when I’m in these arenas, but it’s always fleeting and then they’re out of my life and all I’m left with is more trauma.

name: Jonathan
lastTime: This morning when I woke up. A recent change in lifestyle lately has led to an increase in how much I dream. And thus, I wake most mornings with vivid images of lost friends and old loves having overwhelmed me all night. When I wake, it almost pins me to the bed. I’ve switched my alarm to the radio instead of music (so the top-of the hour news distracts me) and try and immediately rise and do something physical. But the feeling of loneliness sticks with me until I get to work.
lonelinessMeans: Loneliness is a reminder to me of the immense beauty of all the people I have ever met. Unfortunately, when those people are far away, physically or mentally or emotionally, that beauty seems unattainable and makes me feel worse. When I am lonely and get lucky enough to act on that and connect with someone, it is an amazing thing.
mostLonely:
A while ago, in the early summer, I had fallen incredibly in love with someone despite the fact that neither of us were quite ready for a relationship. When we returned to school in the fall I was faced with the prospects that they were an incredibly outgoing and loving person, something which scared and overwhelmed me (as a quiet and very shy person). When I went to them to tell them about my fears, it scared them. It scared them that I am someone with mental health issues and am someone that doesn’t like themselves are as a person. To this point, this person had only seen me in 1-on-1 situations where I am much more carefree and fun. Though I can only guess their thoughts, I imagine the prospects of having to deal with me as a burden was too much for them and they told me that we couldn’t continue to be together.
I spent 2 days at home, periodically sitting in the bottom of the shower or lying on the floor, debating suicide. To be told that your mental health is a burden to others is not easy to hear. On the 3rd day, out of nothing more than obligation, I went to work. There I had a heart-to-heart with a coworker I had never really connected with. She managed to rally the other employees to give me a longer break and bought me ice cream and took me out for beer after work. I understand that not everyone is lucky enough to find someone to pull them out of the bottom when they need it the most. But I remain eternally grateful.
firstTime: When I was 14 I got my first snowboard video for Christmas. It made me incredibly desperate to snowboard, and snowboard with friends. The people in the video appear to only have wonderful times with each other, living carefree lives. I lived in a small prairie town, with no friends who snowboarded. The disconnect between my greatest desire – to be in the mountains with funny and inspiring people – and my suburban prairie life overwhelmed me. I spent many evenings lying on the floor.

name: Nanc
lastTime: In Montréal on vacation, sitting in a crowded rooftop café.
lonelinessMeans: Feeling isolated and missing the human connection.
mostLonely:
Being "admirably independent" is a curse. It translates that people just naturally assume that you’ll be okay on your own. While there is truth within that notion, they forget that when we ask for help, it’s truly a moment that we need help. I asked for assistance to move and each person dismissed me "you’ll be fine on your own", "I’m sure you can handle it yourself", "you’re so organized, you don’t need extra help". On the day I moved into my new townhouse, I bawled on my doorstep. I felt so alone and abandoned.
Being "admirably independent" also means feeling "achingly alone."

name: Lindsay
lastTime: October 18, 2017
lonelinessMeans: Isolation, alone-ness, fear, anxiety, parenthood.
mostLonely:
I was a new mom and my daughter’s "witching hour" was at 3 AM. This time of day was the most lonely for me and the first time I truly felt the depth of how lonely parenthood would end up being for me. I would stand in front of the window looking out over the neighbourhood (while feeding the babe) and I would think about how everyone was sleeping (including my significant other) and I felt like I was the only one awake feeling my wretched feelings. To keep me company, I would keep the TV in the bedroom on. I would watched Real Housewives and Paradise Hotel re-runs. To this day turning the TV on helps me feel less lonely and reduces my anxiety – it has become a source of comfort for me.

I have resented my daughter and being a parent – before this I never felt this degree of isolation. I suffered from postpartum depression for nearly 8 years after she was born and that is an isolating experience because after a while people don’t want to help you deal with it anymore – they become tired and push you away. Thankfully, I am feeling less depressed. As she grows older and becomes someone that I can relate with parenting becomes less of a chore. I think all of my feelings stem from the fact that I never wanted children and now I am stuck with the duty of being responsible for another human life – and my loneliness is borne out of being dislocated from what I truly wanted for myself. I love my daughter and she is a beautiful and amazing soul and I do my best to be the best that I can be, but it’s not enough, for me.
firstTime: When I became a mother.

name: Carrie
lastTime: Two days ago, at work. Been at this job 5 months. None of my coworkers invite me to join them for lunch. They walk past my door in order to exit, so I know they know I’m available and can see them leaving together.
mostLonely: My first two months in my current city. I had just moved here and didn’t know a single soul. I had a tiny basement apartment where I lived alone, and everyone I loved (including my wonderful boyfriend) was a 3 hour flight away.
firstTime: I was 8 years old, and excluded from all of the social cliques at school. No one ever invited me to play at recess, so I hid in a bathroom stall rather than face the prospect of standing alone in the schoolyard.

name: JHS
lastTime: At the bar two days ago with my friends.
lonelinessMeans: A lack of community, a feeling of not being understood, a sense of worthlessness.
mostLonely: Sitting on the playground sometime before I was ten. I would read under the trees, or just stare out and watch the other kids playing. I didn’t understand them, their unadulterated joy just from from screaming and running. I was such a serious child, I thought that I was above that. I was taught that being silly and childlike was a thing to be ashamed of, that being quiet and smart was valued more in a person. I had a vivid imagination, one that went wild into fantasy or my potential future life. But that didn’t extend past dreaming and writing stories. I was too afraid of being embarrassed by the other children, being made fun of or singled out for something I did. I still can’t get over that feeling to this day, that I’m constantly being evaluated and judged. It makes for a lonely world – you have to be able to stomach vulnerability to conquer loneliness.
firstTime: In the second grade. In fact, most of my elementary school years.

name: Without Courage
lastTime: This morning walking my dog.
lonelinessMeans: A sense of hopelessness. It means no relief from struggling alone to parent and pay the bills. It means guilt from going to bed asking God to let me not wake up. The chronic feeling of being broken hearted, betrayed, abused, manipulated and often desperate.
mostLonely: Opening up my heart to another man two years after my divorce only to be rejected and betrayed again. I cried everyday for about a year. I thought I‘d never recover. My husband was the only man I‘d ever been with so this was risky business for me. It took all the courage within me to even meet this man for coffee. I look back now and see him for what he is but that experience has crippled me. I will never trust or risk my heart again. It would take Superman "cape and all" to get me to risk my heart. I‘m doomed to grow old and die alone. All this stupid technology that “connects” us and yet look at the loneliness.
firstTime: About 12 years ago at a fundraiser for my daughter's school. Every table was filled with couples. There I sat… the divorced single parent doomed to be alone because of my church’s stance on remarriage. People say "you're so strong and set such a great example to others with your commitment to your daughter." They have NO CONCEPT of the pain that causes me. The most horrendous trapped feeling.

name: Mai
lastTime: In my apartment when I thought about my life and how far I came to this point of my life. Living in a big city like Berlin can be really lonely even if I have a boyfriend.
lonelinessMeans: When no one understand you. Sometimes I wish there's a technology where I can telepathically telling other people what I think and what I feel because sometimes I can't find the right words for my feeling and my trains of thought.
mostLonely: I was 5 years old when I moved with my Mom from Nakhon Sawan, Thailand to Berlin. Before that I normally lived with my auntie and my grandmother. We sleep and eat together everyday and by night I used to sleep with my grandmother. So I was never alone somehow. My family is complicated. My Mom couldn‘t look after me because she has to work so I never saw her. And when we move to Berlin everything changed. Well, my Mom was a really strict and impatient person. It was hard to lived with her. I had no friends, couldn‘t speak german and I couldn‘t understand why I have to sleep alone. This was the time when I feel really lonely in a big city.

name: SA
mostLonely: The loneliest I felt was when I heard that I needed an emergency surgery, and I had no one to accompany me to the hospital. I went through that phase with the help of spiritual company, and I’m forever grateful to the imaginary friend we can all call upon at times.

name: Wounded
lastTime: Last night. My roommate came home with his new boyfriend, and tucked into his room for an hour. There is nothing that makes a person feel more lonely in their aloneness than someone else’s honeymoon phase.
lonelinessMeans: The absence of or inability to source love and support, especially when I need it.
mostLonely:
A few years ago, I went up to my cottage with my sister and a couple of her friends. On Sunday they left to head home ahead of my sister and I, so we went for a quick fishing trip in the morning, with plans to drive home that afternoon. On the trip, she started asking me probing questions about my my mental and physical health. We weren’t really on that level of sharing, and I was in counselling already to help define boundaries between me and my family as their impact on me was continuously negative. This incident proved, again, to be exactly that. I tried to answer her questions with a certain restriction, as I wasn’t game to share too much - she previously hadn’t treated my experience and feelings with a level of respect that I appreciated. This seemed to antagonize her, and she pressed really hard for info. Then asking why we can’t get along. Why are we not better sisters? I had to let her know I didn’t trust her with my stuff. That I’ve been through a trauma in my childhood, that she doesn’t accept or understand, and I still deal with PTSD-like symptoms to this day that she doesn’t acknowledge. She asked if I had been diagnosed, and pressed to see if my counselling was appropriate to deal with my issues. I felt very judged and triggered by her questions, she again didn’t show the concern for me that I felt a sister should show. It was clinical and cold. It seemed to come from the doubt she had about my experience. So I called her out on that, and got angry, eventually lashing out.

My reaction was exaggerated and extreme. It came from a deeply hurt place in me, that perpetually feels the divide between me and my family and longs for more care and consideration from them. She lashed back, and it just didn’t de-escalate. Over 4 hours we fought as we packed up the cottage. Eventually I paid $40 for a cab to take me to the bus station in town. Then $70 for a bus ticket home, leaving her at the cottage to drive home solo. I fended off my dad in a follow-up call, where he accused me of being the problem, again.

I sat on a pre-made floating dock from a store near the bus stop, crying as I defended myself, and all the information I shared with my sister. I answered the phone thinking he might be concerned for me. Maybe he was, but it’s not what came through. This was the most decisive move I’ve made against my family, in support of myself. It’s also the first time I very physically felt the divide. It is a deep wound, to be emotionally estranged from your family out of self-preservation. Like every time I am feeling alone and need support, and think maybe I’ll call home. I have to point to the wound and remind myself of the hurt. Cause if I don’t they’ll do it again, and I’m the one who suffers. So alone is an everyday feeling. I felt it the most that day, but the wound is always with me.
firstTime: When as a child, I felt my parents had the choice to love me or not based on how they perceived me.  In seeing how they perceived another child’s sexual assault, I decided I didn’t want to be associated with that negative impression. So I kept an incident of sexual abuse secret, creating a divide between me and my family, and a sense of isolation that persists to this day.

name: Sari
lastTime: Now
lonelinessMeans: Sometimes, being lonely is a good thing, I enjoy my alone time. But socially, not having anybody to turn to is loneliness.
mostLonely: I went to a party with my ex best-friend, who had not talked to me in weeks because she was too consumed with her boyfriend. She didn’t even talk to me, put in effort or try to be there for me.
firstTime: The day that my best friend got a boyfriend.

name: Nes
lonelinessMeans: Never being a part of a community even though I very much want to be. I am a single 30-year old Muslim woman and usually when I meet other Muslims, my ’singledom’ is bothersome to them even though I am past it. I am tired of feeling like my worth is tied to a man instead of me.
mostLonely: My parents left the US to go back to Turkey in 2013. I was in my senior year of university and I had just moved in with my friend and her family. There were about 8-10 of us there each day but I felt more alone than ever. I did not know who I was without the guidance of my parents. I was raised in a Muslim household where you go from your father’s house to the house of your spouse...except I was not married and did not plan to marry anytime soon, nor did I have any real prospects. I gained weight, stopped taking care of myself, cried myself to sleep nearly every night, and lost my friend/roommate due to my insecurities. It took me a long time to figure out my own path, but I have and I am not defined by anyone else but me today. I do not fear being alone anymore because I am all that I will ever need. When I shifted my perspective the universe brought in more people into my life, people who genuinely care and I am forever thankful. I would not be the person I am right now if it was not for the excruciating lonely phase I experienced from 2013-2015. I still remember that girl and I honor her struggle by sitting in empty parking lots for a few hours at a time (a favorite past-time of mine when I had no friends or family) here and there.
firstTime: My first relationship and every relationship thereafter. I tend to attract or put out energy which attracts men who do not treat me very well. I would give and give and give only to find myself unloved and used.

name: Mary
lonelinessMeans: Not being able to say to anyone that I feel burnt out.
mostLonely: Being an entrepreneur is really tough and very lonely. The buck stops with you and you have to be on top of everything all the time. In the early years there is no revenue so you have to get by on very little. And the hardest part is when times are tough, you doubt whether what you are doing is going to work, but you can‘t tell anyone how you really feel. In tech startups, founders are 90% men who bluff their way along and never admit that everything isn't great. No one ever says things suck. I understand a little why a friend committed suicide. There was no one he could share what was really going on in his life. I'm at a point with my business where I'm running out of energy and can't get motivated to work 24/7. I'd like to share my real challenges with someone but there is no one. This makes it very lonely.

name: Anonymous
lastTime: The past few months, weeks, days and today.
lonelinessMeans: Being surrounded by people and not being able to relate to anything. Feeling like you’re the only person who doesn’t know what they’re doing with their lives. To me, it also means not being able to share parts of my life because I don’t trust anyone enough.
mostLonely: I felt most lonely when I was out having drinks with my friends and they started talking about their relationships and sex lives. I couldn’t relate because I have always been single and never had sex. I started to wonder if I’m missing out by not dating or ’putting myself out there’. I also think what if I never find a partner and remain forever alone. I never think about it too much until I’m reminded by similar conversations.

name: Anonymous
lonelinessMeans: Helplessness, fear, isolation.
mostLonely:
My parents fight a lot. Belonging to a culture where divorce is heavily frowned upon, all I hear some days are loud yelling, crying, and weeks after that: stony silence. It wrecks me. My sister, half my age, I try to shield her from them. Close the door. Put music on.

I know they love me. I know they don’t love each other.

Days like this I feel lonely. I count down the days until I can leave, count down the days until my sister is left alone with people that hate each other, but love her. They don’t care.

I feel lonely a lot.

name: Chris
lonelinessMeans: Having no one to come to after work.
mostLonely: To understand my story, it’s important to understand its origin. My wife passed when I was 31 years old. Leaving me with a 4 and 2 year old. Raising them became my sole purpose in life. Now they are both away in college I struggle to find and understand my purpose in life. I listen to couples espouse the joys of empty nesting but for me it’s just a dark hole of nothingness every day after work. I work 11 hours a day simply because I have nothing better to do. There’s got to be a better way.
firstTime: The day after my last child went off to college.

name: Madness
lastTime: The last time I felt lonely was last night. Every night, I can’t sleep, I just lie in bed wondering if it’s even worth being here.
lonelinessMeans: Anxiety
mostLonely: The most lonely I’ve felt is when I found out about my anxiety, and it just made me feel crazy, and every time someone looks at me, I tell myself that they think I’m crazy too.
firstTime: When I first started high school I started out with no friends. But even now, when I have friends, I still feel completely alone. When I’m around them I can feel how confident and happy they are, and I’m still here waiting to find out that maybe this is all just a dream, and when I wake up I’ll be okay.

name: Juliet
lonelinessMeans: Two days ago, when I found alcohol my mother had been hiding from me again.
mostLonely: This year I’ve felt both very lonely and very connected. I started university, which began with me pretending I didn’t mind sitting alone when I ate lunch and ended with a best friend and a bunch of other wonderful people who genuinely care about my wellbeing. I still feel lonely when I realise I can’t tell them how much I worry about my mother and her recent alcoholism, though. Sometimes I get home and she’ll be drunk and I’ll feel so guilty for leaving her alone. I keep finding bottles and glasses of vodka stashed away and I get so paranoid that I’m disrespecting her boundaries in trying to find the alcohol she’s hiding from me. The other day she stole alcohol that was a present for my friend and lied about it. She’s not a bad person and she’s been a wonderful mother to me. I think this makes it harder; I’ve trusted her completely my whole life and now whenever I see her I feel nothing but paranoia and isolation. I’m the loneliest I’ve ever been.
firstTime: I very much enjoy going for walks by myself. I’m lucky to live near the bush, so sometimes I’ll go for a day hike and feel like I’m in the middle of nowhere without anyone around. Being alone does not equate loneliness. Loneliness can be the inability to convince yourself that the people who swear they love you aren’t lying. It can be surrounded by people who you talk to but can’t be yourself towards. It can be noticing how connected others are, and then realising that you’re trying in vain to be like them. Worst of all, it can be tempting and almost romantic to be lonely if you disconnect enough from reality.

name: Anonymous
mostLonely: Last week. I got broken up with by someone I had opened up to and talked about a future with, and after the break up I went into a depressed spiral of not eating and not talking to people and just wallowing. Realising that people’s lives just go on while yours is crumbling, and that people can just not notice, is something terribly isolating. But once I extended my hand and said "I need help please," I realised how many people care, they just can’t read minds.

name: Lexie
lastTime: All day today.
lonelinessMeans: Something I got used to, it defines all aspects of my life.
mostLonely: December 17th 2017, my girlfriend went to the United States to help her father, who was going through a medical treatment. After the flight, she spent days without contacting me. It was only when I tried to reach her, I found out she had cancelled her emails and changed her phone number. To this day, I still check my phone and emails every hour, waiting for an answer.
firstTime: When I invited my classmates to my 12th birthday party and no one showed up.

name: Schmatta
lonelinessMeans: No one caring about my feelings or that I have any feelings at all.
mostLonely: I feel most lonely RIGHT NOW realizing that my adult daughters don’t care what I do or where I go (my grandchildren are getting bigger and do not need me like they used to) and my husband is mentally talking himself into being old at 74, and I now have to face the truth that he never cared about me and does not have the ability to love me or listen to my needs. My son died at 30 and the pain will never go away (after 9 years) so that is sitting inside my stomach and my family will not discuss it with me (a mother who is crying for her child). I am trying to understand what I did wrong in my life (and my children’s lives) that they are so callous as not to even listen to their mother’s cry for help. I guess I never showed them my vulnerability before so this situation is not something they know how to deal with. I was always there for them and still am. They are treating me now like a "schmatta" or rag that they can now either throw away or do not need any more (unless a crisis arises). I don’t really have good close friends who might care and acquaintances don’t really give a damn. I don’t seem to have interests that I can pursue and I feel much younger than my age and I haven’t met too many women my age that don’t talk about their ailments or operations. I am a younger person at heart that feels comfortable talking to mothers who have younger children but I am still 73 years old. Our finances are limited so I cannot pursue my only passion right now of fixing up my house so that I can feel refreshed and, of course, my husband doesn’t care where he lives. All he cares about is that I feed him and not give him stress. I don’t need anti-depressants (which would make my physical being a basket case) I JUST NEED SOMEONE TO TALK TO, BE COMPASSIONATE TOWARDS ME AND NOT JUDGE ME FOR FEELING THIS WAY. I have given up on my psychologist because after a while, they don’t want to hear everyday whining, they eventually want to see results. I guess I should look for another psychologist but that’s just the way my life is going. Loneliness is eating me up alive.
firstTime: Being an only child of two parents who wanted me to be their parent at 5 yrs old.

name: Dareen
lonelinessMeans: Having empty conversations with people who will always look at you as their token immigrant in their group. Always feeling like you are on the outside looking in. Being a gay Muslim immigrant is not a combination that makes people want to invite you in their lives. Especially when you don’t look the way they paint immigrants.
mostLonely: When I got to Canada and left my abusive parents’ home. Had no friends, not even casual ones, barely making rent and my friends back home with the time difference couldn’t match up. Felt like I was sinking everyday without anyone to call out for.
firstTime: When I was in grade 9, I had feelings I would be prosecuted for in my home country, and had 0 people to talk to. But millions to judge me.

name: Chloe
lastTime: Every time I’m by myself with my thoughts.
lonelinessMeans: Being the person people see you as instead of the person you know you are.
mostLonely: Some nights when my depression gets bad, I badly need someone to talk to, and the first time I had a full on wave of depression was the first time I realized I had no one to talk to about it. No one I knew was I comfortable to share it with, and my parents were definitely out of the picture. I was forced to internalize it, and the next day when I went to school I expected people to notice that I was not alright, and that I needed someone to talk to and didn’t know who to reach out to. No one noticed. I realized then that it didn’t matter how I felt on the inside and how well I knew myself if everyone I know sees me as a bright and happy girl. If I’m the only person that actually knows who I am, how does anyone really know me at all? Are we really the people we know ourselves to be if everyone else has a different image of us? Do I exist outside of their main image of me?
firstTime: When I was really upset and really needed to talk to someone, but realized that I didn’t have anyone to confide in.

name: Dani
lastTime: All the time. On the bus. On the couch watching TV with friends. At concerts, going dancing. All the time.
lonelinessMeans: I don’t feel human, I feel small and curled up, like a tiny animal in permanent hibernation. Nothing gets through and everything’s cold.
mostLonely: When two of my dearest friends got married and I was in the wedding party. My SO couldn’t be there and I didn’t know many of the other people attending. I love to dance, loved the music... but no one was dancing with me, no matter how much I tried to dance and just let go. So I left the wedding tent and stood outside in a field under the stars, hearing the far away music and dancing by myself because that was the only place I could dance.
firstTime: I’d spend hours in a dreamland in my head, creating elaborate places to go and wild adventures to have, but then I’d look around and realize that no one around me wanted to hear my stories because I was the weird kid at school no one liked.

name: Anonymous
lonelinessMeans: Having a question on the tip of your tongue, but feeling unable to ask it.

name: Melanie
lastTime: Today.
lonelinessMeans: Being on my own for the first time in many years.
mostLonely: When I found out that my partner of 20+ years had cheated on me with multiple women over the years while coming home to me every day pretending that all was well. Incredible sadness and loneliness that lingers even though we are now separated.
firstTime: When I found myself out at a summer festival and I saw so many couples and families having fun together and I was there alone.

name: Newt
lastTime: Yesterday.
lonelinessMeans: No one to share your feelings with.
mostLonely:
The time I felt the loneliest… I actually never knew at the moment I was lonely. It actually was a progression of many years. In my younger years I never felt lonely as I was always in a social setting. Dinners, parties, nightclubs and college life seemed to fill the void of companionship. About 5 years ago I stopped drinking and had my first of 3 children. As the bar days were over and I was spending more time at home with my family. Things seemed good and stable.

It was around this time that the dynamics in my household started to change. I love my partner to death but as we started to argue more often I realized that she was my only confidant. She was there for when I had work issues, when I was mad at the other drivers on the road or if I just wanted to share a good story about my day. With kids screaming and enough problems of her own, these conversation were becoming further and further apart. I had so much to share, but no one to share with. Scrolling through my phone looking for someone to reach out to, I found no shortage of business associates, old college buddies, some far of relatives but no one that I could share my most inner feelings with. This was when I felt the hurt in my chest knowing that this time I really was alone. I had a bomb of emotions inside me and I needed to diffuse it. I went for a walk, allowed myself to hurt and began to reassure myself that albeit I felt alone in that moment, that out there was another man walking on a path, feeling my same emotions.

Loneliness definitely hurts. I have tried to take my experiences and use them to learn about myself and experience how the human soul can persevere. I do long for a meaningful relationship but at the same time I am using this opportunity to develop my own strength and self-awareness so that one day I can be a good friend to the other man walking life’s journey in parallel with me… alone…. for now.
firstTime: When I was deeply hurt by a close family member and as I scrolled through my phone to see who I could call... there was nobody I had that type of open relationship with.

name: Risika
lastTime: Today
lonelinessMeans: Being alone, even when you might be surrounded.
mostLonely: I was, still am I guess, a foster kid. The feeling of abandonment never leaves you, it just continues to grow. My ’family’ was there, but I never belonged. I just drifted in and out of the family experience, feeling like I could disappear any moment and it would be easier for everyone. To this day I still talk to them, and I know they  care, but the feeling still follows. I moved and I was even more alone, I would break down every couple of months. Now loneliness is a way of life, and it’s harder than ever to let people in.
firstTime: Very young, since about 6 years old.

name: Chris
lastTime: This morning
lonelinessMeans: Really discovering who you are. There is no one in the world but you, in the end, and you have to be really lonely to understand, accept, and love yourself. So loneliness means finding out that you’re in pretty good emotional shape in this old world!
mostLonely: This may sound like a stand-up routine or a sitcom, but it’s me. Folding sheets. Seriously. When I lived with someone, it was a fun routine, a ritual, a practiced task. Even the cats got involved trying to get into the sheets that were half-way folded, that looked like a hammock to them. Now, living alone, folding sheets is a nightmare. There is no way to be successful. Even if I fold them on the floor, they just get dirty again. And those goddamn fitted sheets! UGH! And then after I’ve stuffed them away in the closet, then pull them out to make my bed with fresh sheets, they resemble used kleenex! So insult to injury, I go to bed at night alone sleeping in these ridiculously creased sheets. Sigh.
firstTime: I used to move a lot as a kid, and had to change schools all the time. As a young kid who was a little self conscious and shy, that first day of school was always the loneliest. It was a combination of feeling sad for leaving my friends, and being scared of meeting new people - AGAIN - and the fear of being left out or rejected.

name: Aavi
lastTime: This Wednesday.
mostLonely: I’m Indian, so one day at lunch I had my food, this was in 6th grade. Another 6th grader started yelling at me "why you eatin’ dat shiiiiit" "that shiiiiits ugly" as an obvious attempt to look cool. If I had a friend with me I could have stood up to him, but I was alone and he was with his friends so I just moved tables.
firstTime: When something funny happened to me, and I realized I had no one to tell.

name: Chloe
lastTime:
On the train. There is something I find incredibly lonely about travelling and I almost always cry on the train home after travelling. I live 4 hours away from my family and most of my closest friends are spread around. For the past 7 years, whenever I have a week off, most of my time is spent train hopping between cities to see everyone I care about. I feel incredibly fortunate to still live within a reasonable distance to see everyone I love and it is not that my relationships are strained by the distance.

The aspect of travelling that feels lonely to me is feeling suspended in space. I’m not grounded in one place or another, it’s just me and my seat and whatever is in my bag. It’s that liminal space when I’m confronted with myself. I can choose to distract myself to pass the time or take that time to be aware of myself. It is a powerful moment in time that amplifies any emotions related to what I am currently experiencing. And I can’t help reflecting back on the many many many train rides I’ve had over the past 7 years and either revisiting those same emotions or gaining a unique perspective on my personal growth.
lonelinessMeans:
An awareness that we ourselves are the only constant in our own lives.

I don’t think loneliness is synonymous with unhappiness. Accepting your loneliness and finding comfort and happiness while lonely is incredibly empowering.

name: Laura
lastTime: Last night. I was sitting on my couch flipping through Facebook and saw a guy I had a fling with a few years ago had started dating someone. I haven’t spoken to him in years but it made so sad. That brief time we spent together was the last time I remember feeling truly happy with someone. I had always held out hope that we would find each other again. His life is moving on, he is happy, and I am by myself feeling like an idiot for still thinking of him. I realized my feelings and thoughts are completely one-sided because he is not thinking about me. It made me realize that I’m starting to give up on ever finding someone and that there is a real possibility I may never find someone to share my life with. I’m not sure I am prepared for that.
lonelinessMeans: The feeling of isolation celebrating milestones and events of other people knowing fully well I may never get to celebrate them myself. Engagements, weddings, baby showers, it’s wonderful celebrating people that I love genuinely finding happiness, but it is always in the back of my mind that it isn’t me. The older I get, celebrating these things becomes more uncomfortable and more painful, but I can’t tell anyone because I would appear self-centered. The more my friends and family find partners and start families, the more forgotten and alone I feel.
mostLonely: I don’t think there was ever one specific time I felt most lonely. I turned 34 a couple of months ago and it sort of hit me that I am still alone in my mid-thirties. I live in a rural area and there aren’t many prospects so it looks like my being alone isn’t going to change anytime soon. Loneliness is starting to be more apparent to me, and starting to feel more permanent and that really scares me.
firstTime: I was at my cousin’s wedding many years ago with my family. A slow song came on and every one of my family members, my grandparents, parents, sister, aunts and uncles and cousins all took their significant others to the dance floor. I realized I was the only one left sitting at the table. I have never felt such humiliation. For the first time I truly felt alone, and I realized this might be my future. I got up and went to the bathroom and cried. People always talk about the isolation that comes with loneliness but no one ever mentions the feelings of discomfort, embarrassment, and shame it can bring as well.

name: Emma
lastTime: Now
lonelinessMeans: Wanting to be close with someone but being alone and distant from them.
mostLonely: I have no friends and I’m not close enough with anyone to even message occasionally so when I get bored I go on walks. These walks lead to me thinking about life and then my mood goes down. Once when I was walking I was thinking about being asexual and aromantic and how I’d never get married or move in with someone I love... Then I got thinking about how I’ll have to move in with a friend and rely a lot on friendships. I realized that I’ll never have a boyfriend and I’m honestly terrified of making friends so my future will be filled with being alone in my apartment, not talking to anyone outside of work for months at a time and utter boredom. I wish I had a group of friends, I wish I had a best friend and most of all I wish I wasn’t aromantic/asexual because I hate being alone. I’m going to be alone for the rest of my life...
firstTime: Sitting at lunch and realizing that I was the only one sitting alone, the only one who didn’t even talk to anyone online.

name: Hunter
lastTime: Generally during school grades 8 through to 11.
lonelinessMeans: Not being able to connect with others socially, or simply being pushed away by others to the point where you feel as if you are the sole person living in your world.
mostLonely:
Some people at my school joked about hanging out with themselves or having me-time for a change. When I had a couple of me-months, I kind of figured something was up. Every weekend where teenagers my age should be out with friends, socializing, or hanging out there I was at home either sleeping or gaming. I’ve come to realize now that I actually hate gaming because I was using it as a coping method to block out some aspects of my life which I was wanting to just shove away. I was also using sleep as a coping method sometimes even when I wasn’t tired at all.

What I was wanting to hide and why I wasn’t so involved socially with others is the fact that I am gay. I had known since I was just twelve years old but up until about high school it hadn’t been a bother. It was not only boring being by myself but I felt like empty space and had no real feelings. Some people told me to try different things, you know, like meet new people as if its as easy as the snap of a finger. They didn’t know I was gay. What they didn’t know about me, what my closest friends or family didn’t know about me is that I got really anxious around others, my heart rate increases, and if I am not comfortable around people my words come out funny.

I usually played it off cool but as my schooling continued It became more obvious. I got lonely because of my sexuality but also because of how the few friends that I did have left me feeling. I did not tell them that I was gay nor did any of my mannerisms, the way I dress, talk, or hold myself give it away. If a guy they simply stopped being my friend. I don’t know if it was because I wasn’t as close as a guy friend should be or just because I was already so lonely. If a girl they usually thought I was wanting to date them even though I just wanted to be friends and after a while we just wouldn’t click anymore. I felt bad because I thought I was the one making them not be my friends, I thought that I was different than the normal teens at the school. I felt like I needed to change but every time I tried it wouldn’t work and it would send me back to my lonely courtyard table.

I’ve come to realize that I can’t change who I am, I am Hunter, I am gay, and even now sometimes I get lonely but If I don’t stand up for myself and start socially living again, my life would not be as great as it is today.

Thank you.
firstTime: When I was eating lunch during grade nine. I went to my usual spot outside in the courtyard to eat my food and sometimes there was a kid or two also there but they were just like me, quiet. We wouldn’t really talk, just eat, then go back to class. I had no real social life to go to during school and it started degrading me and making me feel like I was tossed away or forgotten. Going out to the courtyard to eat at my table rain or shine was my happy place even though my face may have not shown happiness as an emotion. Some people would walk by the windows and stare but I would face the other way because I just didn’t care. This was one of my first true moments where I realized I wasn’t fitting in and I was lonely.

name: Eric
lastTime: Today
lonelinessMeans: Not being able to share some things in my life with someone who knows me well enough that they understand.
mostLonely:
My wife passed away a little over a year ago. There are many days that I feel this overwhelming sadness but the worst is when I turn to share something with her and I realize that I can’t.

I know it will get better but I sure don’t feel like it has. Work helps to fill some of the void but when I am tired or just tired of work, it gets hard to keep going. I am probably depressed but I am still functional, just not happy.

It’s been said many times that people just want to be loved and I do believe that is true. I was and now I don’t feel it as much as I used to. My son helps a lot and we connect regularly but he lives pretty far away and it isn’t the same. We have grown closer and we worry about each other.

At my age I feel like some sort of dirty old man if I approach a woman and the chance of meeting someone of a similar age is pretty low. I am working on making more of myself and trying to concentrate on things that interest me but there is always that cover of sadness. And then I realize I am whining.

name: Anonymous
lastTime: Yesterday
lonelinessMeans: Wanting something so much but knowing that you can’t have it.
mostLonely: I want to have my own family and should be able to have one but my parents are currently struggling with their jobs and my sister needs help for school so I can’t concentrate on just me. Every Sunday at church when the children are called to the front for the blessing, I want to look away but can’t. I see people my age coming up with their spouse and young children in tow and I think “that could be me” but I’m reminded that I can’t have that. I can’t afford to. I’m needed elsewhere.
firstTime: When I moved to Canada.

name: Megan
lastTime: Christmas
lonelinessMeans: Exclusion
mostLonely: Christmas. My parents are divorced and when I was 19 I spent Christmas alone. My mom was with her husband and his family. My dad was with his girlfriend and her family. My older siblings were with their significant others and I spent Christmas Eve and Christmas Day alone. I didn’t even get a phone call.

name: Just a Kid
mostLonely: It‘s Christmas and we‘re opening gifts. My brother makes a rude comments and my dad gets out of his chair and screeches, "why don't you just leave! I hate you!". This ended in a knockdown drag out fight, my mother crying alone in the bathroom and me trying to hold back tears as I open a gift under the now empty tree. I'm not sure I like Christmas so much anymore. In practice it's wonderful but in reality it feels like acid to my skin.
firstTime: When I woke up and realized that my life is not just happy and carefree. I was seven or eight, maybe six. My parents were fighting and my brother was yelling and my sister was dead silent and I felt like I had no one.

name: Rei
lastTime: I keep telling my mom that I can't continue living in their house anymore. My dad has random angry outbursts and my mom always tells me to just understand him. Sometimes I have to study for exams, but he randomly wants something and I cannot say no. I think I failed the exam because I couldn't study. I keep telling my mom that my dad's ways are toxic, but she keeps condoning his behaviour. I have to always walk on eggshells inside the house and keep doing all the chores that it's exhausting. I feel like I'm dying in my own house. I can't sleep because we live beside a busy street and my room faces the roads, so I can hear all the cars and people at night. I've told her countless times that I think that this isn't the best place. I want to move out. There's a ton of crime right beside our house with someone being murdered recently, but my mom just laughs it off. I'm not even being heard. All my concerns are valid, but they think I'm just being too much of a diva wanting my own place. My mom never listens to any of my concerns unless it's about my grades anymore. Anything else is just me being over-dramatic. It's frustrating and she just laughs at everything I tell her. My dad is worse. One time, my brother said he wanted to kill himself and my dad said to suck it up. Both of them are terrible listeners and all they do is wanna talk about themselves. My dad throws a fit when no one listens to his stories. He's a grown ass man.
mostLonely: Back home Christmas and New Year were big holidays. In my home country, my city was the country‘s capital so there were always gigantic celebrations with families, relatives, friends, and I was invited to go to a lot of places to celebrate. Here in Canada, one of my parents has to work on either Christmas or New Year. It‘s sad because now, it's just my parents, my younger brother and I during the holidays. My youngest brother passed away a few years ago and we already didn't have a lot of people to celebrate it with in this new country... now it hurts even more that my youngest brother passed away. Usually, we just watch TV during the holidays and depending on whether my mom has work or not, she prepares a big feast for like 4 people. If not, we just watch TV and my dad drinks and locks himself in his room until the next day...
firstTime: One time, my family left me at home thinking I was at school. They went to a restaurant all together thinking I wasn't home. I was in my room and no one had bothered to check.

name: Angela
mostLonely: It was Christmas 1971. My family was downstairs – maybe a dozen people – and I was getting something in my bedroom. I remember looking out the window as the stars came out, listening to the laughter and bubbling conversations drifting up from downstairs, and a feeling went through me that told me I would never ever have this – a happy family of my own. Sadly, it proved to be true.

name: Emma
mostLonely: I just had our child after a difficult labor and had my mother come visit us to help out during the first weeks (we lived abroad). Instead my mother was more interested in going out, have coffee with friends than actually be there emotionally for me. When I tried to talk and explain to her that I found the first days of motherhood very difficult and didn’t feel there she was truly being supportive, she told me I needed to stop being emotional and allow her to live her life. The real kicker after this conversation was when she told me that she had put up and was still putting up with dealing with me and my siblings.
firstTime: Just before Christmas about ten years ago. I was homesick but couldn't afford to go home (at the time I was studying abroad). When I admitted this to my mother she simply replied with: "it will be good for you to spend some time alone". This literally felt like emotional betrayal. To this day I still feel like I can't count on her for emotional support.

name: Celia
mostLonely: Having to work in the city when everyone else got to go home for Christmas was always a difficult time but the worst was when I moved to the opposite end of the country to make a fresh start after my relationship ended. I lived with my dad and it brought up so many wounds of the past, I never did make myself at home there and the fresh start never came. I developed a drinking problem, made a lot of stupid mistakes that hurt me, and had a lot of people take advantage of my vulnerability. It has scarred me to this day. Now I have moved again, I have many good friends and a support network close by but I still feel alone much of the time because of having BPD. I am afraid of what loneliness makes me do, the risks I am willing to take to avoid feeling alone. I feel so empty inside. Sometimes I don‘t want to be around people so I avoid them but then I feel isolated and lonely, the longer I spend in my own company the more I hate myself and the less I want to see people, so it becomes an endless toxic cycle.
firstTime: When my sister started school and I was left behind at home.

name: Margarita
lonelinessMeans: Having many kinfolk who relate to you only because they are interested in what they can gain from you.  I am an immigrant and relatives back home are forever needing assistance but never thinking of acknowledging the help or expressing any gratitude. It finally came to the point where I put a stop to the give-aways, and so now I am alone in the world. I feel better about my last decision, because I no longer feel used.
mostLonely: I felt most lonely when I turned 65 and realized that I will be spending the rest of my life with no relatives helping me cross the threshold to death. I’ve read so many obituaries stating that so and so died surrounded by loving family. I will never have that.
firstTime: When I spent Christmas without any greeting or acknowledgment from people to whom I painstakingly sent funds and goodies.

name: Luz
lastTime: Thanksgiving weekend
lonelinessMeans: Not having anyone in town that I can call up for coffee
mostLonely: I felt most lonely when I moved cities for a job and 2 years later realized that I had made no connections deep enough in my new home where I could invite someone or be invited by someone for a Christmas meal. I am Muslim by faith but Christmas had always been a special time for me, so it was a crushing blow to me to realize that I was truly alone in that city.
firstTime: Last Christmas

name: T
lastTime: Every day after I leave work.
mostLonely: I talk to myself – for other people. I‘m so alone that sometimes I call out to people that aren‘t there for dinner or to come see something on TV. At work, I see people all day, but I go home to an empty house and stay there until I repeat the process. All of my friends have their own partners and/or families and and I am divorced, my kids are grown and being single at my age isolates you so anymore, I feel "the most lonely" every day. I had a relationship for about 18 months but one day he decided that he didn't want me anymore which intensified the loneliness. It's funny how you can feel something for a long time but then feel it even more after something like that. As if someone peeled back the layer of normal lonely to expose raw lonely. I suppose perhaps I'm at my loneliest during the holiday months because while everyone else is celebrating, I am often times by myself or even worse, surrounded by couples and families. One holiday I'm fortunate enough to have my children come home, the other I'm not. It's tough and I already feel the sting of it and it's not even Halloween...

name: Anonymous
lonelinessMeans: Feeling isolated or disconnected from family or friends, or a lack of physical or emotional intimacy in a partnership.
mostLonely: Loneliness while in a relationship is the worst – laying next to someone and realizing you are so disconnected, no matter how hard your try, you are better off alone. I endured so much emotional abuse, I felt broken. I know I’m not unique in this, and as a single woman in my 40’s, now I have a fantastic life. At this point, I have been single for a few years, and I am really ready for a solid relationship with a good man. I want the physical and emotional intimacy of having a partner, I want someone with whom I can share my life. It is so frustrating when people who have been married for decades and haven’t ever been alone, say to me “you have to learn how to be happy on your own.” I have more than proven I can thrive as a single and can take care of myself. Holidays are the worst, but at least I still have my parents and siblings. I think I should get a dog, maybe host international students. Create a sense of purpose in having my own, non-biological family, so to speak.

name: Joe
lastTime: Every day – gay, alone now.
lonelinessMeans: Worrying about today, tomorrow – how will I cope, few friends – no-one interested in me. days are long, holidays unbearable.
mostLonely: Thought I was in love twice, both guys treated me badly – had to cry for weeks – no-one communicates honestly with a reason why it did not work.
firstTime: As a teen, knowing I could not date a young man, people would ridicule me if they knew.

name: N
lonelinessMeans: No one truly knowing who I am. Having no one to count on or give me a hug when I need someone.
mostLonely: Now. My sisters and aunt have alienated my mom and me from their lives over the past couple years. We don’t fit into their perfect, snobby lifestyles and think we’re losers. I’m being judged on behavior from my teens and 20s (along their presumptions of what and who I am), but I have changed so much since then. My mom and I may not be as well off as they are, but we’re not suffering either. My sisters and aunt control all family events and we are no longer invited for birthdays, family dinners or holidays. Even though I think they’re pretty much bitches, it hurts to go from big holidays with 30+ people, to just me and my mom. I feel especially sad and lonely when I think of what my life will be like after my mom is gone. I will have no family left.
firstTime: As a teenager, sitting in the basement in the middle of the night watching TV. I was a high school dropout with severe depression and anxiety, and I shut myself off from the world rather than deal with the pain of life.

name: Kimberly
mostLonely:
My loneliness waxes and wanes. Just recently, I got broken up with in public and was left there, sobbing, by myself. No one stopped to ask if I was okay. I’ve been devastated. I tried to fill my time on the weekend, and I felt like I had no one to spend time with me, so I ended up at a pub by myself and got very intoxicated all alone. I sat on the street for a while, drunk and heartbroken, because I had nowhere to go with my pain.

Just like many others, my loneliness is exacerbated by the holidays. I want to spend my holidays with the people I love, and that does not entail my family. I want to spend time with friends, but unfortunately, my family would never allow that. So I’m forced into rooms with extended family members, while I’m incredibly empty and void inside.

Sometimes, I feel like I’m destined for loneliness, and maybe I just don’t deserve companionship.
firstTime: I was probably about 12 or so, and that’s when the bullying at school really started. The worst part was that it was being perpetrated by my “friends.” My parents haven’t ever been very supportive of me emotionally, so I never had anyone to talk to, and that was the start of my habit of holding my sadness and demons by myself.

name: Pamela
lonelinessMeans: Not being connected to family or friends. Not feeling important to anyone. Not fitting in.
mostLonely: I feel the most lonely when I give in to my expectations of what I imagine life should be like. Example: having my parents still alive and having big holiday gatherings with them or wishing I had grandchildren to love and spoil.
firstTime: While my boys were pre -schoolers (mid 80’s) we were posted in a town I knew nobody and my husband was working long shift work. Again, after I lost my job and then my youngest son went to university in Japan. He’s been there for 7 years.

name: Anonymous
mostLonely:
I feel lonely most during holidays and weekends when I don’t have my son. Holidays is a hard time of year overall because I miss family. It’s become harder for me over the last few years.

I feel most lonely when I am faced with a household challenge that is typically a blue job. I have no one to help me figure it out (such as electrical work in my oven and leaves that need to be cleaned out of eaves) and no one to call. Well that’s not true, I have plenty of people to call for help but I have a hard time reaching out. I’ve been trying to ask for help, and lately no one is available. I get it, everyone has their own busy lives and can’t be available when I need it. I feel lonely again because it reminds me I’m single and alone, then amplifies the feeling of loneliness.

Loneliness sinks in again when I have to schedule my holidays at work. Which is due November 15th. I have no one to plan a vacation with. Yes I can take my son somewhere, but that’s not so simple. I have a medical issue, seizures, and where I had a MVA last year while in vacation with my son. This has been traumatic for him. So it’s not easy for me to go places with him alone, because should something happen to me, I have no one to take care of him. Again, I’m reminded I’m alone and the feeling of loneliness (and then sadness) sets in.

I’ve been divorced for 8 years. I was married to a man who is a local in this town. He has a reputation that is not always favourable by some, which leaves the locals avoiding me when it comes to relationships and/or dating. He has been controlling in our marriage, and since I walked out it’s been worse. Since my divorce, I have had experiences where men express their like for me, but because of who my ex can be, they prefer not to have to “deal” with him. I feel that I have been branded in his town, which further makes me feel alone and lonely. I have shared custody and therefore my options of relocating is not great. Most days I’m ok with being single. But it’s because of the examples I listed above, the feeling of being lonely is amplified and acutely at the forefront.

Social media is damaging for us all as well. Loneliness has left me feeling depressed and ironically isolating myself. Being around people do not always make me feel less lonely. I’m some situations I felt more alone.

I am recently practicing yoga. I am doing my best to be mindful and present. Limiting my time on social media. I am practicing being grateful for the great things in my life and keeping myself busy with friends and family. But even with that, the loneliness haunts me and it’s a fight.
firstTime: The first time I realized I felt lonely was a few years ago. I was at a Christmas party full of people. Some were was close friends with, some just acquaintances. I was the only person there without a significant other. That was something I was accustomed to and typically have been ok with. But this time I felt different. Myself, along with many of my girlfriends are divorced with joint custody of their children.  All of my friends have met and started new lives with someone else, all except me. I was in a room full of people and I was not only alone, but felt lonely. I couldn’t understand how that could be when I was surrounded by many people and have so many people love me. But I was still lonely.

name: Em
lastTime: I recently went to visit my grandparents for a long weekend. My grandfather and I were close until a few years ago, when I moved across the state and he started drinking again after 22 years of sobriety and seemed to lose all hope or positivity about anything. He and I had to drive about 20 minutes to the store together, and after about a minute of polite exchange, we both just went silent. I don’t know what was in his mind, but in that moment I felt all the distance that had never been there before. It’s the worst feeling in the world to be alone in someone else’s presence, and it’s gut wrenching how I felt that with someone with whom I used to be inseparable.
lonelinessMeans: When you want, need, to hear another’s voice, to say something that matters, to feel them breathing on the other side of the couch or catch their glance, and there’s no one.
mostLonely: The day my mother died (a long story in and of itself), she had been in the ICU overnight. The doctors came in and told us she had lost all brain activity, and it was just a matter of taking her off the respirator. I was not in the room by myself, but I was the only viable next-of-kin to sign off on removing her life support. One brother was in prison, but the other was only about an hour away. I called him to come and sign with me, and he refused because he “couldn’t do that to Momma.” She had always told us not to let her live comatose – she hated the idea of it. So, I signed my mother’s death warrant by myself, at age 18. I have never felt more loneliness in my life, or more fear, or more sorrow.
firstTime: When my mother had come down with liver disease and no one knew, I would come home from middle school and cook dinner for us both, since it was just the two of us in the house. I’d wake her up and hand her the food, she’d eat it without saying much, and go back to sleep. Those nights were the longest nights. Among the darkest, too.

name: Reese
lastTime: Months ago.
lonelinessMeans: Everyone saying they would always be there for you, and that they'd never forget about you, but they do.
mostLonely: In seventh grade, there was an eighth grader who constantly harassed me physically and verbally, grabbing my thighs and butt, calling me flat, making unwanted advances, etc, and I finally gathered up the courage to tell a friend. They told me that they just liked me, and I was "overreacting" and I just wanted attention. Nobody did anything and I can’t open up the same way since.
firstTime: In second grade, I was the weird kid. I remember walking around the playground wishing that a meteor would hit me because nobody wanted to talk to me.

name: Anonymous
lonelinessMeans: Lack of touching, not in a sexual way, in a way that acknowledges me and sees and feels me as a person.

name: Liz
lastTime: Today – in my history class there are four large desks made up of many individual desks. None of my good friends are in my class but I still get along with everyone. One of the desk groups seats one friendship group, another seats another the the third seats the group that I would be most close with. There are 8 places there and 7 of them are filled up. Everyone's books are on the final place. I am always sitting by myself on the last group of desks. Today I plucked up the courage to ask if I could sit there. I was rejected. They were saving it for someone else, someone who they wouldn't name. I know they were lying because no one ever sits there. No one else came the entire lesson. They didn't want me to sit with them. I had no one.
lonelinessMeans: Having no one you can turn to, no friend or relative or pet. No one you can cry with, laugh with, chat with, discuss problems and feelings with etc.

name: Rachel
lastTime: Last week, out for drinks with my sister and her coworkers while they spoke an academic language in which I have no fluency.
lonelinessMeans: Many people but no connection.
mostLonely: Second year of university, alone in my residence room, having a panic attack as my floor mates had a conversation just outside the door. Having no idea to communicate to them, feeling a mounting wall blocking out those around me. The special, insidious loneliness that comes from the belief that no matter how kind and genuine they seem, the people you know secretly hate you. When trying to explain the worst sides of anxiety and depression, this is often a story I use.
firstTime: When I began experiencing depression at 13 and felt myself relating less and less to those around me.

name: Carebear
lastTime: This week. I know that as we mature we spend less time out and about with friends. However, I work from home, so I get out even less than the norm. I try to reach out via Facebook, but even that is not truly reaching out into one another’s physical space. Last week I got a message from Facebook that said that if I had more friends there would be more stories in my feed. OUCH! This week my feed was full of people nominating 7 of their friends (one a day) to post one black and white photo a day. This is reminiscent of hoping to not be the last person selected for dodge ball. If I had been “nominated” I would have asked all of my friends to join the fun.
lonelinessMeans: Waiting for someone to call me to ask me how I am or asking me if I want to go out and do something together, and the phone just doesn’t ring or the evite never appears
mostLonely: I told my sister about our childhood friends having get togethers, and she went out of her way to reconnect with them, after one group get together that I attended, I learned that there had been others that she went to, and even though she knew this was a sorrow in my life, has not made sure that I too was included. I just find myself wondering why am I so forgettable?
firstTime: After I joined Facebook and discovered that people were an important part of my youth had stayed in touch with each other, but not with me.

name: Tiffany
lastTime: A while ago. I’m in a good spot now.
lonelinessMeans: Feeling empty inside without having anyone or anything to fill that void
mostLonely: When I was in elementary school, we moved to yet another state, South Carolina, because my mom was getting back together with someone and I begrudgingly went with her.
