Not to mention, that guy said that there was a really good job opportunity there so of course we just had to go. I moved there without knowing a single soul and only had my mom to lean on. I was treated quite differently on my first day of school because I was Asian while everyone else just wasn’t. Not the best way to start a new life, especially at my age. My mom was working long hours to support three people and was gone most of the time while the other guy locked himself in his room all day to drink himself out of sobriety, play games, and use up what little hard-earned money she made for gambling purposes. I had never felt so empty and alone; I sunk into depression and didn’t have the will to live anymore.
firstTime: When I cried myself to sleep without anyone knowing.

name: Shannon
lastTime: Today
lonelinessMeans: Lack of meaning to life.
mostLonely: I feel the most lonely when I think about my future. As an unwed, childless woman in her 40’s, I worry about dying alone. Once my parents and older sibling pass away, will I still matter to anyone? Will anyone shed a tear if I get sick or pass away? Does my life matter at that point? I do not regret my decision not to have children. For many reasons, it was the right choice for me. But there is a finality that comes when one is childless, yet no longer able to have children. That finality can be a difficult burden to bear.
firstTime: When I went away to college and didn’t know anyone.

name: Sakhile
lastTime: Last night. I couldn't sleep. When I was 12 years old my mother told me I was HIV positive. I began to isolate myself from my family and nobody bothered to pull me back in.
lonelinessMeans: Loneliness is being sad about being alone. Loneliness is having absolutely no one to talk to. Loneliness is going through the most difficult thing in the entire world with no one to hold your hand.
mostLonely: I was sick a lot during my teenage years because I didn‘t adhere to my medicine as I should have. My illness wasn‘t something we ever discussed, it was taboo, swept under the carpet. I suffered alone and in silence.
firstTime: When I came to understand what HIV was and how it would affect my future in my early teens, there was no one to guide me or sympathise.

name: Anonymous
lonelinessMeans: When I was young it meant pain. It represented some sort of punishment for the crime of just being me. Now, in my forties, it’s a time for myself. Time for self reflection and checking in with myself, my values and the path I am on and the choices I am making.
mostLonely: I was locked in my room and wasn’t allowed to go to school for what seemed to be a week or so but it could have been just a few days. I was eight. My step father forbade my other family members from speaking to me. I was being punished for going to my best friends house without permission. It took me years of loneliness to come to terms with what happened to me. This specific event, the beating and subsequent bruising that prevented me from going to school, being alone in a room, eating my meals by myself, hearing the noises of the rest of the house busy with activity I was excluded from, was the loneliest I have ever felt. The loneliness was a dark familiar pit I clung to and tried to fill with negative behaviours and toxic relationships for years. I despised the loneliness but it was also a part of me. After many years of therapy and a loving supportive relationship with my husband, I finally let go of loneliness or maybe it let go of me.
firstTime: My 13th birthday. My mom had recently separated from my stepfather and had started dating a new man. My younger sister was living with her father (my soon to be ex-stepfather) and my older sister was out with her friends. I spent my 13th birthday by myself sitting on a climbing apparatus in a local school yard. I remember looking up at the very few twinkling stars and thinking this is loneliness. I cried and cried.

name: Sam
lastTime: Today
lonelinessMeans: Not being able to thrive as your true self, having to give up and wait for someone else's approval... loneliness is wanting to do something with your life but going in the other direction out of fear.
mostLonely: Believe it or not, when I got engaged. Life was supposed to be fun and exciting and my family was happy and his were happy... only he wouldn‘t plan the wedding, or talk about the future or help me, I felt an overwhelming sense of loneliness not being able to talk to friends or family about how I felt, knowing that this may be the wrong thing to do... but not wanting to ruin their perception. Living a life for someone else and waiting to find out where you are going and what you are supposed to be doing, when that someone else won‘t talk to you... that is lonely and it‘s makes me feel pathetic that I allow it.
firstTime: After a break up a few years back I would sit and stare at the wall in my bedroom after work until it became dark outside, I was so alone, the feeling was so hard to deal with that all I could do is sit there and hope when I woke up I'd snap out of it and feel whole again.

name: Anonymous
lastTime: Today, yesterday, the day before that, and the day before that... and probably tomorrow.
lonelinessMeans: Feeling like you have no one to talk to who understands what you're going through.
mostLonely:
A year ago I moved to an isolated island in the Caribbean to pursue my dream of becoming a physician. I came here excited to meet people who shared my interests. At first I didn‘t think much about being "lonely" – I had just moved to a foreign place and I didn‘t know anyone yet, after all. I was like, give it more time, you‘ll make some friends and it will be great. But even though I have made some friends here it has been more out of proximity than actual connection. The students here do not share the same values as I do and they look upon my hobbies and lifestyle with derision. I realized that I couldn‘t actually open up to anyone about what was on my mind – and in the rare moments that I did, I was met with polite disinterest, confusion, or even at times veiled disdain. So I stopped telling people about myself. I stopped caring to make human connection. I felt that the people I was surrounded with were completely unrelatable and I started to wonder if it was really me, and not them - everyone else seemed to be making friends. I have "friends." I just don't like them that much, and I don't think they like me that much either.

On top of feeling alienated from my peers, medical school is, obviously, a tough program to get through. I am stressed and irritable all the time. Any mental health issues that I seemingly had under control before I got here came rushing back into my life like a freight train. I have one good source of support, my significant other, but I can feel his palpable frustration when I complain about the same things over and over again. I can feel my negativity weighing him down when I tell him about how I want to give up on this "dream" and come home. I can almost hear his sigh when I text him telling him I can't do this anymore. It is difficult for him, being removed from this situation, to understand what I am going through, to understand how tough it is.

So I'm lonely because I don't feel close to the people around me who would actually get what I'm dealing with, and I'm lonely because the person who I do feel connected to doesn't understand. I think about suicide a lot. I'm almost done with this program. I just remind myself that this is almost over. I'm counting the days.
firstTime: When someone asked me if I had any new friends at school.

name: Catriona
mostLonely:
As I walked back along the darkening streets tonight, an evening in early May, the birds were still singing and the smell of spring was fresh and floral in the air around me. It reminded me, viscerally, suddenly, of the hill behind my childhood home that Dad and I used to climb after dinner. We’d bring a banana or chocolate mousse and eat them sitting on the bench at the top, looking out at the panoramic views of the city’s old stone and slate roofs.

Sometimes, memories like these fill you with warmth, a welcome gift proffered at an unexpected moment. Sometimes, they just serve to remind you of all the things that are different now. In this case, I immediately feel nostalgic for my Dad and my secret language, confined to those pre-adolescent years; for those familiar horizons, the sense of belonging they provoke; for the irrelevance of the future then, a blurry, intangible time in a child’s mind.

Since moving here, I’ve been lonely most of the time. Even when I’m with newly-made friends, even when I’m laughing, even when I’m absorbed in a talk or a class or a reading, there are always people and places I miss.

I’d already got used to the absence of my city’s old stones, slate roofs, many hills. I’d got used to being an ocean away from my family, my friends, my first boyfriend. But it was different then. Now, I’ve moved away not just from my first home, but also my second, the one I’ve constructed over almost seven years and that I’m still actively shaping every time I return.

When I first moved here, I was frustrated by the knowledge that in every coffee shop and lecture hall, there were bound to be like-minded people, potential new friends. This is a university town, after all. There are all sorts of interesting people here and I knew, tantalisingly, that I was probably walking past them in the narrow historic streets every single day.

It was different in the place that has become my second home. There, the loneliness of the first six months were combatted by making friends and basking in the knowledge that we’d have another four years together in the same place, embarking upon and later completing our first university degrees. Here, there’s barely enough time to finish the reading lists, let alone spend hours over a beer getting to know someone. Given the nature of academic rigour in this place, the former activity often takes precedence.

Now that I’m almost done, the course finishing in a flash of visiting scholar talks, library fines and wine receptions, I am telling myself that those potential friends don’t matter anymore. I am telling myself that I will walk over the cobbles and down the lanes content with my own company, happy in the knowledge that my community is elsewhere and it’s not going anywhere: it’s me that left, it’s me that will return. I am telling myself, as my partner so often tells me from across the ocean (in the other direction, this time), to be happy with what I am doing rather than what I could be doing. Some days it works, and I feel strength in solitude, rather than weakness in isolation.

But some days, when the smell of spring is especially strong, or the sound of silence becomes too loud, it makes me wish for another time, another place. And on those days, I ride it out, I try to write a little, I (often unsuccessfully) avoid reaching for my phone to replicate absent people’s presences with messages (because it’s never the same), and I remind myself that I chose this. I chose to move away and move away and move away again. And equally, I will choose to move back.

In this way, loneliness is a temporary state, and, ultimately, a necessary one. For without loneliness, how could we ever truly appreciate company? Without loneliness, would those memories return to us so visceral, full-bodied, nostalgia-inducing? I don’t think so. It is loneliness, then, that allows us, that gives us the time and space and necessary aloneness, to reflect on all that was and all that is still to come.

name: Natalie
lastTime: This week.
mostLonely:
August 2017, it was a sunny summer day. I was sitting in my back yard with my 3 rescue Chihuahuas snuggled at my feet. I was talking to my pups and saying how much I love them. I was all alone, except for my pups and the nature of birds chirping in the cedar trees next to me. I was on social media on my phone, and reading all the posts of others (friends/family/others). They all seemed socially successful in life that day, I observed. My friends/family and strangers‘ posts were those of them going to work, going to school, going to the mall, going out for coffee with friends, etc. I was overwhelmed by the thought, I had no one to call up or text and say "Let's get together." I wasn't able to drive (that day due to fatigue) from my Synthroid I'm on after my Thyroid Cancer. I was feeling very low self esteem and I wanted a visitor to chat with and cheer me up, but everyone was busy, except for myself. I gave my pups some huge hugs, and that made me feel happier!

Some days are still quite lonely, that's okay. I have learned to accept it as rest time, thinking time, and peaceful quiet time. I make sure to make these lonely days, great days! I start the day by writing, playing with my pups, exercising, listening to music, baking, going to the beach, dancing around the house, watching funny movies, and sipping some good coffee! Everyday, I'm thankful to be here to share my story.
firstTime:
After I had Thyroid Cancer in 2010, I observed some friends pulling away from our friendship. I soon was left with a handful of friends (who I love and they love me). I would notice some days I couldn't go attend social events like I have had done before my Cancer. I was was very tired, and weak, for months.

I would be home alone, resting/healing. My family and friends, would be attending social events like birthday parties, family dinners, and even my daughter's school dance recitals. I would be home by myself, feeling lonely and falling into a depression from lacking social contacts and connections. It was a difficult, emotional year for me.

name: Swords
lastTime: Sunday
mostLonely: When I try to make a friend and their interests are alcohol and mine are adventures and swords and history, and not only are they they not asking me anything back and nodding off the things I share voluntarily, I have to really work at asking questions to keep them talking about themselves.
firstTime: Wandering the school yard singing to myself and making up stories during recess.

name: Anonymous
lastTime: Last night at 3:00 am. As usual I could not get to sleep easily. My sister, who I am currently living with, fell asleep before me and I suddenly felt entirely alone in the darkness of the night. I looked out the window to see other apartment buildings with a few scattered lights turned on and wondered who else might be awake with me. Even though they were visible and across the street, they were so far away.
lonelinessMeans: Feeling disconnected and isolated in that disconnection. More than anything loneliness for me is about feeling alone in a crowd; a certain kind of sadness with not finding my tribe; an inability to relate to the popular values presented in mainstream media in North America; not being able to find a place of comfort and safety outside of my own home; a disappointment and disconnect with the mainstream ways of the world.
mostLonely: Later in life I wound up in a leadership role with more than forty employees and several direct reports at the company where I worked. It was a high profile position that involved public speaking, television appearances, attending galas, and meeting upon meeting. I was inundated with people coming and going from my office. I had a narcissistic boss who was emotionally abusive. I realized that I was the buffer for all these wonderfully talented people but I couldn‘t really talk about how difficult the experience was for me with anyone at the office. When things became really challenging, I would take long walks, stay in the washroom for longer periods of time, or I would get sick and stay home from work. Even though I had this highly public job, I was utterly lonely.
firstTime: At a birthday party when I was 6 or 7 year old. All of the other kids were playing games, yelling, and making noise — generally having a fun time I suppose. But I just wasn't up to joining in. I knew that, generally speaking, I was more at ease in quiet, one-on-one situations where a real connection can be shared between friends. Unable to join in the fun, I retreated to a quiet room to play alone until my mom came to pick me up.

name: Austin
lastTime: As long as I have had memories.
lonelinessMeans: When people see you, but it’s not really you.
mostLonely: Not too long ago I fell into a deep depression where I developed severe anxiety and gender dysphoria. Nothing could fill the void in my heart; my job, cars, friends or even substance abuse. Growing up I was always more inclined to be feminine and couldn’t understand why it was so shameful to be gay or transgender. With constant pressure from my family to not come out I tended to shut down or close myself off from everyone around me. Until I finally burst letting all my feelings out all at once and to such a relief my mom wasn’t angry. Although she still isn’t very comfortable with me being transgender I’m sure one day she will when she sees me happy to be myself. For now I’m still finding my way in this world, often alone and against the beliefs of everyone around me. Shout out to all the renegades out there, just know that there are others even if they aren’t near.
firstTime: When I realized I felt too feminine to be a boy.

name: Anonymous
lastTime: Two weeks ago
lonelinessMeans: That you are unable to share your everyday or exceptional experiences.
mostLonely: I was a new mum and had recently lost both my parents. These were profound experiences that affected me deeply, in good and bad ways. None of my close friends had experienced any of this which made it difficult to share what I was feeling. Ultimately I feel I‘m more "human" because of what I learned from this time.
firstTime: As a child when I was hospitalized in a ward by myself. My mother was unable to visit, I think because she found it too difficult to see me ill.

name: Scout
mostLonely: I think I‘ve felt lonely throughout my life and I am truly alone except for my dog. Christmas guts me every year. I already accept there will be not even a phone call for me. I have bought a pre-cooked meal and a slice of pie. My evening walk with the dog takes my soul every year for curtains are open into living rooms full of families and friends, I can hear them, sometimes smell their turkey dinners, but most of all I feel all their happiness knowing I will never have it. I get home and get into bed and cry and will the day away with sleep.

name: Daniel
lastTime: Last night. It was later in the evening, I was walking back to my residence building after some practice studio time I had. I saw one of my roommates leave the building with a big group of people I'm assuming were friends or classmates. I waved to him. He begrudgingly nodded back. I felt my heart drop. Not only did he already have a large group of friends only a month into college, while I have none, but we're barely acquaintances and we live together. Loneliness hit me like a fucking truck right then.
lonelinessMeans: When everything you do is alone, but not the nice kind of alone like when you choose to see a movie by yourself. It's not being alone voluntarily, it's being forced into it. Loneliness is a bubble around me that's constantly pushing out bad vibes to make sure it's never cured. It's a crutch that I have to lean on to get by and a reason to feel sorry for myself.
mostLonely: There is no one time I felt the most lonely, I think. For me, lonely has been an ever growing sensation. It multiplies with every realization I have that my old friends don‘t care about me anymore, with every excited thought that quickly dies because I have no one who will want to hear it, and with each event I consider going to then don‘t because I know I‘ll never have as much fun alone as I would with other people. Loneliness lives in my stomach constantly, and I can feel it eating all my organs with each week that passes. It‘s like a parasite. But then again, I'm only 18, what do I fucking know.
firstTime: Actually one of the first times I realized I was lonely was when I had friends, they just never wanted to hear what I had to say and made no effort to talk to me. I realized sure, I had friends, but to them I wasn't a friend. Friendship is the kind of thing that needs to be reciprocated otherwise it's void, so I didn't really have anyone.

name: Jeanette
lastTime: Coming home from a disappointing date
mostLonely:
I was working on a cruise ship and was emergency disembarked in Barbados for a suspected appendicitis. It turned out to be a ruptured ovarian cyst. The doctor told me I wouldn‘t be able to have kids. I spent 2 days in the hospital and 2 days in a hotel before being flown back to meet the ship. Those days in Barbados were the loneliest I‘ve ever been. I was in pain, I was scared, I'd been told something I always wanted wouldn't happen and I had nothing to distract myself (no television or books). I couldn't call my family or friends. Besides the medical staff checking on me, I only had the ship's port agent stop by with my passport. It was awful.

3 years later, on my last cruise contract, I was trained for a care program where crew will stay in port with passengers or crew members who are dealing with a crisis. The new program was designed to avoid what happened to me. I cried during the training and told the trainer how important this new program was. It would have made all the difference for me.

name: Ellen
lastTime: 6 months ago
lonelinessMeans: Isolation
mostLonely: My partner of nearly five years and I broke up. It was not a healthy relationship. My partner was abusive towards me and people knew she could be difficult to deal with. When we broke up, I was the one who had to leave and the queer "community" that we shared abandoned me and isolated me because my ex wouldn‘t acknowledge the break up and continued to party and go out. I‘ve never felt more lonely in my life. All these relationships I had spent nearly five years putting effort into completely disappeared. People who are supposed to have good politics, and work in social work, or are doulas, took the easy route, fully knowing my ex‘s behaviour towards me was unacceptable. She offered them more social capital than I did and I lost my entire life.

name: Roman
lonelinessMeans: Nobody paying attention.
mostLonely:
When I sat in a coffee shop and realized everyone around me was locked into their electronic device. Earbuds in place, there was not an inch of space into which I could start a conversation.

As a society, I believe we are the architects of our isolation. But I‘m hopeful that one day the need for real interaction in a meaningful way will get people to put down their devices and casually strike up a conversation with other people nearby.

name: Sabrina
lastTime: Yesterday
lonelinessMeans: When your told people will always be there for you but when you need them most they are never there to help
mostLonely: When my mom and her ex left to go out and they never came back home until the next day
firstTime: When my mom would always leave to go out with friends instead of staying home

name: Andrew
lastTime: I went all the way home to visit and no one was there. Except the cats.
lonelinessMeans: Loneliness is the feeling you get when you realize you do like other people.
mostLonely: I spent two hours alone wandering around an IKEA because I was too nervous to ask people to come with me. I ate two hotdogs and bought nothing.
firstTime: The first time I felt truly alone is when all my friends made me their emotional punching bag at the young age of twelve. I had no one.

name: Maisa
lastTime:
The last time I felt lonely was a few days ago. It was dusk and I decided to go for a walk around the new neighbourhood I just moved into. It’s a residential area, with calm streets, beautiful houses and little parks. I like to look at each house and see what kind of lives are being lived in it. I could smell food being made inside homes, and I could hear kids playing in the backyard. I realized how badly I crave family life, and miss my family who lives all the way in Brazil.

I felt lonely because there is always a dissonance to what I am experiencing. I never lived in big Canadian houses growing up. They look like the movies.

I never walked my golden retriever in a park. I never ran unsupervised with my friends, freely, around the neighbourhood.

Instead of bemoaning how badly I miss Brazil - the music, the warmth, the colours and trees, and most importantly, my language - I am here now. I am trying to let go of my old life (kicking and screaming) and build a Canadian life. It feels like the loneliest thing in the world to do. I don’t know anybody else who is doing it. I have one foot here, and one foot there all the time. And I wonder if when I am walking around my neighbourhood, standing outside somebody’s house trying to negotiate all of this...whether anyone inside can understand what it feels like.
lonelinessMeans: Not being able to relate to others, physically being away from familiar people, sounds, language, food.
mostLonely:
My loneliness comes in waves. I feel very lonely when I think about my niece back home, and how I’ve only met her once, and haven’t seen her in person in two years. I feel lonely that she gets to hang up on me whenever she likes on FaceTime because I’m not truly physically a person to her. And that can also be a little bit funny.

I feel lonely the most around the holidays because I have to spend it with other people’s families. I am so grateful that I have somewhere to go, but at the same time, I get exhausted having to adopt other people’s lives, customs, etc. My mind is always somewhere else around the holidays. I have definitely cried in bathrooms after Christmas dinner.

I feel lonely when I hear people talking about immigrants in a particular way, because I am an immigrant, even though I don’t look like what people perceive an immigrant to be. I feel lonely that my partner doesn’t like my country’s cuisine. I feel lonely when I want to greet people with a warm hug and kisses on their cheeks, but Canadians don’t really like being touched. I feel lonely when nobody asks me about Brazil, or asks how my family is doing.
firstTime: When people kept forgetting that I was foreign. My English is flawless, and so it’s hard to discern that I am from a different country. I feel lonely each time I have to remind my close friends and my partner of 7 years that I had a different experience than they did. They forget. They just forget, and will start to tell stories and say "you know?" and truly, I don’t know a lot of the time. I don’t know the TV shows they are referring to, the old movies, the places, the regular Canadian experiences they had.

name: Child of the ‘50s
lastTime: Holidays. Memories of what was can make it a very lonely time.
lonelinessMeans: It’s missing something or feeling disconnected from what the world says should be a busy exciting fun time. I’ve felt lonely in a room of happy partying people. I am not good watching frivolous stupidity. Guess I’m a loner who is never lonely. I visit Archives and never want to leave because I discover things that excite me. I can have great conversations with strangers in odd places and feel connected. Loneliness is so different for everyone. I don’t need people around me. I do need a few I can connect with for specific interests and projects. That sustains me.
mostLonely: I’m too old to put a specific on that but think my first Christmas away from family would be near the top. I could hardly make the call home and not cry. But I see it now as just a stepping stone to growing up. Life will send more difficult times than a Christmas away from family. You will find you are not alone at facing sad lonely times. That’s when it’s time to reach out. Find the lonely. Create your own special time. Make a new memory. You don’t have to conform to society’s normal expectation and tradition. Change the expectation and tradition. Don’t focus on yourself and the loneliness will lessen. Look outward and you’ll find what or who was meant to brighten your day. Find your purpose and you won’t have time for loneliness. Be kind to yourself. Buy yourself your favourite birthday cake, light the candles, sing the song and eat the whole thing! Because you can. Because you’re alive.
firstTime: At a party. It wasn’t my scene. The conversation was mind-numbing. Would have preferred to be at home with a good book.

name: Lisa
lastTime: When I realized I was married but not to my soulmate. (This was many years ago and I have since changed my life to remedy that situation)
lonelinessMeans: Being cast adrift, unable to connect with people around me but most importantly, unable to connect with myself.
mostLonely: I was attending a large church that I had donated my design services to -- I had done the interior design for an entire campus of buildings for them. Both of my children were baptized there and I tried to attend every Sunday I was able. I was in the midst of struggling to understand the burgeoning special needs of my now 3 year old daughter, feeling so daunted, frustrated, scared and alone. I got a text from the nursery, telling me my daughter was throwing a tantrum and asking if I could come back. I ducked out of the Sunday morning service and was walking across the campus to the children‘s building. One of the mothers I knew was out there walking as well. She asked how I was and I admitted to my bewilderment with the health and behavioral problems with my little girl. She looked at me smugly, knowingly, and suggested that if I would stay at home and give my daughter the time and attention she clearly needed, perhaps this wouldn't be a problem for me any longer. I was stunned, shocked, horrified. Every possible molecule of mother-guilt surged up inside me and I realized that she didn't understand. And I wondered if I would ever find a like-minded soul who had walked the path I was on. I felt impossibly alone right then. And I have tried really, really hard to never judge another mother's path. It can be incredibly lonely at times.
firstTime: When I was a teenager and understood for the first time what a solitary journey our life's path truly is.

name: Sarah
mostLonely: The time I felt the most lonely was at the 17km mark of my first half marathon. I trained for weeks and begged everyone I knew to please come support me at the finish line. Not one person came. I knew for sure at km 17 that no one was there for me because you had to run near where the finish line was. I spent the next 4 kilometres feeling sorry for myself.

name: Anonymous
lonelinessMeans: To me, one of the worst things about being lonely is that it can often seem like something desirable. There's something sexy about being sad, alone, tormented by "deep thoughts." Drinking in the rain at 4:00 AM listening to post-rock. It feels like you're in a movie (think Ryan Gosling in Drive), and as long as you can keep dissociating from reality, it actually feels good. But that feeling doesn't last long, because it's predicated on the idea that "if only people could see me now, they'd know how tortured and lonely and sexy I am" -- and no one is watching. So when you reluctantly come back to reality, you're tipsy and soaking wet in the middle of the night wondering why you ever "wanted" to be alone in the first place. And that's when the real loneliness hits you.

name: Anonymous
lonelinessMeans: Not having anyone to go to, anyone there for you, feeling like no one understands you.
mostLonely:
It was my first day on kindergarten, the first time I had ever really been around other kids my age. I was so excited, but of course nervous to meet all my new peers. I remember getting there and my mom had to leave for work, so I waited patiently by myself for the class door to open. I watched as other kids began to arrive with their parents. There I was standing all alone, in the cold fall breeze, watching all my soon to be classmates latching onto their parents and smiling. I stood there for another ten minutes observing all of them. Eventually the door opened and the teacher started to welcome everyone. I looked around as all the kids hugged their parents and said goodbye to them, their parents hugging and kissing them back. I was the only kid there that had no parent to kiss or hug them goodbye, because my mom was a single parent and couldn‘t afford to be late for work.

Throughout the day I was laughing and smiling and completely ignoring what had happened earlier. The memory had completely swept out of my mind, I was too focused playing with all my new friends.

After the day had ended, i soon realized it was time to leave class and go home. Our teacher announced she would dismiss us from the class once she met our parents. All the kids started walking out of the door, practically leaping into their parents arms, blabbering on about how amazing their day was. Their parents all smiled while they rambled on aimlessly.

Me on the other hand......

I had to wait 45 minutes after class had ended for my mom to come pick me up. I sat there, while my teacher just typed away at her computer. The class was silent and made me feel stuck. I just wanted to be like all the other kids in my class. I wanted to be able to hug my mom goodbye, I wanted to be able to leave class on time and tell her about my day. I wanted to be normal, or what I, being five, thought was supposed to be normal. I felt all alone.
firstTime: 5 years old.

name: Christopher
lonelinessMeans: Loneliness is that overwhelming feeling of not having a shoulder to cry on, a laugh to share, memories to reminisce about, memories to build with someone
mostLonely:
My first memory represents the most lonely instance in my life. Since that, loneliness has been a constant companion.

I was adopted at 18 months. My first memory is sitting on a window bench in the CAS building in Mississauga. It was a renovated old Victorian house. The bench I was in the cove of a bay window. I remember seeing my adoptive parents filling out forms and talking with the caseworker at a table across the room. I was facing out the window. It was a rainy day and it was starting to get dark outside. I remember the rain hitting the window and drops rolling down. I now know that I didn‘t feel warmth and happiness, I felt loneliness and fear. It's The type of loneliness that isn't born of absent companions or loved ones, it's an infant feeling the pure and absolute envelope of loneliness.

Since that memory, I have always felt singular in life. Having a "blood relative" is something that I have never known. My parents tried as best they could. They simply couldn't be that. When "The Lonelies" hit, they can hit really hard. The feeling of being TRULY SINGULAR has a feeling attached to it that is really hard to describe.

name: Military Base
lastTime: Everyday my husband is deployed or tasked and i am here
lonelinessMeans: Feeling empty. Sad. Lost. Like you have nowhere or no one to turn to. You could be in a room with 100 people and still feel lonely.
mostLonely: Again my husband has deployed after we moved to a new town. I don‘t know a soul here. I feel soo alone. The kids don't have friends and families are provinces away.   People are so unfriendly here i just want to go home. This is the most lonely i have ever felt.
firstTime: My husband deployed when my son was 2 days old. We lived in town where family was available but no one came to see me or our son. I spent hours upon hours of the year he was gone alone. People would call but no one would visit. And when they would call everyone said the same thing "this too shall pass." i didn't want to hear it would pass i wanted to hear its okay to be sad.

name: Alyson
mostLonely:
In April, I rollerbladed down to the Waterfront around sunset. This is an activity I‘ve done several times throughout my 5 years in Toronto. I felt so content sitting by the water with my headphones in as I admired our beautiful city. As I looked around the boardwalk, I realized I was the only person there who was not only alone, but not with a significant other.

I have been single for 5 years and have never paid too much attention to it; I have a career, my own apartment and while men have come and gone through this time, none of them have caused much disruption or disturbance in my happiness or life. As I sat on the boardwalk, I wondered if neglecting this aspect of my life is what has lead to me spending so much time alone; I go to Allan Gardens alone, I go to the beach alone, I go to TIFF alone, I go to Nuit Blanche alone.

While I enjoy and am not embarrassed by spending so much time solo, sometimes a pang of loneliness creeps up and needs to be acknowledged. I usually try to suppress them as they threaten my outlook of living a happy and enjoyable life.

On the boardwalk on the unseasonably warm April night, I started looking at all of the couples and comparing them to my friends who have significant others. I thought of all of my friends who disappear when they start dating someone new and sometimes never return; I wonder how many people on the boardwalk have traded in nights with best friends for nights with significant others. I thought of all of my friends who give up little pieces of themselves daily ; I wonder how many people on the boardwalk are neglecting who they are for the sake of keeping that significant other.

For me, my loneliness is a reminder that I’ve made the best choices for me to live a happy life. I think of what I would have given up with every potential significant other I’ve met just to make it work; it wasn’t worth it. I think of my friends’ relationships and how those dynamics (often abusive) wouldn’t fit in my life.

I would rather be on the boardwalk alone surrounded by couples than changing myself and my life for the sake of having someone to go to the Waterfront with.

Plus, if I had someone with me- I would have to take out my headphones and I hate doing that ;)

name: Liz
lastTime: 6 months ago
mostLonely: there’s no one time, but i was completely alone and almost fully nocturnal for about 6 months. i’d maybe see family members for about 10 minutes a day, if i was lucky. this was in the pre-ubiquitous internet era, and before i had a cell phone, so i was completely alone. i was dealing with some health issues, so i couldn’t read books. all i had was tv and my dog (when she wasn’t sleeping/hanging out upstairs with my sleeping family members). you start talking to things -- yourself, out loud, your food, the tv, the walls. you develop an even richer inner life, filled with more characters and more fantasy, because it’s all you have. you try to squeeze every second out of possible interactions, because they’re so special and small and fleeting. i’m sort of amazed i survived it.
firstTime: when i would stay home from school sick and read tons and be excited about my life, until about 2pm, at which point i’d just be bored and vaguely nauseated and wishing i had someone to talk to.

name: Joelle
lastTime: When I was on the couch and mama and dad and Thomas were in the bedroom.
lonelinessMeans: When I'm all by myself.
mostLonely: I went into the car to go to daycare. It took a long time waiting for mama and Thomas.

name: AJ
lastTime: TODAY, my Mum's birthday.
lonelinessMeans: Not having anyone with shared memories to talk with anymore.
mostLonely: I can‘t identify just one time of feeling most lonely. My childhood was full of loneliness, my father kind but Victorian, being 35 years older than my mum. So I never learned to question anything, just had to go along with what my parents told me to believe and had nobody my own age with whom I could talk about things. As an adult, the fact that I had a half-brother who I called "uncle" out of old fashioned politeness imposed by my parents, hit hard after mum died in 2009. This because he had died at the age of 52, many years before and I then felt I had been ‘deprived‘ of a happy relationship, due to some family discord and lack of understanding on my father‘s part. I could go on, but you don't have to be alone to be lonely; I feel lonely on a regular basis, but that doesn't mean I am always unhappy, just wish I could share more memories......
firstTime: After my mum died and there was nobody left who knew all the same people and to whom I could tell news. As a child, realising that almost everyone else had siblings - I had none.

name: Anonymous
lastTime: A few weeks ago I realized I can't keep calling my ex for comfort anymore because it isn't fair to him. We were together for four years and even though it's what I want and was my choice, realizing you can't lean on the person who knows and understands you better than anyone is a devastatingly lonely feeling.
lonelinessMeans: I enjoy solitude and like to spend a large majority of my time alone. So loneliness to me is an absence on an emotional level. Often when I tell a story about my past, I can see a change in people's eyes. There is a glaze that comes over when they can't understand or get uncomfortable by some of the traumatic events that have shaped my life. It's a very lonely feeling when the person who made you feel safe to open up, is doing the equivalent of backing up slowly and running away with their facial expression.
mostLonely: I was raised as a Jehovah‘s Witness. I struggled to leave the faith for years, living a secret life where I hid many things about myself. I used coping mechanisms of drugs and alcohol because I felt trapped and was severely depressed and suicidal. When you leave that faith you get cut off from everyone in it. I knew what would come and I couldn‘t bare to say goodbye. These were people who I had known and loved for years, some my entire life. People who had told me they would be in my life forever. It was almost five years ago when my mother left my house for the last time, when she realized I had finally really left the faith, I wept but she didn‘t. She just said goodbye.
